Knowledge Point: No good morphological definition of nouns is possible in Mauwake, as there is no inflection for number \REF{ex:3:x1}, gender or class,\footnote{Gender or class systems are widespread in Papuan languages \citep[77]{Foley1986}. Especially in the \textsc{tng} languages a covert system is common \citep[58]{Wurm1982}, where the noun class determines what existential verb is used with each noun.} or case, in the noun itself. Especially the lack of plural marking is typical of the nouns in Trans-New Guinea languages \citep[36]{Wurm1982}. The glosses in \REF{ex:3:x1} indicate a singular/plural alternative in the nouns, but the singular form in the glosses of other examples is to be understood as neutral regarding number.
Content 1: \gll siowa wiawi | \gls dog(s) father(s) | \glt `The dog's/dogs' owner(s)'
Content 2: \gll siowa wiawi | \gls dog(s) father(s) | \glt `The dog's/dogs' owner(s)'

Knowledge Point: The syntactic function provides the best criterion for defining a noun in Mauwake. Nouns function mainly as the head of a noun phrase, often the head being the only element in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}.\footnote{Sometimes an adjective, a quantifier or a genitive pronoun looks like a head of a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, but those cases are elliptical, and the head noun is recoverable.} They can also function as a qualifier or, more rarely, as a modifier in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}. In \REF{ex:3:x2}, the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s function as subject and object, and are manifested by just nouns.
Content 1: \gll Emeria=ke iwera fiirim-i-mik. | \gls woman=CF coconut gather-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `(The) women gather coconuts.'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: A \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{phonologically}} interesting feature common to nouns and adjectives is that the majority of both end in the vowel <a>.\footnote{In the other word classes words ending in <a> do occur but they are very infrequent.} Inside noun phrases this vowel, when unstressed, is usually elided preceding a vowel and often also preceding a consonant. In cases like \REF{ex:3:x3}, where there are two or more possible places for elision, the vowel most easily drops at the end of an adjective preceding an intensifier. Elision is also acceptable in two or more sites within one \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}; this is shown in \REF{ex:3:x3} and \REF{ex:3:x4}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll koor(a) kemena manek(a) akena nain | \gls house inside big very that1 | \glt `the very big room'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: Both nouns \REF{ex:3:x7} and adjectives \REF{ex:3:x8} may be derived from verbs with the nominalizer suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owa}.
Content 1: \gll mua \textbf{soop-owa} sira | \gls man bury-NMZ custom | \glt `the burial custom (lit: the custom of burying men)'
Content 2: \gll Emi \textbf{kekan-owa} nain puuk-a-mik. | \gls taboo be.strong-NMZ that1 cut-PA-1/3p | \glt `They broke the strong taboo rule.'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: Verbs can be derived from both adjectives and nouns by zero verb formation \REF{ex:3:x482}, \REF{ex:3:x484} or by the inchoative verbalizer \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar} (\textstyleParagraphCharChar{\stepcounter{nx}{\thenx}}). (See \sectref{sec:3.8.2.2} for these processes and more examples.)
Content 1: \gll Miiw-aasa samor-a-k. | \gls land-canoe bad-PA-3s | \glt `He broke/ruined the car.'
Content 2: \gll Iwer(a) ififa palis-i-ya. | \gls coconut dry pair.of.coconuts-NPS-PR.3s | \glt `He is tying dry coconuts into pairs.'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: A clear morphological \textstyleEmphasizedWords{difference} between nouns and adjectives is that adverbs may be formed from some adjectives by deleting the word-final <a> \REF{ex:3:x19}, but they cannot be formed from nouns in the same way.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Syntactically}}, there are a few similarities between nouns and adjectives. Both can function as a modifier following the head noun in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, although adjectives \REF{ex:3:x9} are much more common in this position. In \citegen[161]{HopperEtAl1985} terms, it is nouns whose categorial status has been reduced, i.e. nouns that are not fully individuated in the discourse \REF{ex:3:x10}, that can function in this modifier position.
Content 1: \gll aasa \textbf{awona} fain | \gls canoe old this | \glt `this old canoe'
Content 2: \gll mua \textbf{sira} \textbf{eliwa} | \gls man manner good | \glt `a well-mannered man (=a good man)'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: The intensifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `real(ly), very' can also modify both adjectives \REF{ex:3:x3} and nouns \REF{ex:3:x11}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll mua \textbf{akena} | \gls man real/true | \glt `a real man'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: Complete or partial reduplication of adjectives is a common strategy for indicating plurality in Austronesian languages \citep[62]{Wurm1982}, and it also occurs to some extent in many Papuan languages, including Mauwake. Reduplication is a more productive process in the adjectives \REF{ex:3:x12}, \REF{ex:3:x481}, but it is possible for a few nouns too \REF{ex:3:x13}, \REF{ex:3:x1859} (\sectref{sec:3.2.6.2}).
Content 1: \gll ifa \textbf{samo-samora} | \gls snake RDP-bad | \glt `bad snakes'
Content 2: \gll Maa \textbf{ele-eliwa} sesek-a-mik. | \gls thing/food RDP-good sell-PA-1/3p | \glt `They sold good foods (different kinds).'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Owow-owowa} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls RDP-village go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went to many villages.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{sira-sira} | \gls custom-custom | \glt `many customs', `different kinds'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: The syntactic \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{differences}} between nouns and adjectives are as follows. Adjectives do not function as head of a noun phrase. The cases where they would seem to do so are in fact cases of ellipsis, and the head noun must be recoverable from the context, either linguistic or extra-linguistic \REF{ex:3:x14}.
Content 1: \gll {\O} awona nain p-ekap-e! | \gls {\O} old that1 BPX-come-IMP.2s | \glt `Bring the old one!'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: Only a noun may occur as a qualifier in a noun phrase, preceding the head noun \REF{ex:3:x15}. In some of these cases it is difficult to decide whether they are really \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s with a qualifier and a head noun, or compound nouns. But if the latter is the case, then the restriction applies that an adjective cannot be the first element in a compound noun.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{mera} eka | \gls fish water | \glt `fish soup'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: An adjective cannot be the only element following a genitive pronoun, but a noun can. Even in elliptical expressions an adjective following a genitive pronoun is not very acceptable \REF{ex:3:x17}.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: An exception to this rule is the adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} `big' \REF{ex:3:x105}. The expression \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yiena Maneka} `our Lord' (literally: our Big one), is probably formed following Tok Pisin \textstyleForeignWords{Bikpela bilong yumi.}\footnote{Non-prototypical adjectives are discussed later in this section; `big' is a prototypical adjective, so its use in a typically nominal position is an exception.}
Content 1: \gll wi Amerika \textbf{maneka}, unuma Magerka | \gls 3p.UNM America big name MacArthur | \glt `the leader of the Americans, whose name was MacArthur'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: Only an adjective functions as the head of an adjective phrase. In that position it may be modified by intensity adverbs (\sectref{sec:3.9.2}). Of these, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{lawisiw} `rather' does not modify nouns at all \REF{ex:3:x18}; \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `very' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek} `enough' may modify nouns as well; \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wenup} `very' can do that too, but as a noun modifier it has a somewhat restricted use and a different meaning: `many'.
Content 1: \gll Mera nain \textbf{lawisiw} \textbf{maneka} \textbf{akena}. | \gls fish that1 rather big very | \glt `That fish is rather huge.'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: What further obscures the area of nouns and adjectives is the fact that there are a number of words that sometimes function like nouns \REF{ex:3:x20}, sometimes like adjectives \REF{ex:3:x21}, and that also semantically could be like either.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pina} maneka kamenap? | \gls weight big what.like | \glt `What is the weight like?', `How big is the weight?'
Content 2: \gll Maa nain lawisiw \textbf{pina}. | \gls thing that1 rather heavy | \glt `The thing is rather heavy.

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: It turns out that in Mauwake the most prototypical nouns include names of concrete \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{non}}-human rather than human objects, when one would expect words referring to human beings to be nouns \textit{{par excellence}} (see \citealt[192]{Taylor1989}). Some human nouns may be used as post-modifiers in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}: from the cluster of properties denoted by the noun one has been picked out, and the noun is used like an adjective \REF{ex:3:x23}, \REF{ex:3:x24}. The adjectival use of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mua} `man' in \REF{ex:3:x23} is particularly interesting, because the adjectives \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{morena} `male' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{suwina} `female' are used for animals.
Content 1: \gll labuel(a) mua | \gls pawpaw man | \glt `male pawpaw'
Content 2: \gll donki takira | \gls donkey young.person | \glt `young donkey'
Content 3: \gll labuel(a) mua | \gls pawpaw man | \glt `male pawpaw'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: The less prototypical status of human nouns also shows in words like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{apura} `widow' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oosa} `widower' which may occur by themselves as heads of a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, but which are most typically used as post-modifiers of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{emeria} `woman' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mua} `man', respectively.\footnote{Other words in this group are \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{muupera}\textbf{ }`visitor, guest' and especially \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{weria}, which as a human noun only occurs in the combination \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{mua weria}, `uncle/ male cross cousin/ nephew'. The \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{mua weria'}s are responsible for burying a dead person and dispensing of his/her belongings (\sectref{sec:1.3.6}).} As age in human beings tends to be treated as a crucial determinant of \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{kind}}, even languages with large adjective classes often have special nouns for referring to old persons \citep[368]{Wierzbicka1986}. In Mauwake, adjectives that indicate age in humans are non-prototypical, more noun-like than most adjectives: both \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iperowa} `middle-aged' \REF{ex:3:x25} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{panewowa} `old' are used as the head of a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} besides the typical adjectival use.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Iperowa} opora wiar miim-i-yen. | \gls middle-aged talk 3.DAT hear-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We will listen to the talk of the middle-aged (men).'

Subsection: Nouns and adjectives: one or two word classes?\label{sec:3.2.2
Knowledge Point: With the rules given above it is fairly straightforward to distinguish the nouns and adjectives in Mauwake. But a small group remains that seems to have a membership in both classes. Originally, they are are nouns that are now employed as adjectives as well. The claim is based on the fact that the noun category is the more basic and universally recognized, whereas the existence of the adjective category is disputed in some languages; in Mauwake the noun class is clearly established, large, and more easily definable. Also, there are at least two nouns in Mauwake that currently seem to be in the process of becoming regular adjectives: the meaning of the phrase stays the same with the pre-modifying noun and the post-modifying adjective \REF{ex:3:x107}--\REF{ex:3:x1823}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{napum(a)} mua | \gls sickness man | \glt `a sick man'
Content 2: \gll opor(a) \textbf{wadola} | \gls talk lie/false | \glt `a lie'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake, proper names can be modified without difficulty, especially by the demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that', but also by adjectives. In a culture where there are several namesakes, and surnames are rarely used, modifiers are occasionally needed to distinguish between people \REF{ex:3:x27}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Adek} \textbf{panewowa} \textbf{nain} ma-i-yem. | \gls Adek old that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am talking about the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{old} Adek.'

Knowledge Point: But even proper names, that have a unique reference and do not need to be distinguished from any other referent can be modified \REF{ex:3:x106}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dabe} \textbf{fain} uuw-ow(a) mua=ke. | \gls Dabe this work-NMZ man=CF | \glt `Dabe here is a hard worker.'

Knowledge Point: The place name is also used when the inhabitants are referred to. When reference is made to an individual or a select group, the place name is used as a qualifier in the noun phrase \REF{ex:3:x421}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Amiten} mua oko ekap-o-k. | \gls Amiten man other come-PA-3s | \glt `A man from Amiten came.'

Knowledge Point: When the whole group is referred to, a plural pronoun is added to the place name \REF{ex:3:x422}, \REF{ex:3:x423}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{Moro=ke} uf-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM Moro=CF dance-PA-1/3p | \glt `We Moro people danced.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{(Wi)} \textbf{Lasen} \textbf{wia} nokar-e-k.{\upshape\footnotemark{}} | \gls 3p.UNM Lasen 3p.ACC ask-PA-3s | \glt `He asked the Lasen people'

Knowledge Point: The ``possessors'' are differentiated as first, second or third person but not as singular vs. plural. An unmarked \REF{ex:3:x1311} or a genitive pronoun \REF{ex:3:x28} and \REF{ex:3:x1312} may be used to either make this number distinction or to emphasize the kin relationship, when the relationship is used as a term of reference rather than as a term of address.
Content 1: \gll Kuuten \textbf{wiawi} iperowa, \textbf{yo} \textbf{auwa} kapa=ke. | \gls Kuuten 3s/p.father firstborn 1s.UNM 1s/p.father lastborn=CF | \glt `Kuuten's father was the firstborn, my father the lastborn.'\footnote{Both of these fathers could be called auwa `my/our father(s)' by the two men.}
Content 2: \gll Aakisa \textbf{yena} \textbf{auwa} kapa fain=ke yia uruf-i-ya. | \gls now 1s.GEN 1s/p.father lastborn this=CF 1p.ACC see-Np-PR.3s | \glt `Now this lastborn of my ``fathers'' watches over us.'
Content 3: \gll Sa, a \textbf{nena} \textbf{nie=ke}, \textbf{nena} \textbf{nepua=ke,} niawi=ke. | \gls INTJ INTJ 2s.GEN 2s/p.uncle=CF 2s.GEN 2s/p.brother-in-law 2s/p.father | \glt `(Don't you understand,) those are your uncle(-in-law), your brother-in-law and father(-in-law).'

Knowledge Point: The basic \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{stress pattern}} of noun phrases and compounds is similar, as one of the modifiers usually receives the phrase stress rather than the head noun \REF{ex:3:x29}, \REF{ex:3:x30}. Likewise, in compound nouns the modifying formative receives the main stress and the main formative is only weakly stressed \REF{ex:3:x31}, \REF{ex:3:x32}: the ``stress centre'' \citep[45]{Anderson1985a} is on another element than the head.
Content 1: \gll yo {\textprimstress}auwa aasa{\upshape\footnotemark[1]{}} | \gls 1s.UNM 1s/p.father canoe | \glt `my father's canoe'
Content 2: \gll aas(a) ge{\textprimstress}lemuta | \gls canoe small | \glt `a small canoe'
Content 3: \gll {\textprimstress}miiw(a)-aasa{\upshape\footnotemark[2]{}} | \gls land-canoe | \glt `vehicle, car'
Content 4: \gll enow(a) ge{\textprimstress}lemuta{\upshape\footnotemark[3]} | \gls food/meal small | \glt `feast'

Knowledge Point: \footnotetext[1]{In the examples \REF{ex:3:x29}-\REF{ex:3:x32} only the phrase stress is marked by ' preceding the stressed syllable.}
Content 1: \gll yo {\textprimstress}auwa aasa{\upshape\footnotemark[1]{}} | \gls 1s.UNM 1s/p.father canoe | \glt `my father's canoe'
Content 2: \gll enow(a) ge{\textprimstress}lemuta{\upshape\footnotemark[3]} | \gls food/meal small | \glt `feast'

Knowledge Point: Since there is hardly any \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{morphology}} in nouns and noun phrases, one would not expect to find much help here in distinguishing between compounds and phrases. But there is a minor factor that is relevant in this respect: a phrase containing a noun and an adjective can be pluralized by adjectival reduplication when the adjective allows reduplication \REF{ex:3:x33}, whereas a compound noun with a similar structure usually cannot \REF{ex:3:x34}, even if it is possible in some rare cases \REF{ex:3:x35}.
Content 1: \gll maa gelemuti-tik | \gls thing small-RDP | \glt `small things'
Content 2: \gll enow(a) gelemuti-tik | \gls food/meal small-RDP | \glt  `feasts'}
Content 3: \gll owow(a) mane-maneka | \gls village RDP-big | \glt `towns', `big villages'

Knowledge Point: Uninterruptibility is more typical of compounds than phrases. The noun phrase \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owow maneka} means `a big village', as a compound it means `a town/city'. As a phrase it is interruptible \REF{ex:3:x1768}, as a compound it is not.
Content 1: \gll owowa lawisiw maneka | \gls village rather big | \glt `a rather big village'

Knowledge Point: Likewise, as a compound \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kae sira} `ancestral custom' (literally: `grandfather's custom') is uninterruptible. When a genitive pronoun is inserted between the two parts, the meaning cannot be `ancestral custom' \REF{ex:3:x1860}:
Content 1: \gll kae ona sira | \gls grandfather 3s.GEN custom | \glt `grandfather's custom/habit'

Knowledge Point: On the basis of the semantic relations between the parts the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{n}+\textstyleAcronymallcaps{n} compounds can be divided into a few main groups. In the first one the relationship can be said to be characterized by \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{origin}} understood very widely, e.g. in the sense of place of origin \REF{ex:3:x37}, source \REF{ex:3:x1860}, or ``possession'' \REF{ex:3:x40}, \REF{ex:3:x41}.
Content 1: \gll piip(a) mera | \gls seaweed fish | \glt `rainbow fish'
Content 2: \gll kae ona sira | \gls grandfather 3s.GEN custom | \glt `grandfather's custom/habit'
Content 3: \gll emeria napuma | \gls woman sick(ness) | \glt `menstruation'
Content 4: \gll ibiamun sama | \gls dove ladder | \glt `cross-beam (in a roof)'

Knowledge Point: The compound noun \REF{ex:3:x40} has the stress centre on the first part, but the noun phrase \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{emeria napuma}, with the phrase stress on \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{napuma}, may be used to mean either `a sick woman', or more commonly `a (dead) woman's body', a euphemistic expression.
Content 1: \gll emeria napuma | \gls woman sick(ness) | \glt `menstruation'

Knowledge Point: The second relationship is a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{whole-\textsc{part}} relationship: the first element states the whole, the second its part \REF{ex:3:x42}, \REF{ex:3:x43}.
Content 1: \gll mokok(a) oposia | \gls eye meat | \glt `pupil (of the eye)'
Content 2: \gll ekek(a) muuna | \gls branch joint/projection | \glt `bud'

Knowledge Point: The third relationship is that of \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{container}}. As a compound \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muuk(a) sia} \REF{ex:3:x45} has the stress centre on the first word. In a noun phrase \REF{ex:3:x1770}, however, the phrase stress may also be on the second item if it is emphasized, and a third person singular genitive pronoun may be added between the parts as well. Example \REF{ex:3:x46} is an extended compound: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iinan aasa} is a ``sky canoe'', or vehicle, for flying in the sky, and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iinan aasa epa} a place for those vehicles.
Content 1: \gll muuk(a) sia | \gls son netbag | \glt `womb', `pouch (of a marsupial)'
Content 2: \gll muuk(a) sia | \gls son netbag | \glt `a son's/child's netbag (used for carrying the baby)'
Content 3: \gll iinan aasa epa | \gls sky canoe place | \glt `airstrip, airport'

Knowledge Point: As was mentioned above, the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{generic-specific}} relationship is different in that the modifying part follows rather than precedes the main part \REF{ex:3:x47}--\REF{ex:3:x49}. In this respect these compounds resemble phrases where the head noun has an adjective rather than a noun modifier. A particularly common word for the first part in these compounds is the maximally generic word in Mauwake, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maa} `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{thing'} \REF{ex:3:x49}.\footnote{The scope of meaning for \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{maa} is like that of `thing' in its widest sense in English.}
Content 1: \gll mera nepa | \gls fish bird | \glt `eagle ray'
Content 2: \gll maa pela | \gls thing leaf | \glt `(edible) greens'
Content 3: \gll maa pela | \gls thing leaf | \glt `(edible) greens'

Knowledge Point: There are two compound types with nominalized verbs. When the nominalized verb follows the other noun, it behaves like an adjective and receives the phrase stress \REF{ex:3:x1521}, \REF{ex:3:x1522}.
Content 1: \gll maa en-owa | \gls thing/food eat-NMZ | \glt `food'
Content 2: \gll emer(a) ik-owa | \gls sago roast-NMZ | \glt `bread, roasted sago'

Knowledge Point: A compound type where the nominalized verb precedes the other noun is more common than the one above. When the second part is a human noun, it usually has to be the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{agent}} of the verb \REF{ex:3:x52}, but when the noun is non-human, it is harder to find a common denominator for the semantic relationships between the parts in different compounds. Quite often the meaning centers around function, purpose or ``typical'' action, place, time, etc. \REF{ex:3:x53}, \REF{ex:3:x54}.
Content 1: \gll uuw-ow(a) mua | \gls work-NMZ man | \glt `worker'
Content 2: \gll in-ow(a) koora | \gls sleep-NMZ house | \glt `bedroom'
Content 3: \gll om-ow(a) eka | \gls cry-NMZ water | \glt `tear'

Knowledge Point: This compound type particularly easily allows compounds with more than two roots \REF{ex:3:x55}--\REF{ex:3:x60}:
Content 1: \gll ikemik(a) kaik-ow(a) mua | \gls wound tie-NMZ man | \glt `doctor'
Content 2: \gll ama urup-ow(a) (epa/kame) | \gls sun rise-NMZ place/side | \glt `east'

Knowledge Point: In the example \REF{ex:3:x61} the main noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{epa}/\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kame} can be dropped, and this happens in some other compounds as well:
Content 1: \gll epir(a) suruk-ow(a) (tetelka) | \gls plate wipe-NMZ finger | \glt `forefinger'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{coordinate}} compounds are different from the other compounds in that neither of the parts modifies the other. The meaning of the whole is derived from the combined meaning of the two terms. Also, there is no stress centre: both parts of the compound are stressed equally. The number of these compounds is small \REF{ex:3:x50}, \REF{ex:3:x51}.
Content 1: \gll emeria mua | \gls woman man | \glt `people'
Content 2: \gll muuka wiipa | \gls son daughter | \glt `children'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleAcronymallcaps{n}+\textstyleAcronymallcaps{adj} compounds are as hard to distinguish from phrases as some of the other groups mentioned above \REF{ex:3:x57}--\REF{ex:3:x59}. Again the uninterruptibility and lexicalized meaning are the main criteria. If the adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sepa} `black' is added between the two words in \REF{ex:3:x57}, the meaning changes into `a small black man'.
Content 1: \gll mua gelemuta | \gls man small | \glt `a little boy'
Content 2: \gll maa samora | \gls thing bad | \glt `mosquito'
Content 3: \gll mua gelemuta | \gls man small | \glt `a little boy'

Knowledge Point: The process of nominalizing verbs is a straightforward and fully productive process of adding the nominalizing suffix -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owa} to the verb stem. The nominalized verbs most commonly function as nouns \REF{ex:3:x62}--\REF{ex:3:x1231}, sometimes also as adjectives \REF{ex:3:x1247}.\footnote{In the Mauwake dictionary some of these nominalized forms have their own entry as if they were fully lexicalized as nouns, but this is to some extent a concession to other languages, where separate nouns may be required for the action nominals and more lexicalized deverbal nouns (for the distinction, see \citealt[193]{Ylikoski2003}). In Mauwake it is often difficult to establish which of the nominalizations are lexicalized.}
Content 1: \gll uf-\textbf{owa} | \gls dance-NMZ | \glt `(the act of) dancing', `(traditional) dance'
Content 2: \gll Fiirim-\textbf{owa}=pa opaimika aakun-e-mik. | \gls gather-NMZ=LOC talk talk-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the meeting we talked.'
Content 3: \gll Amina puk\textbf{-owa} eliw(a) marewa=ke. | \gls pot break-NMZ good none=CF | \glt `The pot is broken (and) not good' or: `The broken pot is not good.'

Knowledge Point: Action nominals function like any regular nouns in Mauwake. They can be, for example, a head \REF{ex:3:x64} or a qualifier \REF{ex:3:x65} in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, and a first \REF{ex:3:x66} or last element \REF{ex:3:x67} in a compound noun.
Content 1: \gll Siowa \textbf{alu-owa} miim-ap ekap-o-k. | \gls dog make.noise-NMZ hear-SS.SEQ come-PA-3s | \glt `He heard the dog's noise and came' or: `The dog heard noise and came.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Oram \textbf{niir-ow(a)} opora ma-e-m. | \gls just laugh-NMZ talk say-PA-1s | \glt `I just said it as a joke.'
Content 4: \gll Kaul \textbf{wafur-owa} mera \textbf{aaw-owa} eliw. | \gls hook throw-NMZ fish get-NMZ all.right | \glt `As for throwing a hook, it is a good way of catching fish.' (Lit: `Hook-throwing is all right for fish-catching.')

Knowledge Point: The following expressions form an interesting pair, as \REF{ex:3:x424} is a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} with a nominalized verb as its head, and \REF{ex:3:x425} is a compound noun with a nominalized verb as the first part.
Content 1: \gll mua aakun-\textbf{owa} | \gls man talk-NMZ | \glt `talk(ing) of man/people', `people's talk'
Content 2: \gll aakun-\textbf{ow}(\textbf{a}) mua | \gls talk-NMZ man | \glt `a talker', `a spokesman'

Knowledge Point: \citet[334--342]{ComrieEtAl2007} list various kinds of other nominalization possibilities,\footnote{\citet[500]{Givon1990} calls all of these lexical nominalizations, and Ylikoski calls them deverbal nouns (\citeyear[193]{Ylikoski2003}) to distinguish them from action nominals.} but in Mauwake the corresponding expressions are compound nouns or noun phrases consisting of the nominalized verb (or clause) plus another noun \REF{ex:3:x1232}, \REF{ex:3:x1233}, rather than simple nominalizations.
Content 1: \gll ikemika kaik-\textbf{ow(a)} mua | \gls wound tie-NMZ man | \glt `doctor, nurse'
Content 2: \gll maa eneka teek-\textbf{ow(a)} (maa){\upshape\footnotemark{}} | \gls thing tooth open-NMZ (thing) | \glt `can opener'

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of nouns to denote plurality is a very marginal process in Mauwake \REF{ex:3:x68}--\REF{ex:3:x426}, whereas reduplication of verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.4.1}) is much more frequent, and that of adjectives (\sectref{sec:3.3}) also more common. Usually the whole noun is reduplicated; final <a> is deleted in the reduplicated part of words that are longer than two syllables \REF{ex:3:x426}.
Content 1: \gll Dabuel \textbf{poka-poka} nain=iw biiris on-am-ik-e-mik. | \gls pawpaw RDP-trunk that1=INST bridge make-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept making the bridge with pawpaw trunks.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Owow-owowa} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls RDP-village go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went to several villages.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Owow-owowa} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls RDP-village go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went to several villages.'

Knowledge Point: A prototypical adjective functions as the head of an adjective phrase\footnote{Often the head is the sole constituent of the adjective phrase.} (\sectref{sec:4.2}) \REF{ex:3:x70}, \REF{ex:3:x71}, and may be modified by different intensity adverbs (\sectref{sec:3.9.2}), including the pre-modifier \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{lawisiw} `rather' \REF{ex:3:x72} and various post-modifiers \REF{ex:3:x73}.
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa \textbf{maala} war-e-k. | \gls tree long cut-PA-3s | \glt `He cut a tall tree.'
Content 2: \gll Waaya me \textbf{maneka}, muuka, \textbf{kia} \textbf{gelemuta}. | \gls pig not big son white small | \glt `The pig was not big, it was a piglet, white (and) small.'
Content 3: \gll Malol \textbf{lawisiw} \textbf{yoowa}. | \gls open.sea rather hard | \glt `(Fishing in the) open sea is rather hard.'
Content 4: \gll Koora nain \textbf{maneka} \textbf{wenup}. | \gls house that1 big very | \glt `That house is very big.'

Knowledge Point: The adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{awona} `old' refers to the age of things, not people; when used of people, the meaning is `previous' \REF{ex:3:x74}. Correspondingly, its antonym \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{enuma} `new' refers to age of things or recency in humans \REF{ex:3:x75}. The adjective referring to age in people, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{panewowa} `old'\footnote{\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{Panewowa} is derived from the verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{pan}- `grow old'.} does not have any adjective as an antonym; the noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{takira} `youth' is used instead. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Panewowa} `old' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iperowa} `middle-aged' do not only indicate age, but social status as well: it is the middle-aged men, rather than young or old, that have most power and make the important decisions in the community. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Iperowa} is also used for older siblings when the age of siblings is compared.
Content 1: \gll Emeria \textbf{panewowa} nain Kait emeria \textbf{awona}=ke. | \gls woman old that1 Kait woman old=CF | \glt `The old woman is Kait's old (=previous) wife.'
Content 2: \gll Ona mua \textbf{enuma} iiriw pani-e-k. | \gls 3s.GEN man new already grow.old-PA-3s | \glt `Her new husband is (already) old.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Value}} adjectives \REF{ex:3:x1760}, \REF{ex:3:x1759} are listed in \tabref{tab:3:valueadj}.
Content 1: \gll Inasin opaimika \textbf{eliwa} me yia maak-e-mik. | \gls spirit talk good not 1p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p | \glt `They did not speak good Tok Pisin (lit: spirit talk) to us.'
Content 2: \gll Iiriw sira nain \textbf{emi} maneka wiar ik-ua. | \gls earlier custom that1 forbidden big 3.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `Earlier that custom was completely forbidden to them.'

Knowledge Point: The list of \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{colour}} adjectives \REF{ex:3:x1753}--\REF{ex:3:x1755} is also very limited; only the first three terms in \tabref{tab:3:colouradj} are purely colour terms, all the others have their origin elsewhere:
Content 1: \gll Aalbok mia \textbf{sepa} \textbf{akena} kerer-e-k. | \gls black.cuckoo.shrike body black very become-PA-3s | \glt `The body of the black cuckoo-shrike became very black.'
Content 2: \gll Komora nain \textbf{kia} \textbf{ne} \textbf{maneka} wenup. | \gls cuscus that1 white ADD big very | \glt `That cuscus is/was white/light-coloured and very big.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x1754} the dimensional adjective for `small' may follow directly after the colour adjective, whereas the adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} `big' needs a connective between the two adjectives in \REF{ex:3:x1755}, because \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} is used as an intensifier when immediately following a colour term, and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kia maneka} would mean `completely white'.
Content 1: \gll Mia afif(a) \textbf{oka}, \textbf{oka} gelemuta. | \gls body hair red, red small | \glt `The feathers were red, (it was) red and small.'
Content 2: \gll Komora nain \textbf{kia} \textbf{ne} \textbf{maneka} wenup. | \gls cuscus that1 white ADD big very | \glt `That cuscus is/was white/light-coloured and very big.'

Knowledge Point: The darkness of a colour is expressed through the adjectives \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sepa} `black' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kia} `white' used as modifiers of the main colour adjective \REF{ex:3:x110}.
Content 1: \gll ifa \textbf{enuma} \textbf{lawisiw} \textbf{sepa} | \gls leaf new/green rather black | \glt `a dark green leaf'

Knowledge Point: Among the adjectives denoting \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{dimension}} \REF{ex:3:x1756}--\REF{ex:3:x77} there are a number of terms describing various kinds of thinness and thickness, as well as shortness (\tabref{tab:3:dimensionadj}).
Content 1: \gll Epa dabela=pa mia suuw-owa \textbf{gawela} suuw-ap mia fulil-i-nan. | \gls place cold=LOC body push-NMZ thin push-SS.SEQ body feel.cold-Np-FU.2s | \glt `When you wear thin clothes (mia suuwowa) in a cold place you will feel cold.'
Content 2: \gll Epa dabel-al-eya mia suuw-owa \textbf{kuruma} wu-e. | \gls place cold-INCH-2/3s.DS body push-NMZ thick put-IMP.2s | \glt `When it gets cold, put thick clothes on.'

Knowledge Point: The group of adjectives denoting \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{physical property}} \REF{ex:3:x78}, \REF{ex:3:x1758} is larger than any of the other groups and includes several antonym pairs. \tabref{tab:3:physprop} lists just a sample of them.
Content 1: \gll Iwera \textbf{ififa} ora-eya fiirim-i-mik. | \gls coconut dry descend-2/3s.DS gather-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `When the dry coconuts drop we gather them'.
Content 2: \gll {\dots}epia foma lawisiw \textbf{yoowa} ik-ua. | \gls fire(wood) ashes rather hot be-PA.3s | \glt `{\dots} the ashes were rather hot.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Human propensity}} adjectives (\tabref{tab:3:humanprop}) is the second largest group \REF{ex:3:x1757}, \REF{ex:3:x1418}.
Content 1: \gll Takira=ke keker op-ap \textbf{popor(a)} maneka ik-e-mik. | \gls boy=CF fear hold-SS.SEQ quiet big be-PA-1/3p | \glt `The boys were afraid and very quiet.'
Content 2: \gll Mua \textbf{lebuma} nain emeria me wi-i-mik. | \gls man lazy that1 woman not give.them-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We do not give wives to lazy men.'

Knowledge Point: Although Mauwake has a considerable inventory of adjectives for a Papuan language, in actual use they are rather infrequent.\footnote{Their frequency in the text material is about 1.5% of all the words.} Especially physical property and human propensity are frequently expressed through verbs which have been verbalized from adjectives. A true adjective is a more likely candidate to indicate a stable or essential quality of the head noun \REF{ex:3:x1418}, whereas the verbalized form is used for more temporary characteristics \REF{ex:3:x1419}-\REF{ex:3:x80}.
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{lebuma} nain emeria me wi-i-mik. | \gls man lazy that1 woman not give.them-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We do not give wives to lazy men.'
Content 2: \gll Sama=pa or-owa nain eliw, nain ikoka or-op or-op or-op \textbf{lebum(a)-ar-i-nan}, epasia akena. | \gls stairs=LOC descend-NMZ that1 well that1 later descend-SS.SEQ descend-SS.SEQ descend-SS.SEQ lazy-INCH-Np-FU.2s far very | \glt `Descending on the stairs is all right, but later when you have gone down and down and down you will be lazy/tired, (as) it is very far.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Yamunsi(a)-ar-iwkin} me wia nokar-e-m. | \gls stingy-INCH-2/3p.DS not 3p.ACC ask-PA-1s | \glt `They were (being) stingy, (so) I didn't ask them.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Comparison}} of adjectives is an area where there is very little differentiation in many Papuan languages, including Mauwake.\footnote{See \citet[134--135]{Roberts1987}; \citet[68]{Reesink1987}; \citet[63--64]{Hardin2002}. \citet[268]{Haiman1980} reports only three or four true adjectives for Hua, and does not mention comparison.} Intensifiers are used for this function, as well as the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nomak-} `overcome, surpass' \REF{ex:3:x81}.
Content 1: \gll Poka fain maala, nain \textbf{nomak-e-k}, ne oko nain \textbf{maala} \textbf{akena}. | \gls stilt this long that1 surpass-PA-3s ADD other that1 long very | \glt `This stilt is longer than that, and/but the other one is the longest (lit: very long).'

Knowledge Point: Two adjectives can also be compared by contrasting them \REF{ex:3:x441}:
Content 1: \gll Nomokow(a) kakawa fain \textbf{iiwa}, oko \textbf{maala} puuk-a-n. | \gls tree part this short other long cut-PA-2s | \glt `You cut this plank shorter than the other one.' (Lit: `You cut this plank short, the other long.')

Knowledge Point: Like nouns, adjectives can also be \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{reduplicated}} for plural \REF{ex:3:x85} (\sectref{sec:2.3.3.2}). Reduplication of adjectives is not very common, but it is more frequent than that of nouns.
Content 1: \gll Maa eneka kes \textbf{mane-maneka} oram iw-e-mik. | \gls thing tooth case RDP-big just give.him-PA-1/3p | \glt `They just gave him big cases of meat tins.'

Knowledge Point: The adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{gelemuta} `small' has several reduplicated forms: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{gelemuti-tik}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{,} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{gelemutu-mut} \REF{ex:3:x486}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{,} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{gele-gelemuti-tik}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{.}
Content 1: \gll Waaya \textbf{gelemutu-mut} pu-puuk-e. | \gls pig small-RDP RDP-cut-IMP.2s | \glt `Cut the pig into small pieces.'

Knowledge Point: Occasionally reduplication can be used for an intensifying function as well. The noun modified by the reduplicated adjective in \REF{ex:3:x485} is either singular or plural, in \REF{ex:3:x86} it is definitely singular.
Content 1: \gll Biiris eliwa me on-a-mik, \textbf{damo-damola}=ko. | \gls bridge good not make-PA-1/3p RDP-bad=NF | \glt `They didn't make a good bridge (but) very bad.' (or: `{\dots}good bridges but bad.')
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{New adjectives}} are derived from verbs with the nominalizing suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owa} \REF{ex:3:x1766}--\REF{ex:3:x1767} (\tabref{tab:3:derivedadj}). This is not a very productive process.
Content 1: \gll No mua samora, mua emin(a) \textbf{kekan}\textbf{-}\textbf{owa} nefa na-i-kuan. | \gls 2s.UNM man bad man occiput be.strong-NMZ 2s.ACC say-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They will call you a bad man, a pig-headed (lit: strong occiput) man.'
Content 2: \gll Makera \textbf{saawirin}\textbf{-}\textbf{owa} kaik-a-m. | \gls cane surround-NMZ tie-PA-1s | \glt `I tied the cane round.'

Knowledge Point: A quantifier is the only obligatory element in a quantifier phrase (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{qp,} \sectref{sec:4.3}). These are used as post-modifiers in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, where their position is between an adjective phrase (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{ap}) and demonstrative \REF{ex:3:x87}, or by themselves as a non-verbal predicate \REF{ex:3:x442}.
Content 1: \gll I koora maneka \textbf{kuisow} nain yiar aw-o-k. | \gls 1p.UNM house big one that1 1p.DAT burn-PA-3s | \glt `That one big house of ours burned.'
Content 2: \gll Mua iperowa \textbf{arow} \textbf{muutiw.} | \gls man middle-aged three only. | \glt `There are/were only three middle-aged men.' (Lit: `The middle-aged men (are/were) only three.')

Knowledge Point: The numerals, especially erup `two', may be added to a pronoun to quantify it: the numeral occurs following a reflexive (or occasionally unmarked) form of the pronoun, but the resulting phrase functions like an unmarked pronoun \REF{ex:3:x89}.
Content 1: \gll Ne \textbf{wiam} \textbf{erup} pun epa neeke or-o-mik. | \gls ADD 3p.REFL two too place there.CF descend-PA-1/3p | \glt `And the two of them too went down there.'

Knowledge Point: The traditional counting system in Mauwake is quinary, i.e. based on five\footnote{In New Guinea languages, there are counting systems based on two, five ten and twenty, as well as systems that use different body parts as tallies. All of these systems are present in the Madang area languages as well \citep{Lean1991}.} \REF{ex:3:x90} (\tabref{tab:3:numerals}), and counting is gestured using the fingers.\footnote{To count, the fingers are bent down one by one, starting from the little finger of the right hand, and proceeding towards the thumb, then on to the little finger of the other hand, and so on.}
Content 1: \gll Uura ama \textbf{ikur} \textbf{okai}(\textbf{wi})\textbf{=pa} \textbf{arow} naap in-e-mik. | \gls night sun five other.side=LOC three thus sleep-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the evening we slept at around eight o'clock.'

Knowledge Point: Nowadays the borrowed Tok Pisin numerals have largely superseded the vernacular numerals, especially those indicating numbers ten and above \REF{ex:3:x91}. There are no terms for `hundred', `thousand' or bigger numbers in the vernacular system.
Content 1: \gll Mokoma \textbf{ten} \textbf{arow} aaw-o-k. | \gls year ten three get-PA-3s | \glt `He became 30 years old.'

Knowledge Point: Numerals can be modified with the intensity adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kakeniw} `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{correctly, exactly}' \REF{ex:3:x443}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `really, truly' \REF{ex:3:x661}, or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muutiw} `only'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Erepam} \textbf{kaken}\textbf{=iw} mik-a-mik. | \gls four straight-ISOL spear-PA-1/3p | \glt `We speared exactly four.'
Content 2: \gll Mua \textbf{arow} \textbf{akena} epa nain iimar-e-mik. | \gls man three truly place that stand.up-PA-1/3p | \glt `Exactly three men stood at that place.'

Knowledge Point: When the number is somewhat uncertain and the disjunctive connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{or}' and/or the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} is used, either the smaller \REF{ex:3:x1416} or the bigger number \REF{ex:3:x92} may be mentioned first .
Content 1: \gll Waaya maneka wiowa \textbf{erup=i} \textbf{e} \textbf{arow} naap mik-iwkin um-i-ya. | \gls pig big spear two=QM or three thus hit-2/3p.DS die-Np-PR.3s | \glt `When a big pig is hit with two or three spears it dies.'
Content 2: \gll Mua wiam \textbf{ikur=i} \textbf{erepam} naap wia aaw-e-mik. | \gls man 3p.REFL five=QM four thus 3p.ACC get-PA-1/3p | \glt `They took/got those four or five men.'

Knowledge Point: Repetition \REF{ex:3:x93} or reduplication \REF{ex:3:x94} of the numerals indicates manner: `so and so many \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{at a time}}'. The reduplicated form of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kuisow} `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{one}', \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kui-kuisow}, has two meanings: `one by one' and `a few'.
Content 1: \gll Naap \textbf{kuisow} \textbf{kuisow} aaw-ikiw-e-mik. | \gls thus one one get-go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept getting them one at a time as they went.
Content 2: \gll Waaya merena \textbf{ere-erup} kaik-ap{\dots} | \gls pig leg RDP-two tie-SS.SEQ | \glt `I tied the pig's legs two and two together and {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: Mauwake has no separate words for \textstyleEmphasizedWords{ordinal} numbers. To indicate numerical order, various structures are employed. In many cases the cardinal numbers can be used \REF{ex:3:x96}, \REF{ex:3:x428}.
Content 1: \gll Mua arow epa nain iimar-e-mik, yos=ke \textbf{erepam}. | \gls man three place that1 stand-PA-1/3p 1s.FC=CF four | \glt `Three men were standing there, and I was the fourth.'
Content 2: \gll Koora tuun-e: \textbf{kuisow} \textbf{iki}(\textbf{w})\textbf{-}(\textbf{e})\textbf{p} \textbf{erepam}, ne \textbf{oko} nain ona koora. | \gls house count-IMP.2s one go-SS.SEQ four ADD other that1 3s.GEN house | \glt `His house is the fifth one' (Lit: `Count the houses: one to four, and the other/next is his house.')

Knowledge Point: In the case of time units, cardinal numbers are combined with the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `go' \REF{ex:3:x427}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Fofa} \textbf{okai}(\textbf{wi})\textbf{=pa} \textbf{arow} \textbf{ikiw-eya} ekap-i-non. | \gls day other.side=LOC three go-2/3s.DS come-Np-FU.3s | \glt `He will come on the ninth day.' (Lit: `When eight days have gone he will come').

Knowledge Point: Order can also be indicated through verbs like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{murar}- and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ook}- `follow' \REF{ex:3:x98}.
Content 1: \gll Wi Ulingan=ke nomak-e-mik. Ne i Moro \textbf{murar-e-mik}. | \gls 3p.UNM Ulingan=CF win-PA-1/3p ADD 1p.UNM Moro follow-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Ulingan people/team won. And (we from) Moro came second.'

Knowledge Point: Some non-numeral quantifiers can only be used with either count or mass nouns, others with both \REF{ex:3:x665}--\REF{ex:3:x99} are shown in \tabref{tab:3:quantcountnmass}.
Content 1: \gll Moma \textbf{senam} en-e-mik. | \gls taro too.much eat-PA-1/3p | \glt `We ate too much taro.'
Content 2: \gll Yagin eka=pa \textbf{unow=iya} nan yaki-e-mik. | \gls Yagin water=LOC many=COM there bathe-PA-1/3p | \glt `We all bathed there at Yagin together.'

Knowledge Point: The quantifiers in \tabref{tab:3:quantcount} are only used with \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{count}} nouns \REF{ex:3:x100}, \REF{ex:3:x667}. Papako is actually a plural indefinite `other'(\sectref{sec:3.7.2}), but it has a secondary function as a quantifier.
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{unowa}, emeria \textbf{papako} um-e-mik. | \gls man many woman some die-PA-1/3p | \glt `Many men and some women died.'
Content 2: \gll Ipia saana=pa iina \textbf{wenup}. | \gls rain season=LOC mosquito lots.of | \glt `In the rainy season there are lots of mosquitoes.'

Knowledge Point: Both \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wenup} \REF{ex:3:x809} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowa} can be intensified with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `very'; \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowa} may also be intensified with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wenup} `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{very}' \REF{ex:3:x101}; or with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} (lit: `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{big}') that gives it the meaning `\textstyleFreeTranslationChar{all}' \REF{ex:3:x102}.
Content 1: \gll Siipepe kokora maroka \textbf{wenup} \textbf{akena} ika-i-ya. | \gls Siipepe riverbed prawn lots.of very be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `There are lots of prawns in the Siipepe riverbed.'
Content 2: \gll Iinan aasa nepa saarik, \textbf{unow(a)} \textbf{akena/wenup}. | \gls sky canoe bird like many very | \glt `The planes were like birds, very many.'
Content 3: \gll Emeria \textbf{unow}(\textbf{a}) \textbf{maneka} sosora bee-beela a-e-mik. | \gls woman many big grass.skirt RDP-rotten tie-PA-1/3p | \glt `All the women put on rotten grass skirts.'

Knowledge Point: The quantifiers in \tabref{tab:3:quantmass} only occur with \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{mass}} nouns \REF{ex:3:x103}.
Content 1: \gll Eka yoowa=pa aaya \textbf{maneka/gelemuta} wu-e. | \gls water hot=LOC sugar big/little put-IMP.2s | \glt `Put a lot of/a little sugar in the tea.'

Knowledge Point: The following non-numeral quantifiers also function as degree/intensity adverbs, modifying a verb: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{lawiliw} \REF{ex:3:x511}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{senam} \REF{ex:3:x512}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iiwawun} \REF{ex:3:x513}, and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wenup} (\sectref{sec:3.9.2}).
Content 1: \gll Yos=ke \textbf{lawiliw} asip-i-yem. | \gls 1s=CF somewhat help-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am helping her somewhat/a little.'
Content 2: \gll Iperowa=ke \textbf{senam} kekan-e-mik. | \gls middle.aged=CF too.much be.strong-PA-1/3p | \glt `The middle-aged men were very strong (in their opinion).'
Content 3: \gll Waaya mik-amkun \textbf{iiwawun} um-o-k. | \gls pig spear-1s/p.DS altogether die-PA-3s | \glt `When I speared the pig it died completely.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Fractions}} are hard to express in Mauwake.\footnote{I have not seen fractions treated in grammars of Papuan languages, but know from discussions with colleagues that translating fractions is a major problem not only in Mauwake but in other Papuan languages as well.} The noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{enakiwa} `half' is sometimes also used for unspecified `part', and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{okaiwi} `one/other side' can be used for `half', when a clearly bounded entity is divided in half \REF{ex:3:x104}. I have not found other terms indicating fractions. Longer expressions are needed for them e.g. `divide into ten parts and take one part'.
Content 1: \gll Yabuela \textbf{okaiwi} enak-e. | \gls pawpaw one.side feed.me-IMP.2s | \glt `Give me half of the pawpaw to eat.'

Knowledge Point: It is a fairly common feature in languages that pronouns can either modify a noun in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} or replace a full \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, but cannot be the head of a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} taking modifiers \citep[e.g.][]{ HakulinenEtAl1979,Saari1985,Roberts1987}. In Mauwake the personal pronouns usually occur without modifiers, but they \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{can}} be modified by a demonstrative, provided there is no collocational clash between the demonstrative and the personal pronoun \REF{ex:3:x530}, \REF{ex:3:x531}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ni} \textbf{fain=ke} ekap-eka! | \gls 2s.UNM this=CF come-IMP.2p | \glt `You here (or: This group of you), come!'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{O} \textbf{nain} fan me ik-ua. | \gls 3s.UNM that1 here not be-PA.3s | \glt `He is not here.'

Knowledge Point: A pronoun copy after a full \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is hardly ever used in Mauwake for the subject. The rare example \REF{ex:3:x683} is from a hortatory text and may show rhetoric style:
Content 1: \gll Maneka fain wie \textbf{wi} eliw wiar op-i-kuan. | \gls big this uncle 3p.UNM well 3.DAT grab-NpFU.3p | \glt `These big ones the uncles may take from her.'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:3:x532} is not a case of a genuine pronoun copy, since the genitive pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wiena} adds the emphasizing meaning `themselves':
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} iperowa \textbf{wi-ena} ekap-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM middle.aged 3p-GEN come-PA-1/3p | \glt `The middle-aged (people) themselves came.'

Knowledge Point: The main use of the unmarked pronouns is as subjects. In narratives, only the person marking on the verb, rather than a pronoun, is used for an established, continuing subject/topic (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}). Especially third person unmarked pronouns marking the subject are quite rare in narrative texts \REF{ex:3:x533}, \REF{ex:3:x534}; first person pronouns are relatively much more common \REF{ex:3:x1803} \citep[79--80]{Jarvinen1991}.
Content 1: \gll Irak-owa=ke kerer-eya \textbf{wi} puk-omak-e-mik. | \gls fight-NMZ=CF appear-2/3p.DS 3p.UNM disperse-DISTR.PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `When the fight started they (many) dispersed.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{O} koora=pa naap ik-ok um-o-k. | \gls 3s.UNM house=LOC thus be-SS die-PA-3s | \glt `She was like that in the house and died.'
Content 3: \gll Bogia=pa nan wu-ap \textbf{i} kiiriw ekap-e-mik. | \gls Bogia=LOC there put-SS.SEQ 1p.UNM again come-PA-1/3p | \glt `We buried his body (lit: put it) there in Bogia and came (back) again.'

Knowledge Point: However, with imperative verbs the subject pronoun is common (\sectref{sec:3.5.11}, \sectref{sec:3.8.3.3.2}, \sectref{sec:7.3}). In this Mauwake provides an interesting exception to a very strong cross-linguistic tendency of dropping subject pronouns in imperative clauses (\citealt[80]{Givon1979}; \citealt[173--174]{SadockEtAl1985}). In this position the pronoun is usually unstressed \REF{ex:3:x1771}, \REF{ex:3:x1772}, unless it is contrasted with the subject of another clause coordinated with the imperative clause \REF{ex:3:x1780}.
Content 1: \gll ``\textbf{No} me baurar-e,'' naap maak-e-k. | \gls 2s.UNM not flee-IMP.2s thus tell-PA-3s | \glt ` ``Don't run away,'' he told her.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I} or-u. | \gls 1p.UNM descend-IMP.1d | \glt `Let's go down.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{No} feeke ik-e, yo Amerika wia akup-ikiw-i-yem. | \gls 2s.UNM here.CF be-IMP.2s 1s.UNM America 3p.ACC search-go-Np-PR.1s | \glt `You stay here, I will go searching the Americans.'

Knowledge Point: In an imperative clause the subject pronoun may also be used appositionally with a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} that has vocative function, to address a person \REF{ex:3:x627}.
Content 1: \gll Muuka, \textbf{no} aakisa emeria aaw-e! | \gls son 2s.UNM now woman take-IMP.2s | \glt `Son, take a wife now!' (i.e. Son, it is time you got married.)

Knowledge Point: There are some cases where the imperative clauses tend not to have a subject pronoun. When the clause has a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}) different from the subject \REF{ex:3:x1773}, and especially when the theme is another pronoun \REF{ex:3:x1774}, the imperative subject is blocked:
Content 1: \gll A, ifera\textsubscript{TH} feeke un-eka. | \gls ah salt.water here.CF draw/fetch-IMP.2p | \glt `Ah, fetch the salt water (right) here.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: When an imperative final clause is preceded by a different-subject medial clause, it does not have a subject pronoun either \REF{ex:3:x1775}:
Content 1: \gll Nefa war-iwkin naap ma-e. | \gls 2s.ACC shoot-2/3p.DS thus say-IMP.2s | \glt `When they shoot you, (then) say like that.'

Knowledge Point: A sentence-initial subject pronoun is quite common, when one or more same-subject medial clauses precede the imperative final clause and the scope of the imperative extends backwards over all the verbs \REF{ex:3:x628}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ni} ikiw-ep moma perek-eka! | \gls 2p.UNM go-SS.SEQ taro pull.out-IMP.2p | \glt `Go and pull out (i.e. harvest) taro!'

Knowledge Point: The only example in the text data of a subject pronoun repeated in the final clause is a case where the medial clause is subordinated with the topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} \REF{ex:3:x1776}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ni} uf-ep-na \textbf{ni} maadara me iirar-eka{\dots} | \gls 2p.UNM dance-SS.SEQ=TP 2s.UNM forehead.ornament not remove-IMP.2p | \glt `If/when you have danced, do not remove the forehead ornaments {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: When the level of politeness is reduced, the subject pronoun is less common. Some acceptable reasons for this are urgency \REF{ex:3:x1777}, or speech by an official that is expected to be brusque \REF{ex:3:x1778}. Example \REF{ex:3:x1779} is from a situation where the behaviour of some men has been offensive to their wives, and when the men return home and give a blunt command, their wives react to this additional insult by repeating the command and then stating their own grievance and their revenge.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll ...amia mua=ke ma-e-mik, ``Nainiw owowa ikiw-eka.'' | \gls bow man=CF say-PA-1/3p again village go-IMP.2p | \glt `{\dots}the policemen said, ``Go back to the village.'' '
Content 3: \gll Ekap-emi wia maak-e-mik, ``Maa iiw-eka.'' ```Maa iiw-eka.' Nis=ke sira oko on-ami...'' | \gls come-SS.SIM 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p food dish.out-IMP.2p food dish.out-IMP.2p 2p.FC=CF custom other do-SS.SIM | \glt `They came and told them, ``Dish out the food.'' `` `Dish out the food!' You acted offensively (lit: did another custom) and{\dots}'' '

Knowledge Point: There is some tendency to have a pronominal form to occupy the sentence-initial theme position (\sectref{sec:9.1}), especially when the pronoun refers to the main participant of the sentence. In some cases this results in the restructuring of the sentence so that a medial clause appears in the middle of the finite clause, instead of coming before it as would be more normal. In \REF{ex:3:x539} and \REF{ex:3:x540} the medial clauses are enclosed in square brackets.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} eka yoowa Magidar=ke kirip-ap yi-eya en-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM water hot Magidar=CF mix-SS.SEQ give.me-2/3s.DS eat-PA-1s | \glt `Magidar made tea and gave it to me, and I drank it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{No} um-eya or-o-n. | \gls 2s.UNM die-2/3s.DS descend-PA-2s | \glt `After he died you went down.'

Knowledge Point: Sentence-initial unmarked pronouns are also used when they are not subjects but rather mark a pronoun with other than subject function as the theme. The first person pronoun in particular is placed in the theme position very frequently \REF{ex:3:x535}, \REF{ex:3:x536}, the second person less so and the third person least of all.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} \textbf{efa} uruf-e! | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.ACC look-IMP.2s | \glt `Look at me!'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{yiena} mua opora \textbf{yia} asip-owa ekap-e-mik nain | \gls 1p.UNM 1p.GEN man talk 1p.ACC help-NMZ come-PA-1/3p that1 | \glt `Our men who have come to help us with the language {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: Especially in spoken language the unmarked pronouns may also be used, instead of genitive pronouns, to indicate possession. This is most commonly done with kinship terms \REF{ex:3:x537} and body parts \REF{ex:3:x538}, sometimes with other nouns\footnote{The following list covers most of them: \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{opora} `talk, speech', opaimika `mouth, speech', unuma `name', \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{koora} `house, home', manina `garden', siowa `dog' and \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{amina} `saucepan'.} too, referring to things closely associated with a person \REF{ex:3:x1804}. This usage can be seen as a kind of widening of the range of inalienably possessed nouns beyond the kinship terms (\sectref{sec:3.2.4}) to other nouns that would be inalienably possessed in related languages or some other languages in the area.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} auwa nan ik-ua. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s/p.father there be-PA.3s | \glt `My father is there.'
Content 2: \gll Ikoka Yaapan=ke \textbf{ni} umakuna nia puuk-i-kuan. | \gls Later Japan=CF 2p.UNM neck 2p.ACC cut-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Later the Japanese will cut your necks.'
Content 3: \gll Aria, \textbf{yo} opora muut nan-e-k. | \gls alright 1s.UNM talk only there-PA-3s | \glt `Alright, there is my talk.'

Knowledge Point: The third person plural unmarked pronoun is used to pluralize a noun phrase \REF{ex:3:x625}. It is also often used with a place name to refer to the inhabitants of the place collectively \REF{ex:3:x626}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} sawur nain=ke kuura puuk-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM spirit that1=CF fly change.into-PA-3s | \glt `Those spirits changed into flies.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wi} Lasen=ke kuum-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM Lasen=CF burn-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Lasen people burned it.' (Or: `It was the Lasen people who burned it.')

Knowledge Point: The neutral focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ko} attaches itself to the unmarked pronoun rather than the focal pronoun \REF{ex:3:x547}. I do not know the reason for this.\footnote{Kwan Poh San suggests as a possible reason that as the neutral focus does not give as strong an emphasis as the contrastive focus, it also attaches itself to a less emphasized form of the pronoun (p.c.).}
Content 1: \gll Waaya en-e-man nain \textbf{yo=ko} me uruf-a-m. | \gls pig eat-PA-2p that1 1s.UNM=NF not see-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't (get to even) see the pig that you ate.'

Knowledge Point: The focal pronouns are similar to the unmarked pronouns but have final \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-s: yos, nos, (w)os, (y)is, nis, wis.} These pronouns are never used for a neutral, non-focused subject. They are used in isolation and in lists \REF{ex:3:x541}, as well as with the topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} \REF{ex:3:x542}, the contrastive focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} \REF{ex:3:x543}, the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} \REF{ex:3:x544} and the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pun} `also' \REF{ex:3:x546}. With the limiter -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} \REF{ex:3:x545} the focal pronoun forms one of the two kinds of restrictive pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.7}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Nos}=na? | \gls 2s.FC=TP | \glt `What about you?'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Is}=ke me kuum-e-mik. | \gls 1p.FC=CF not burn-PA-1/3p | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{We}} didn't burn it.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Yos}=i? | \gls 1sg.FC=QM | \glt `I?'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Os} pun opora kuisow naap=iw ma-e-k. | \gls 3s.FC also talk one thus=LIM say-PA-3s | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{He}} also said the same thing.'
Content 6: \gll Anane \textbf{nos=iw} nefa maak-i-ya. | \gls always 2s.FC=LIM 2s.ACC tell-Np-PR.3s | \glt `He always talks to you only.'

Knowledge Point: When the subject of an imperative clause is contrasted with some other possible subject, the focal pronoun with contrastive focus clitic is employed \REF{ex:3:x629}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nos=ke} ikiw-e! | \gls 2s.FC=CF go-IMP.2s | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{You}} go (not someone else)!'

Knowledge Point: The accusative pronouns are used for encoding semantic patient \REF{ex:3:x548}, or recipient \REF{ex:3:x550}, both of which are syntactic objects (\sectref{sec:5.2}, \sectref{sec:5.3}).
Content 1: \gll Irakowa=pa \textbf{wia} war-e-mik. | \gls fight=LOC 3p.ACC kill-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the fight they killed them.'
Content 2: \gll Opora nain \textbf{efa} maak-e-k. | \gls talk that 1s.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt `He told me the story.'

Knowledge Point: The plural forms of the accusative pronouns are used together with the beneficiary form in the verb to disambiguate between the persons \REF{ex:3:x549} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.1}).
Content 1: \gll Aite maa \textbf{yia} p-or-om-a-k. | \gls mother food 1p.ACC BPX-descend-BEN-BNFY2.PA-3s | \glt `Mother brought food down for us.'

Knowledge Point: The only grammatical difference between the semantic roles of patient and beneficiary is shown in the verb, which can incorporate the benefactive suffix; and between patient and recipient there is no syntactic or morphological difference. The following hierarchy is followed: if there is a recipient not incorporated in the verb root,\footnote{Verbs like `give' and `feed' incorporate the recipient object in the verb root itself (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}).} the accusative pronoun refers to it \REF{ex:3:x550}, if there is no recipient but a plural beneficiary, the pronoun refers to the latter \REF{ex:3:x549}. And if there is neither recipient nor beneficiary, the accusative pronoun refers to the patient \REF{ex:3:x548}.\footnote{Cf. a rather similar hierarchy for the distributive suffix in verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.3.2})}
Content 1: \gll Opora nain \textbf{efa} maak-e-k. | \gls talk that 1s.ACC tell-PA-3s | \glt `He told me the story.'
Content 2: \gll Aite maa \textbf{yia} p-or-om-a-k. | \gls mother food 1p.ACC BPX-descend-BEN-BNFY2.PA-3s | \glt `Mother brought food down for us.'
Content 3: \gll Irakowa=pa \textbf{wia} war-e-mik. | \gls fight=LOC 3p.ACC kill-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the fight they killed them.'

Knowledge Point: Transitive verbs in Mauwake usually require an overt object, and verbs like `teach', `tell', `ask', which can take two objects, require the presence of at least the human object, whether patient \REF{ex:3:x552}, or recipient \REF{ex:3:x551}. In \REF{ex:3:x551} the pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} `3p.\textsc{acc}' may be definite or indefinite, hence the alternative free translations.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nefa} nokar-i-yem. | \gls 2s.ACC ask-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I'm asking you.'
Content 2: \gll Inglis \textbf{wia} ofakow-i-ya. | \gls English 3p.ACC teach-Np-PR.3s | \glt `(S)he teaches them English.' (Or: `(S)he teaches English.')
Content 3: \gll Inglis \textbf{wia} ofakow-i-ya. | \gls English 3p.ACC teach-Np-PR.3s | \glt `(S)he teaches them English.' (Or: `(S)he teaches English.')

Knowledge Point: In rare cases the human object may be left out \REF{ex:3:x553}:
Content 1: \gll Oram nokar-i-yem. | \gls just ask-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I'm just asking.' (Asking nobody in particular, or for no particular reason.)

Knowledge Point: Transitive verbs with [+human] objects require pronouns even when the object is mentioned as a noun or a noun phrase \REF{ex:3:x554}, \REF{ex:3:x555}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria \textbf{wia} amukar-e-k. | \gls woman 3p.ACC scold-PA-3s | \glt `He/she scolded the women.'
Content 2: \gll Emeria \textbf{nia} amukar-e-k. | \gls woman 2p.ACC scold-PA-3s | \glt `He/she scolded (you) women.'

Knowledge Point: Since the third person singular form is zero, all the cases with [+human] object noun without overt object pronoun by default indicate the third person singular \REF{ex:3:x556}. Because there is no number or case distinction in the nouns for the arguments of the verb, without this indication by pronouns it would often be ambiguous whether the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} was subject or object, or whether the object was singular or plural.
Content 1: \gll Emeria amukar-e-k. | \gls woman scold-PA-3s | \glt `He scolded his wife.'

Knowledge Point: In theory, the example \REF{ex:3:x556} could also mean `The woman scolded him/her' but in practice it does not. For when the subject is old/established information it is usually left out rather than marked by a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, and when it is new information, it is marked by the contrastive focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke}.\footnote{To have the meaning `He/she scolded a/the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{woman'}, the noun would be followed by the non-numeral quantifier \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{oko} `a, a certain' or the demonstrative \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{nain} `that'.}
Content 1: \gll Emeria amukar-e-k. | \gls woman scold-PA-3s | \glt `He scolded his wife.'

Knowledge Point: It must be clearly indicated whether the speaker or addressee is included in the object \REF{ex:3:x554}, \REF{ex:3:x555}, \REF{ex:3:x557}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria \textbf{wia} amukar-e-k. | \gls woman 3p.ACC scold-PA-3s | \glt `He/she scolded the women.'
Content 2: \gll Emeria \textbf{nia} amukar-e-k. | \gls woman 2p.ACC scold-PA-3s | \glt `He/she scolded (you) women.'
Content 3: \gll Mua \textbf{yia} aaw-i-kuan. | \gls man 1p.ACC take-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They will take (us) men.'

Knowledge Point: \citet[52--53]{Reesink1987} mentions that Usan has object prefixes, but a free pronoun can also occupy the object position in the third person singular. This is not the case in Mauwake; in \REF{ex:3:x1354} the free pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{o} is a re-activated topic (\sectref{sec:9.2.3}). The negative clause \REF{ex:3:x1353} shows that the position of the free pronoun is not directly preceding the verb. The clauses \REF{ex:3:x684}, \REF{ex:3:x560} have a similar structure with pronouns in non-third person marking a theme. When the pronoun is fronted as a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}), it is this unmarked pronoun that is used in the theme position.
Content 1: \gll Wi teeria papako \textbf{o} {\O} asip-a-mik... | \gls 3p.UNM group other 3s.UNM {\O} help-PA-1/3p | \glt `Another group helped him{\dots}' (Or: `He was helped by another group{\dots}')
Content 2: \gll \textbf{O} me {\O} aaw-e-mik. | \gls 3s.UNM not {\O} take-PA-1/3p | \glt `They did not take/choose him.' (Or: `He was not taken by them.')
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Yo} me \textbf{efa} aaw-e-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM not 1s.ACC take-PA-1/3p | \glt `They didn't take/choose me.' (Or: `I wasn't taken by them.')
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Yo} \textbf{efa} aaw-e-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.ACC take-PA-1/3p | \glt `They took/chose me.' (Or: `I was taken by them.')

Knowledge Point: There is one instance where the free third person singular pronoun does occur after the negator and immediately preceding the verb, just like accusative pronouns. This is when there is constituent negation (\sectref{sec:6.2.2}.) on the object, which then also receives clausal stress \REF{ex:3:x561} (\sectref{sec:2.1.3.1}, \ref{sec:9.3.3}). Here it is the negator that moves to precede the constituent it negates. The same process is also seen in \REF{ex:3:x562} where the negator has moved in front of the whole object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}.
Content 1: \gll Me \textbf{o} uruf-a-m. | \gls not 3s.UNM see-PA-1s | \glt `It wasn't him/her that I saw.'
Content 2: \gll Me \textbf{wi} owow mua \textbf{wia} arew-a-mik{\dots} | \gls not 3p.UNM village man 3p.ACC wait-PA-1/3p | \glt `It wasn't the village people that we waited for{\dots}'

Knowledge Point: There are situations where it is impossible to determine whether the unmarked third person singular pronoun is marking a topic/subject or an object fronted as a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}). The context would be needed to disambiguate between the slightly different meanings of \REF{ex:3:x563}, which do not come out well in the English translation. The first meaning is likely if the context mentions some other people seeing something; the second meaning is more probable elsewhere.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{O} me uruf-a-k. | \gls 3s.UNM not see-PA-3s | \glt `(S)he didn't see him/her/it.' (Or: `(S)he didn't see him/her.')

Knowledge Point: There are a few verbs in Mauwake that cross-reference the patient or recipient object in the verb root (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.2.4}). These verbs do not allow a separate accusative pronoun for the function that is already expressed by the verb root \REF{ex:3:x564}, \REF{ex:3:x1526}, but it is possible to have a separate accusative pronoun for the patient when the verb cross-references the recipient rather than the patient \REF{ex:3:x565}.
Content 1: \gll Ipia=ke \textbf{yiar-eya} ekap-e-mik. | \gls rain=CF hit.us-2/3s.DS come-PA-1/3p | \glt `The rain hit us and we/they came.'
Content 2: \gll Yomar, no uurika \textbf{yook}\textbf{-}\textbf{ap} urup-e. | \gls friend 2s.UNM tomorrow follow.me-SS.SEQ ascend-IMP.2s | \glt `Friend, follow me up tomorrow.'
Content 3: \gll Iiriw \textbf{nefa} \textbf{wi-e-mik}. | \gls already 2s.ACC give.them-PA-1/3p | \glt `We have already given you to them.'

Knowledge Point: When other verbs require both a [+human] recipient and a [+human] patient, it is encoded as a clause chain \REF{ex:3:x566}. The first verb then takes one of the arguments and the second the other.
Content 1: \gll Uuriw \textbf{wia} aaw-ep \textbf{nia} p-ekap-om-i-yen. | \gls morning 3p.ACC take-SS.SEQ 2p.ACC BPX-come-BEN-Np-FU.1p | \glt `In the morning we will bring them (people) to you.'

Knowledge Point: The genitive pronoun is used when the possessor is coreferential with the subject,\footnote{It does not have to be used when the possessive relationship is clear from the context; see (196) above.} and its meaning is often close to English `own' \REF{ex:3:x1805}--\REF{ex:3:x567}.
Content 1: \gll Sawur emeria nain=ke \textbf{ona} soma mua nain ifakim-o-k. | \gls spirit woman that1=CF 3s.GEN lover man that1 kill-PA-3s | \glt `The spirit woman killed her (own) lover.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Niena} unuma maifa feeke siisim-eka. | \gls 2p.GEN name paper here.CF write-IMP.2p | \glt `Write your names on the paper here/ on this paper.'

Knowledge Point: In descriptive or equative clauses genitive pronouns can modify both the subject \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:3:x568} and the non-verbal predicate \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:3:x569}, whereas the dative pronouns can modify neither.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yena} koora maneka wenup. | \gls 1s.GEN house big very | \glt `My house is very big.'
Content 2: \gll Mua fain me \textbf{nena} niawi akena=ke. | \gls man this not 2s.GEN 2s/p.father true=CF | \glt `This man is not your real father.'

Knowledge Point: It is possible for a genitive pronoun to co-occur with a dative pronoun to modify the same noun which is not coreferential with the subject \REF{ex:3:x570}. (See \sectref{sec:3.5.5} for a further discussion on the differences between genitive and dative possessives.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yena} koora \textbf{efar} aw-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN house 1s.DAT burn-PA-3s | \glt `My house burned.'

Knowledge Point: Even when the possessor is expressed by a noun or \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, the genitive pronoun is sometimes explicit, \textstyleParagraphContinuationChar{occurring either between the possessor and the possessed} \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:3:x573} or, quite frequently, preceding both \REF{ex:3:x574}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wiena} mia kia maa=iw on-a-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN skin white thing=INST do-PA-1/3p | \glt `They did it with the Europeans' things.'

Knowledge Point: The reason for this addition of a pronoun may be the lack of case marking in nouns, which makes the processing of possessed \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s more difficult when there are modifying nouns in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}. But it is also quite common for a possessive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} to occur without a genitive pronoun \REF{ex:3:x575}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The third person singular possessive pronoun provides an exception to the rule that the personal pronouns are only used for the humans. However, the cases where \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ona} `3s.\textsc{gen}' refers to a non-human possessor are few and seem to require the connotation `own' \REF{ex:3:x1808}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In those instances where the possessed \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} in the predicative position lacks an overt head noun, three different strategies may be used. I have not observed any difference in meaning. The genitive pronoun may occur by itself, without a head noun, which can either be deleted completely \REF{ex:3:x576} or substituted by \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' \REF{ex:3:x577}, or the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} can be expressed by a possessive phrase \REF{ex:3:x578} (\sectref{sec:4.4}). In all these instances the head noun occurs earlier in the same sentence, or occasionally in the preceding sentence.
Content 1: \gll Ikiwosa \textbf{yena}, wapena \textbf{yena}{\dots} | \gls head 1s.GEN, hand 1s.GEN | \glt `The head is mine (to eat), the hands are mine{\dots}'
Content 2: \gll Fikera pun \textbf{wiena} nain=ke. | \gls kunai.grass too 3p.GEN that1=CF | \glt `The kunai grass is theirs, too.'
Content 3: \gll Maa nain \textbf{yo/yena} \textbf{efarik}. | \gls thing that1 1s.UNM/1s.GEN 1s.DAT | \glt `That thing is mine.'

Knowledge Point: Like possessives in many other languages, the genitive pronoun may function as the subject of a nominalized clause \REF{ex:3:x571} (\sectref{sec:5.7}). The unmarked pronoun is used in the same position too; I have not found any difference in their use.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yiena} owow maneka ikiw-owa nain ma-i-yem. | \gls 1p.GEN village big go-NMZ that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I'm telling about our going to town.'

Knowledge Point: As ordinary main clause subjects the genitive pronouns are more emphatic than the unmarked pronouns.\footnote{Usan \citep[55]{Reesink1987}, Siroi \citep[20]{Wells1979} and Maia \citep[73]{Hardin2002} also use the same pronoun forms for possessive and emphatic pronouns, whereas Waskia \citep{RossEtAl1978} does not.} The pronunciation reflects the emphasis too: these pronouns receive a stronger stress than the unmarked pronouns when used as a subject \REF{ex:3:x572}.
Content 1: \gll Aasa enuma \textbf{yena} me suuw-i-yem. | \gls canoe new 1s.GEN not push-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I don't take a new canoe down myself.'

Knowledge Point: The following example \REF{ex:3:x686} has two identical genitive pronouns, the first one functioning as an emphatic subject pronoun and the second one as a possessive pronoun:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yiena} iisow, \textbf{yiena} garanga muutiw aaw-ep uup-ep en-e-mik. | \gls 1p.GEN 1p.ISOL 1p.GEN family only take-SS.SEQ cook-SS.SEQ eat-PA-1/3p | \glt `Only our family by ourselves (lit: we ourselves we only, our family only) took it, cooked and ate it.'

Knowledge Point: A genitive pronoun is also possible as the subject of a relative clause, when the subject is emphatic \REF{ex:3:x1809}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: When the limiting clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} `only' is added to the genitive pronoun, the result is a restrictive pronoun \REF{ex:3:x604} (\sectref{sec:3.5.7}).
Content 1: \gll Yo me nia maak-i-nen, \textbf{nien=iw} ma-eka. | \gls 1s.UNM not 2p.ACC tell-Np-FU.1s 2p.GEN=LIM say-IMP.2p | \glt `I will not tell you (what to do); discuss it on your own (among yourselves/as a group).'

Knowledge Point: The semantic function of a dative pronoun is related to the verb of the clause. With motion verbs it has goal function \REF{ex:3:x1781}, \REF{ex:3:x580}:
Content 1: \gll Pok-ap ika-iwkin mua \textbf{wiar} ekap-e-mik. | \gls sit-SS.SEQ be-2/3p.DS man 3.DAT come-PA-1/3p | \glt `They were sitting and (their) husbands came to them.'
Content 2: \gll Mia kokas-owa=ke \textbf{wiar} kerer-e-k. | \gls skin itch-NMZ=CF 3.DAT appear/arrive-PA-3s | \glt `Her skin started to itch.' (Lit: `Skin itch appeared to her.)'

Knowledge Point: With stative verbs the pronouns indicate location \REF{ex:3:x1782}, \REF{ex:3:x1783}. (Note that the free translation needs to use a comitative expression, since English does not have a [+human] locative expression equivalent to the Mauwake dative.)
Content 1: \gll Feeke \textbf{wiar} ik-ok kiiriw mua wiar urup-e. | \gls here.CF 3.DAT be-SS again man 3.DAT ascend-IMP.2s | \glt `Having been here with him, go (back) to your husband again.'
Content 2: \gll Wi sawur nain ir-ami fan \textbf{yiar} pok-a-mik.{\upshape\footnotemark} | \gls 3p.UNM spirit that1 go.east-SS.SIM here 1p.DAT sit-PA-1/3p | \glt `The spirits, going eastward, sat here with us.'

Knowledge Point: With verbs that indicate receiving something (take, get, buy, etc.) the dative has the semantic function of source \REF{ex:3:x579}--\REF{ex:3:x1785}.
Content 1: \gll Yo emeria Lasen=pa \textbf{wiar} aaw-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM woman Lasen=LOC 3.DAT get/take-PA-1s | \glt `I got (my) wife from (the) Lasen (people).'
Content 2: \gll Mua oko=ke waaya nain mik-ap \textbf{nefar} aaw-i-non. | \gls man other=CF pig that1 spear-SS.SEQ 2s.DAT get/take-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Another man will spear the pig and take it from you.'
