Knowledge Point: The ``source'' can also be more abstract. I have observed this use only with verbs indicating hearing or speaking \REF{ex:3:x1786}.
Content 1: \gll Naap \textbf{wiar} miim-a-m. | \gls thus 3.DAT hear-PA-1s | \glt `I heard thus about him/her/them.'

Knowledge Point: A locative phrase referring to a village or village area including its inhabitants is commonly used with a dative pronoun as well \REF{ex:3:x586}, otherwise it refers to just the location rather than the inhabitants. The pronoun may be used with towns or bigger areas as well, but the bigger the location, the less probable the pronoun is. In \REF{ex:3:x587} the people ran away to the people in the Bogia area, whereas in \REF{ex:3:x1802} the people of Bogia town may not have been involved in the burial at all. In \REF{ex:3:x1800} the speaker was going to the Highlands, not in order to meet the Highlanders but to work in a location there.
Content 1: \gll Lasen \textbf{wiar} ek-a-mik. | \gls Lasen 3.DAT go.east-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went to Lasen (=to the people of Lasen village).'
Content 2: \gll Baurar-ep Bogia kame \textbf{wiar} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls run.away-SS.SEQ Bogia area 3.DAT go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They ran away to the Bogia area.'
Content 3: \gll P-ikiw-ep Bogia=pa nan wu-a-mik. | \gls BPX-go-SS.SEQ Bogia=LOC there put-PA-1/3p | \glt `We/They took it (a body) and buried it in Bogia.'
Content 4: \gll Uuriw iinan aasa aaw-ep Epa Dabela urup-e-mik. | \gls morning sky canoe take-SS.SEQ place cold ascend-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the morning we took an airplane and went up to the Highlands.'

Knowledge Point: Cross-linguistically a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{possessive predicate}} construction, a `have' construction, has often been derived from a locative or a goal/dative construction, plus a verb of existence \citep[50--61]{Heine1997}. In the possessive predicates in Mauwake the dative pronoun precedes the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-} `be' \REF{ex:3:x1788} The possessive predicate construction is discussed in more detail in \sectref{sec:5.5.2}. .
Content 1: \gll I sira naap \textbf{yiar} ik-ua. | \gls 1p.UNM custom thus 1p.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `We have a custom like that.' (Lit: `A custom like that is to us.)'

Knowledge Point: The same dative pronoun has also grammaticalized as a possessive attribute in a noun phrase , but here it is the semantic function of [+\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{human}}] \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{source}} that is behind the development. Conceptually the structures `\textstyleAcronymallcaps{X} took \textstyleAcronymallcaps{Y} from me' and `\textstyleAcronymallcaps{X} took my \textstyleAcronymallcaps{Y}' are very close. In \REF{ex:3:x581} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{efar} can mean either `my' or `from me'.
Content 1: \gll Nos=ke anane urema \textbf{efar} ikum-ar-i-n. | \gls 2s.FC=CF always bandicoot 1s.DAT illicitly-INCH-Np-PR.2s | \glt `You always steal bandicoots from me / my bandicoots.'

Knowledge Point: That it is difficult to distinguish between the roles of possessor and source is not unusual.\footnote{Sometimes it is hard to distinguish even between a possessor and a goal. In the following sentence efar could also mean `to my place/house', with the head noun deleted: Yo me efar ekap-e! [1s.\textsc{unm} not 1s.\textsc{dat} come-\textsc{imp}.2s] `Don't come to me!' } \citet[133]{Heine1997} mentions that early in the grammaticalization process ``these expressions can simultaneously be interpreted with reference to either their non-posses\-sive source or to possession.'' In \REF{ex:3:x1861} and \REF{ex:3:x1862} the source interpretation is not possible. The example \REF{ex:3:x1862} describes a situation in future when the speaker will already be dead and his son is made to lose his inheritance.
Content 1: \gll A, yo aamun nan \textbf{efar} ik-ua. | \gls ah 1s.UNM younger.sibling there 1s.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `Ah, there is my younger brother.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found

Knowledge Point: This grammaticalization probably started with the verbs denoting taking and getting, but it is only a short step from there to interpreting the dative as a possessor with other verbs as well, especially as it is likely that the dative pronoun was already earlier established in the possessive predicate structure \REF{ex:3:x1789}--\REF{ex:3:x1795}.
Content 1: \gll Owowa \textbf{yiar} kuuf-owa ekap-e-mik. | \gls village 1p.DAT see-NMZ come-PA-1/3p | \glt `They came to see our village.'
Content 2: \gll No me emeria \textbf{nefar} maak-i-mik. | \gls 2s.UNM not woman 2s.DAT tell-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We are not telling/talking to your wife.'

Knowledge Point: Although the possessive is often associated with malefactive overtones as in \REF{ex:3:x1787} and \REF{ex:3:x1792}, this is not part of its meaning \REF{ex:3:x1791}, \REF{ex:3:x1790}.
Content 1: \gll Buburia koora \textbf{wiar} aw-o-k. | \gls bald house 3.DAT burn-PA-3s | \glt `The bald man's house burned (on him).'
Content 2: \gll Irak-emi amina \textbf{wiar} fo-fook-omak-e-mik. | \gls fight-SS.SIM pot 3.DAT RDP-split-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `They\textsubscript{i} fought and split their\textsubscript{j} pots.'
Content 3: \gll Auwa afura \textbf{wiar} akim-ap=ko uruf-e. | \gls 1s/p.father lime 3.DAT try-SS.SEQ=NF see-IMP.2s | \glt `Try father's lime and see (what it is like).'
Content 4: \gll Ikiwosa \textbf{wiar} pepekim-ep kaik-a-m. | \gls head 3.DAT measure-SS.SEQ tie-PA-1s | \glt `I measured her head and tied it (a cane).'

Knowledge Point: The dative possessive construction is particularly useful for disambiguating between the subject and the possessor, if both of them are in third person. The following two pairs of examples, \REF{ex:3:x1797}--\REF{ex:3:x1796} and \REF{ex:3:x1798}--\REF{ex:3:x1799} show this clearly. The corresponding English sentences are ambiguous, whereas the Mauwake sentences are not:
Content 1: \gll Yena eremena=ke \textbf{ona} siowa aruf-eya kepura ku-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN nephew=CF 3s.GEN dog hit-2/3s.DS leg break-PA-3s | \glt `My nephew\textsubscript{i} hit his\textsubscript{i} dog and its leg broke.'
Content 2: \gll Yena eremena=ke siowa \textbf{wiar} aruf-eya kepura ku-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN nephew=CF dog 3.DAT hit-2/3s.DS leg break-PA-3s | \glt `My nephew\textsubscript{i} hit his/her\textsubscript{j} dog and its leg broke.'
Content 3: \gll Wis=ke wiawi maak-e-mik. | \gls 3p.FC=CF 3s/p.father tell-PA-1/3p | \glt `(It was) they\textsubscript{i} (who) told their\textsubscript{i} father.'
Content 4: \gll Wis=ke wiawi \textbf{wiar} maak-e-mik. | \gls 3p.FC=CF 3s/p.father 3.DAT tell-PA-1/3p | \glt `(It was) they\textsubscript{i} (who) told their\textsubscript{j} father.'

Knowledge Point: Currently the dative possessive has to be used when the possessor is non-coreferential with the subject or recipient of the clause \REF{ex:3:x588}--\REF{ex:3:x1794}.
Content 1: \gll Marasin nain=ke kema \textbf{wiar} iw-a-k. | \gls medicine that1=CF liver 3.DAT go-PA-3s | \glt `The medicine went into his liver.'
Content 2: \gll Pina ... \textbf{nefar} kaken-ami welaw-i-kuan. | \gls guilt ... 2s.DAT straighten-SS.SIM finish-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They will straighten your(sg) {\dots} guilt and finish it.'

Knowledge Point: In the possessor function the dative pronoun does not co-occur with the accusative pronoun in the same clause \REF{ex:3:x584}. In the rare occasion where there would be rivalry for the position immediately preceding the verb, the accusative is chosen \REF{ex:3:x583} rather than the dative \REF{ex:3:x1928}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Yena muuka erup \textbf{wia} aaw-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN son two 3p.ACC take-PA-3s | \glt `He took my two sons.'
Content 3: \gll ?Yena muuka erup \textbf{efar} aaw-o-k. | \gls 1s.GEN son two 3.DAT take-PA-3s | \glt  %

Knowledge Point: But if the dative pronoun has the semantic role of goal, it may co-occur with an accusative pronoun; in this case it precedes the accusative pronoun \REF{ex:3:x1576}.
Content 1: \gll O \textbf{wiar} \textbf{nefa} sesek-i-yem. | \gls 3s.UNM 3.DAT 2s.ACC send-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am sending you to him.'

Knowledge Point: The use of the genitive possessive pronoun is much less restricted. Besides being employed where the possessor is coreferential with the subject \REF{ex:3:x589} or recipient \REF{ex:3:x590}, it can also be used when a possessed \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is the subject or non-verbal predicate of a descriptive or equative clause \REF{ex:3:x591}.
Content 1: \gll Eema=ke \textbf{ona} kolos Garamin iw-o-k. | \gls Eema=CF 3s.GEN dress Garamin give.him/her-PA-3s | \glt `Eema\textsubscript{i} gave her\textsubscript{i} dress to Garamin.'
Content 2: \gll Eema=ke Garamin \textbf{ona} kolos iw-o-k. | \gls Eema=CF Garamin 3s.GEN dress give.him/her-PA-3s | \glt `Eema\textsubscript{i} gave Garamin\textsubscript{j} her\textsubscript{j} dress.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Yena} koora maneka wenup. | \gls 1s.GEN house big very | \glt `My house is very big.'

Knowledge Point: The genitive or unmarked pronoun may co-occur together with the dative pronoun referring to the same person, thus emphasizing the possessive function of the dative \REF{ex:3:x1863}, \REF{ex:3:x593}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} emeria \textbf{efar} uruf-a-man=i e wia? | \gls 1s.UNM woman 1s.DAT see-PA-2p=QM or no | \glt `Have you seen my wife or not?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ona} koora=pa \textbf{wiar} wu-a-mik. | \gls 3s.GEN house=LOC 3.DAT put-PA-1/3p | \glt `They put it in his (own) house.'

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:3:x594} shows how the genitive and dative possessives, in \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{different}} person forms, can modify the same noun. The dative pronoun can here be interpreted either as a possessive `your (wives)' or as a source `(wives) from you'.
Content 1: \gll Emeria ikoka Yaapan \textbf{wiena} \textbf{niar} aaw-i-kuan. | \gls woman later Japanese 3p.GEN 2p.DAT take-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Later the Japanese will take your wives as their own.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x1318}, where there are several possessive \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s, the two genitive pronouns both refer to the man who is identified in the preceding text. In the second clause the possessor is a modifier in the subject \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, so it has to be in the genitive. The subject in the third clause is the lover's spirit, and because only one dative possessive is possible in one clause, here it is naturally assigned to the man's wife whose things were thrown around, and the man is referred to by a genitive possessive. In this case the genitive possessive also underlines the fact that one of the women was the man's own wife. The clauses are separated by brackets.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Dative pronouns also have a longer form, with the suffix -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{efarik}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nefarik} etc. The pronoun is a contracted form of the `have' construction, with just the root left of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be', which has been suffixed to the pronoun. In natural text the frequency of these pronouns is extremely low. They have to be used when the dative pronoun is clause final \REF{ex:3:x597}-\REF{ex:3:x598}, as the regular dative pronoun only occurs pre-verbally. The longer form is often accompanied by either the genitive pronoun \REF{ex:3:x597} or the unmarked pronoun \REF{ex:3:x596}, which suggests that it is more emphasized than the simple dative.
Content 1: \gll Miiw ara gelemuta nain \textbf{yiena} \textbf{yiarik}. | \gls land piece small that1 1p.GEN 1p.DAT | \glt `That small piece of ground is ours.'
Content 2: \gll Wiawi=ke amap-or-o-k=i, weke \textbf{wiarik}? | \gls 3s/p.father=CF BPX-descend-PA-3s=QM 3s/p.grandfather 3.DAT | \glt `Did her father take her down to her grandfather?'
Content 3: \gll Miiw ara gelemuta nain \textbf{yiena} \textbf{yiarik}. | \gls land piece small that1 1p.GEN 1p.DAT | \glt `That small piece of ground is ours.'
Content 4: \gll Yo mesa up-owa fain \textbf{ni} \textbf{niarik} aaw-ep isak-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM winged.bean plant-NMZ this 2p.UNM 2p.DAT get-SS.SEQ plant-PA-1s | \glt `I got these winged bean seeds from you and planted them.'

Knowledge Point: The long dative with a ``receive'' type verb in the following example can be traced back to niar ikeya `you had it, and{\dots}' \REF{ex:3:x596}.
Content 1: \gll Yo mesa up-owa fain \textbf{ni} \textbf{niarik} aaw-ep isak-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM winged.bean plant-NMZ this 2p.UNM 2p.DAT get-SS.SEQ plant-PA-1s | \glt `I got these winged bean seeds from you and planted them.'

Knowledge Point: When an isolative pronoun functions as a subject, which is \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}), it is alone \REF{ex:3:x599}; but more commonly it is both theme and subject, and is preceded by the unmarked pronoun also showing the case marking overtly \REF{ex:3:x600}.
Content 1: \gll Manina \textbf{waisow} mauw-ap neeke wu-a-k. | \gls garden 3s.ISOL work-SS.SEQ there.CF put-PA-3s | \glt `He made his garden alone/by himself and left it there.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{No} \textbf{naisow} or-op kaul wafur-e. | \gls 2s.UNM 2s.ISOL descend-SS.SEQ hook throw-IMP.2s | \glt `Go down alone/by yourself and do fishing (lit: throw the hook).'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:3:x601} has an accusative pronoun to show the case and an initial unmarked pronoun yo `I' to mark the object as theme.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} \textbf{yaisow} me \textbf{efa} keraw-a-k. | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.ISOL not 1s.ACC bite-PA-3s | \glt `It didn't bite only me.' (Or: `It wasn't only me that it bit.')

Knowledge Point: When the isolative pronoun is preceded by the genitive/emphatic pronoun it is intensified \REF{ex:3:x1813}.
Content 1: \gll Aakisa mua iperowa nain \textbf{ona} \textbf{waisow} soor owowa=pa ika-i-ya. | \gls now man middle.aged that1 3s.GEN 3s.ISOL jungle village=LOC be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `Now that middle-aged man is staying all by himself in a jungle hamlet.'

Knowledge Point: In the plural the meaning is `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{only}} we/you/they (as a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{group}})' \REF{ex:3:x602}.
Content 1: \gll Wi feeke ika-uk, \textbf{i} \textbf{iisow} ikiw-i-yen. | \gls 3p.UNM here.CF be-IMP.3p 1p.UNM 1p.ISOL go-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Let them stay here, only we will go.'

Knowledge Point: When the first syllable of a plural isolative pronoun is reduplicated, the pronoun refers to \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{individuals}} in the group \REF{ex:3:x603}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ii-iisow} pok-ap opora siisim-ep weeser-eya unow=iya aakun-e-mik. | \gls RDP-1p.ISOL sit-SS.SEQ talk write-SS.SEQ finish-2/3s.DS many=COM talk-PA-1/3p | \glt `We sat and wrote separately, and then talked together.'

Knowledge Point: Although the pronouns in \REF{ex:3:x602} and \REF{ex:3:x603} sound rather similar, there is a stress difference between them. In the former, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iisow} gets stronger stress than the unmarked pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i}, in the latter the first syllable of the reduplicated word is stressed.
Content 1: \gll Wi feeke ika-uk, \textbf{i} \textbf{iisow} ikiw-i-yen. | \gls 3p.UNM here.CF be-IMP.3p 1p.UNM 1p.ISOL go-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Let them stay here, only we will go.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ii-iisow} pok-ap opora siisim-ep weeser-eya unow=iya aakun-e-mik. | \gls RDP-1p.ISOL sit-SS.SEQ talk write-SS.SEQ finish-2/3s.DS many=COM talk-PA-1/3p | \glt `We sat and wrote separately, and then talked together.'

Knowledge Point: The restrictive pronouns are formed by adding the limiting clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} `only' either to a genitive pronoun or to a focal pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.12.6}). When it is added to a genitive pronoun it means `on one's own' \REF{ex:3:x605}--\REF{ex:3:x607}.
Content 1: \gll No \textbf{nena=iw} ma-i-n=i? | \gls 2s.UNM 2s.GEN=LIM say-Np-PR.2s=QM | \glt `Do you say it on your own?' (i.e. `Did you think of it yourself?')
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yien=iw} ikiw-ik-ua. | \gls 1p.GEN=LIM go-be-PA.3s | \glt `Let's go on our own (as a group, or one by one).'

Knowledge Point: When the limiting clitic is added to the focal form of the free pronoun it adds the meaning of exclusiveness to the pronoun \REF{ex:3:x608}, \REF{ex:3:x609}.
Content 1: \gll Anane \textbf{nos=iw} nefa maak-i-ya. | \gls always 2s.FC=LIM 2s.ACC tell-Np-PR.3s | \glt `He always talks to you only.'
Content 2: \gll Wi anane \textbf{is=iw} yiam=iya irak-i-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM always 1p.FC=LIM 1p.REFL=COM fight-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They always fight with us only.'

Knowledge Point: The singular forms are used as reflexives only \REF{ex:3:x610}, \REF{ex:3:x1864}, the plural forms both as reflexives \REF{ex:3:x611}, \REF{ex:3:x1865} and as reciprocals \REF{ex:3:x612}, \REF{ex:3:x1866}.
Content 1: \gll Naap on-ap \textbf{yame} amukar-e-m. | \gls thus do-SS.SEQ 1s.REFL scold-PA-1s | \glt `Having done so I scolded myself (i.e. was angry at myself).'
Content 2: \gll Iinan akena ikiw-ep \textbf{wame} pipilim-ep aakun-em-ika-i-non. | \gls on.top very go-SS.SEQ 3s.REFL hide-SS.SEQ speak-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.3s | \glt `It (= a bird) will go very high up and hide itself and keep making its calls.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Niam} tuun-ap teeria erup wu-eka. | \gls 2p.REFL count-SS.SEQ group two put-IMP.2p | \glt `Count yourselves and form two groups.'
Content 4: \gll Nainiw sande uura \textbf{yiam} fiirim-e-mik. | \gls again Sunday night 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt `Again on Sunday night we gathered.'
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Wiam} fook-ap irak-e-mik. | \gls 3p.REFL split-SS.SEQ fight-PA-1/3p | \glt `They split from each other and fought.'

Knowledge Point: In many contexts only the reflexive or the reciprocal interpretation is natural. But a potential ambiguity in some contexts is resolved by adding a genitive pronoun to mark the reflexive \REF{ex:3:x614} and an unmarked or restrictive pronoun to mark the reciprocal pronoun \REF{ex:3:x613}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Niena} \textbf{niam} kookal-eka. | \gls 2p.GEN 2p.REFL like-IMP.2p | \glt `Like/love yourselves.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ni/nieniw} \textbf{niam} kookal-eka. | \gls 2p.UNM/2p.LIM 2p.REFL like-IMP.2p | \glt `Like/love each other.'

Knowledge Point: The reflexives are not very frequent in Mauwake, because they seem to be fairly strongly connected with [+Control]. If one hurts oneself unintentionally, the cause(r) or instrument occupies the subject position instead of the person hurt. Thus, \REF{ex:3:x617} is a semantically appropriate equivalent for the English clause `I cut myself with a knife':
Content 1: \gll Fura=ke efa puuk-a-k. | \gls knife=CF 1s.ACC cut-PA-3s | \glt `A knife cut me.'

Knowledge Point: But a reflexive pronoun is used especially in expressions involving \textstyleParagraphChari{body parts} when one does something to oneself, and the instrument is not known or mentioned \REF{ex:3:x618}. In corresponding expressions English often uses possessive rather than reflexive pronouns.
Content 1: \gll Merena \textbf{yame} puuk-a-m. | \gls leg 1s.REFL cut-PA-1s | \glt `I cut my leg.' (Or: `I cut myself in the leg.')

Knowledge Point: The plural forms of the reflexive pronouns have another, quite different use: when they are followed by numerals, especially by `two' or `three', they function as dual/trial etc. forms for the personal pronouns. They are considered to be in the nominative case when not followed by other pronoun forms \REF{ex:3:x615}. Other cases need to be shown by appropriate additional pronouns \REF{ex:3:x616}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yiam} \textbf{arow} nain miim-ap soran-e-mik. | \gls 1p.REFL three that1 hear-SS.SEQ be.startled-PA-1/3p | \glt `The three of us heard that and were startled.'
Content 2: Not found

Subsection: Primary and secondary reference of personal pronouns
Knowledge Point: In Mauwake both the first and second person singular forms as well as the third person plural marking on verbs can be used for non-specific, or generic, reference. They occur particularly in explanations of customs or general principles, and in examples. The sentences are usually in the future tense and therefore hypothetical. In these texts the second person singular pronoun and the third person verb marking can alternate quite freely. Example \REF{ex:3:x621} is from a text describing the adoption process in general, and example \REF{ex:3:x622} was said to a person who does not even have a spirit name to call upon, nor does know how to spear pigs. Here the pronouns have acquired a non-deictic role: their correct interpretation does not depend on the non-linguistic context \citep[260]{AndersonEtAl1985}%Keenan
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yo} muuka kookal-ep \textbf{yena} samapora wia maak-i-nen. | \gls 1s.UNM son like-SS.SEQ 1s.GEN clan 3p.ACC tell-Np-FU.1s | \glt `When I like to have a son/child I will tell my clan.' (Or: `When one wants a child he will tell his own clan.')
Content 2: \gll \textbf{No} waaya mik-ap inasina unuma me unuf-i-nan=na mua oko=ke nainiw mik-ap \textbf{nefar} aaw-i-non. | \gls 2s.UNM pig spear-SS.SEQ spirit name not call-Np-FU.2s=TP man other=CF again spear-SS.SEQ 2s.DAT take-Np-FU.3s | \glt `If you spear a pig and don't call your spirit name, another man will spear it again and take it from you.' (Or: `If one spears a pig{\dots}')

Subsection: Primary and secondary reference of personal pronouns
Knowledge Point: When a maximally generic object is needed for a transitive verb, or when there is no overt object available, the first person plural accusative form is used \REF{ex:3:x623}, \REF{ex:3:x624}.
Content 1: \gll Ifa nain=ke \textbf{yia} keraw-i-ya. | \gls snake that1=CF 1p.ACC bite-Np-PR.3s | \glt `That snake bites.'
Content 2: \gll Marasin fain \textbf{yia} girin-i-ya. | \gls medicine this 1p.ACC smart-Np-PR.3s | \glt `This medicine smarts.'

Subsection: Use of personal pronouns in text\label{sec:3.5.11
Knowledge Point: A pronoun may be used for the second mention of a newly established topic (\sectref{sec:9.2.2}). In particular when an important participant has been introduced by a proper name, in the next sentence (s)he can be referred to by a personal pronoun \REF{ex:3:x1867}.
Content 1: \gll Eema=ke waisow amis-ar-e-k. \textbf{Os=ke} uuriw urup-emi{\dots} | \gls Eema=CF 3s.ISOL knowledge-INCH-PA-3s 3s.FC=CF morning rise-SS.SIM | \glt `Only Eema knew. She got up in the morning and {\dots}'

Subsection: Use of personal pronouns in text\label{sec:3.5.11
Knowledge Point: When a participant has been established as the topic, (s)he is referred to with a verb suffix only, or with a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} if a better identification is needed. A pronoun is used mainly when the topic is re-activated after being inactive for a while (\sectref{sec:9.2.3}). The example \REF{ex:3:x1922} is from a text where a couple goes down to the husband's village and then returns to the wife's village. The wife's relatives, inactive as a topic for the span of five clauses, are re-assigned the topic status with the pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wi} `they'.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Use of personal pronouns in text\label{sec:3.5.11
Knowledge Point: In commands (\sectref{sec:7.3}) the subject pronouns are more frequent than in statements.\footnote{As many as 39% of commands in the text material have a pronoun subject, as against 6% in statements.} The pronoun here is not a vocative; that would be separated from the rest of the clause by a pause, whereas a subject is not. The example \REF{ex:3:x685} is a fairly typical command in Mauwake. This is an unusual feature cross-linguistically, as languages tend to drop the subject pronoun in imperative clauses \citep[80]{Givon1979}.\footnote{The relatively high frequency of subject pronouns in imperative clauses may not be a peculiarity of Mauwake only. The grammatical descriptions of Papuan languages often state that the subject pronoun is optional in these clauses, but give no information as to their actual frequency. Personal communication with other field linguists working on Papuan languages gives reason to suggest that an overt personal pronoun with the imperative may be more common than is generally assumed.}
Content 1: \gll Ni ikiw-eka! | \gls 2p go-IMP.2p | \glt `Go (2p)!'

Knowledge Point: The numeral modifiers are positioned between an adjective and a demonstrative in a \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:3:x631}, but never between two adjectives \REF{ex:3:x632}.
Content 1: \gll koora maneka arow \textbf{nain} | \gls house big three that1 | \glt `those three big houses'
Content 2: \gll siowa sepa gelemuta erup | \gls dog black small two | \glt `two small black dogs'

Knowledge Point: There is a clear distinction in Mauwake between human and non-human reference, which shows in the choice of a pronoun vs. a demonstrative. A third person pronoun is not used for non-humans, whereas demonstratives in isolation\footnote{Demonstratives are common as modifiers of \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s referring to humans.} are normally only used for non-humans. The only exception in my data is example \REF{ex:3:x633}; \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' would not be acceptable even here.
Content 1: \gll No{\upshape\footnotemark} \textbf{fain} me nena niawi akena=ke. | \gls 2s.UNM this not 2s.GEN 2s/p.father true=CF | \glt `This is not your true father.'

Knowledge Point: Apart from the proximal demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fain} `this', the other demonstratives are not mutually exclusive. The distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' is the least restricted of the three, and it is extremely frequent, whereas both \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eefin} `this/that' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eenin} `that' are very rarely used. In \REF{ex:3:x1749} the distances of the two mountains fit the specifications for \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eefin} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eenin} , and more than one distal demonstrative is needed for contrastive purposes:
Content 1: \gll Ema \textbf{eenin} fikera=ke aw-o-k, aria \textbf{eefin} fikera=ke me aw-o-k. | \gls mountain that3 kunai.grass=CF burn-PA-3s, alright that2 kunai.grass=CF not burn-PA-3s | \glt `The kunai grass on that mountain (far away, invisible) burned, but the grass on this/that one (somewhat closer) did not burn.'

Knowledge Point: There is no number distinction in demonstratives. When they modify a [+human] noun, plurality is shown in the person/number marking of the verb and optionally by an additional personal pronoun \REF{ex:3:x635}.
Content 1: \gll (\textbf{Wi}) takira \textbf{fain=ke} niir-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM boy this=CF play-PA-1/3p | \glt `It was these boys that played.'

Knowledge Point: With [-human] nouns, a quantifier in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} may be used \REF{ex:3:x636}, or distributive suffix on the verb \REF{ex:3:x637} to indicate plurality, or the number may be left unspecified \REF{ex:3:x638}.
Content 1: \gll Mera \textbf{arow} \textbf{nain} aaw-e-m. | \gls fish three that1 get-PA-1s | \glt `I caught those three fish.'
Content 2: \gll Mera \textbf{nain} aaw-\textbf{omak}-e-m. | \gls fish that1 get-DISTR.PL-PA-1s | \glt `I caught those (many) fish.'
Content 3: \gll Amina \textbf{fain} p-ekap-e-mik. | \gls pot this BPX-come-PA-1/3p | \glt `We brought this pot / these pots.'

Knowledge Point: Mauwake follows the typical pattern: the neutral distal demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' is anaphoric: it only refers to the text preceding it, as in \REF{ex:3:x639}, where the example sentence comes after the description of fishing with a fish trap. The proximal \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fain} `this' is cataphoric, referring to the text following it \REF{ex:3:x640}. The other two demonstratives, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eefin} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eenin}, are not used for text-internal reference at all.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Nain} soo era=ke. | \gls that1 fish.trap way=CF | \glt `That is the way (to catch fish) with a fish trap.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Still another function for the demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' is that of a nominalizer of otherwise finite verbal clauses (\sectref{sec:5.7.2}). A nominalized clause of this type may be a relative clause \REF{ex:3:x687} (\sectref{sec:8.3.1}), a complement clause \REF{ex:3:x689} (\sectref{sec:8.3.2}) or a temporal subordinate clause \REF{ex:3:x688} (\sectref{sec:8.3.3.1}).\footnote{All these clauses have a function that is consistent with the core meaning of `givenness' \citep{Haiman1978} or presupposition \citep{Reesink1987}.}
Content 1: \gll Merena ifa keraw-a-k \textbf{nain}\textsubscript{RC} puuk-a-mik. | \gls leg snake bite-PA-3s that1 cut-PA-1/3p | \glt `They cut the leg that the snake had bitten.'
Content 2: \gll Mukuna kerer-e-k \textbf{nain}\textsubscript{CC} i me paayar-e-mik. | \gls fire start-PA-3s that1 1p.UNM not understand-PA-1/3p | \glt `We didn't know that a fire had started.'
Content 3: \gll Goron-ep ora-i-ya \textbf{nain}, maa muutitik iiwawun lalat-i-ya. | \gls fall-SS.SEQ descend-Np-PR.3s that1 thing all.kinds altogether sweep-Np-3s | \glt `When it goes down, it sweeps everything with it.'

Knowledge Point: The same demonstrative is also used as a strong adversative `but' \REF{ex:3:x690} (\sectref{sec:8.1.3}). In that function it is placed clause-initially rather than clause-finally.
Content 1: \gll Wiawi eliw naak-e-k, \textbf{nain} me ikiw-o-k. | \gls 3s/p.father all.right say-PA-3s that1 not go-PA-3s | \glt `He said yes (lit: all right) to his father, but didn't go.'

Knowledge Point: The difference in the usage between the neutral and focused member of each pair is that the first is \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{only}} used with realis-type verb forms, i.e. past \REF{ex:3:x463}, \REF{ex:3:x1213} and present tense \REF{ex:3:x1214}, whereas the second one is \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{mainly}} used with future \REF{ex:3:x464}, imperative \REF{ex:3:x465}, and counterfactual \REF{ex:3:x466}, i.e. irrealis-type forms. Yet Mauwake does not differentiate between realis and irrealis in verbs, and a possible explanation here is that only locative adverbs that are in focus can make it into a future, imperative or counterfactual clause, whereas past or present clauses are less restrictive and use either focal or non-focal form.
Content 1: \gll Owowa=pa \textbf{fan} ik-emkun aasa maneka ekap-o-k. | \gls village=LOC here be-1s/p.DS canoe big come-PA-3s | \glt `As I was here in the village the big ship came.'
Content 2: \gll Yo fura belemuta \textbf{eefan} piipu-a-m. | \gls 1s.UNM knife small there2 leave-PA-1s | \glt `I left the small knife (somewhere) here.'
Content 3: \gll Wi aakisa fain manina \textbf{eenan} on-i-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM now this garden there3 make-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `Nowadays they make the garden(s) there (far away).'
Content 4: \gll Eliw \textbf{feeke} soop-i-yen. | \gls well here.CF bury-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We can bury him \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{here}}.'
Content 5: \gll Ni koora epa \textbf{eefeke} ku-eka. | \gls 2p.UNM house place there2.CF build-IMP.2p | \glt `Build a/the house \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{over here}} in this place.'
Content 6: \gll \textbf{Neeke} ik-ek-a-k=na iwer(a) ififa=ke ifakim-ek-a-k. | \gls there1.CF be-CNTF-PA-3s=TP coconut dry=CF kill-CNTF-PA-3s | \glt `If he had been \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{there}} a (falling) dry coconut would have killed him.'

Knowledge Point: In the following examples \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{neeke} and\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ feeke} are used with past \REF{ex:3:x1146} -- \REF{ex:3:x1200} or present tense verbs \REF{ex:3:x1572} and indicate a temporary rather than permanent location, but this is probably secondary, or related, to the adverbs being focal: there is less need to focus on a permanent location than on a temporary one. Note that in these clauses it is possible to have two constituents with contrastive focus marking \REF{ex:3:x1146}, \REF{ex:3:x1572}.
Content 1: \gll Miiw(a) aasa fa-ow(a) mua=ke \textbf{neeke} wia aaw-o-k. | \gls land canoe drive-NMZ man=CF there1.CF 3p.ACC take-PA-3s | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{There}} the truck driver picked them up.'
Content 2: \gll Nainiw mukuna mamaiya \textbf{neeke} ikiw-o-k. | \gls again fire close there1.CF go-PA-3s | \glt `Again he went \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{there}} close to the fire.'
Content 3: \gll Fa, Yaapan=ke \textbf{feeke} ik-e-mik! | \gls INTJ Japan=CF here.CF be-PA-1/3p | \glt `Damn, the Japanese are \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{here}}!'
Content 4: \gll Miiw(a) aasa fa-ow(a) mua=ke \textbf{neeke} wia aaw-o-k. | \gls land canoe drive-NMZ man=CF there1.CF 3p.ACC take-PA-3s | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{There}} the truck driver picked them up.'
Content 5: \gll Fa, Yaapan=ke \textbf{feeke} ik-e-mik! | \gls INTJ Japan=CF here.CF be-PA-1/3p | \glt `Damn, the Japanese are \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{here}}!'

Knowledge Point: The four deictic manner adverbs are based on the deictic roots, but their derivation is less regular than that of either the demonstratives or the deictic locatives, due to the restriction that a geminate vowel is only possible in an initial syllable (\tabref{tab:3:deicticmanneradv}). Again, the proximate \REF{ex:3:x701} and especially the distal-1 adverbs \REF{ex:3:x702} are common but the others are very infrequent.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Naap} maak-iwkin \textbf{naap} ik-ua. | \gls thus tell-2/3.DS thus be-PA.3s | \glt `They told him like that, and he was like that.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x1857} there is a long temporal distance between the hearing and the recounting of the story, which is apparently reflected in the choice of the adverbial.
Content 1: \gll Iiriw auwa-ke ma-iwkin \textbf{eefenap} miim-a-m. | \gls earlier 1s/p.father=CF say-2/3p.DS thus2 hear-PA-1s | \glt `The fathers spoke (about this) long ago and I heard it like that.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x1858} there is both some temporal and a considerable locative distance between the original time and place of the quote and that of the rest of the example:
Content 1: \gll ``Mua nain opora=pa wu-ami ifakim-e,'' \textbf{eenap} efa maak-e-mik. | \gls man that1 talk=LOC put-SS.SIM kill-IMP.2s thus3 1s.ACC tell-PA-1/3p | \glt ` ``Accuse (lit: put to talk) that man and kill him,'' they told me like that.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Kaan} `where' is formed by the question root \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ka}- and the same locative affix -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{an} that is used in the deictic locative adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fan} `here' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan} `there' \REF{ex:3:x1852} (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}). The derivation with the contrastive focus marker \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-(e)}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} is more frequently used than the non-focused form \REF{ex:3:x1854}, possibly because the the other two most frequent question words, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mauwa} `what' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naarewe} `who', so often take the contrastive focus clitic.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain unuf-ami ma-i-kuan, {\textquotedbl}Mua nain \textbf{kaan} ik-ua?{\textquotedbl} | \gls man that1 call-SS.SIM say-Np-FU.3p man that1 where be-PA.3s | \glt `They call the man's name and say, ``Where is that man?'' '
Content 2: \gll Oo Sarak, no \textbf{kaan=eke} ik-ok kerer-e-n a? | \gls INTJ Sarak 2s.UNM where=CF be-SS arrive-PA-2s INTJ | \glt `Oh Sarak, where have you been (lit: where were you and arrived)?'

Knowledge Point: The question words, except for \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenion} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap-i}, occupy the same syntactic position and clausal function \REF{ex:3:x520}, \REF{ex:3:x521} as the corresponding non-interrogative element would have \REF{ex:3:x647}, \REF{ex:3:x648}.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain \textbf{iikamin} ekap-o-k? | \gls man that when come-PA-3s | \glt `When did that/the man come?'
Content 2: \gll Maa \textbf{mauwa} en-e-n? | \gls thing/food what eat-PA-2s | \glt `What did you eat?'
Content 3: \gll Mua nain \textbf{unan} ekap-o-k. | \gls man that yesterday come-PA-3s | \glt `That/the man came yesterday.'
Content 4: \gll Maa \textbf{oposia} en-e-m. | \gls thing/food meat eat-PA-1s | \glt `I ate meat.'

Knowledge Point: Neither number nor case is marked on the interrogative words themselves. If either marking is required, it is done through personal pronouns, but for [+human] \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s only \REF{ex:3:x522}, \REF{ex:3:x523}.
Content 1: \gll Mua \textbf{naarew} \textbf{wia} uruf-a-n? | \gls man who 3p.ACC see-PA-2s | \glt `Whom (pl) did you see?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Naarew} \textbf{wiar} aaw-o-k? | \gls who 3.DAT get-PA-3s | \glt `Who did he get it from?'

Knowledge Point: When an interrogative word is used as a subject, the contrastive focus marker \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} is added. This is natural since it is the question word that is the focal element in questions \REF{ex:3:x524}--\REF{ex:3:x526}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mauwa}\textbf{=ke} nefa aruf-a-k? | \gls what=CF 2s.ACC hit-PA-3s | \glt `What hit you?'
Content 2: \gll Masin \textbf{kaanin=ke} samor-ar-e-k? | \gls engine which.of.2=CF bad-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `Which engine (of the two) broke?'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naarew}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{(e)} `who?' is only used for [+human] referents. When the contrastive focus maker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} is suffixed to the question word, the last syllable is normally deleted. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Mauwa} `what', on the other hand, is used almost solely for [-human] nouns. The only natural expression with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mauwa} referring to humans that I have encountered is of the type \REF{ex:3:x649}. When a person's name is inquired, either \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naarewe} \REF{ex:3:x1855} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenap} \REF{ex:3:x650} is used rather than \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mauwa}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria nain no/nena \textbf{mauwa=ke}? | \gls woman that 1s.UNM/1s.GEN what=CF | \glt `What (relation) of yours is that woman?'
Content 2: \gll O unuma \textbf{naare=ke}? | \gls 3s.UNM name who=CF | \glt `What is his/her name?'
Content 3: \gll O unuma \textbf{kamenap}? | \gls 3s.UNM name what.like? | \glt `What is his/her name?'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Kaanin} `which of two?' is specified for number \REF{ex:3:x526}, but \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kain} `which?' is not \REF{ex:3:x691}.
Content 1: \gll Masin \textbf{kaanin=ke} samor-ar-e-k? | \gls engine which.of.2=CF bad-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `Which engine (of the two) broke?'
Content 2: \gll No \textbf{kain} kookal-i-n? | \gls 2s.UNM which like-Np-PR.2s | \glt `Which one (of two or many) do you like?'

Knowledge Point: The locative question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kaan}(\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eke}) `where' is often used as a phrase by itself \REF{ex:3:x1852}, \REF{ex:3:x1854}. but it is also employed as a modifier of a locative noun phrase rather than \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kain} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kaanin} \REF{ex:3:x1853}.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain unuf-ami ma-i-kuan, {\textquotedbl}Mua nain \textbf{kaan} ik-ua?{\textquotedbl} | \gls man that1 call-SS.SIM say-Np-FU.3p man that1 where be-PA.3s | \glt `They call the man's name and say, ``Where is that man?'' '
Content 2: \gll Oo Sarak, no \textbf{kaan=eke} ik-ok kerer-e-n a? | \gls INTJ Sarak 2s.UNM where=CF be-SS arrive-PA-2s INTJ | \glt `Oh Sarak, where have you been (lit: where were you and arrived)?'
Content 3: \gll Epa ara \textbf{kaan=eke}\textsubscript{NP} ikiw-e-mik? | \gls place section where=CF go-PA-1/3p | \glt `What/which area did they go to?'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Kamenap} is a question word both for manner `how?' \REF{ex:3:x527} and for adjectives `what {\dots} like?'. In the latter sense it usually modifies the noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sira} `custom, kind' \REF{ex:3:x528}.
Content 1: \gll No \textbf{kamenap} ik-o-n? | \gls 2s.UNM how be-PA-2s | \glt `How are/were you?'
Content 2: \gll O koora \textbf{sira} \textbf{kamenap} ku-a-k? | \gls 3s.UNM house custom/kind what.like build-PA-3s | \glt `What kind of house did he build?'

Knowledge Point: It is also used with the noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unuma} `name' when the name of someone or something is inquired \REF{ex:3:x650}, \REF{ex:3:x651}:
Content 1: \gll O unuma \textbf{kamenap}? | \gls 3s.UNM name what.like? | \glt `What is his/her name?'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa fain unuma \textbf{kamenap}? | \gls tree this name what.like | \glt `What is the name of this tree?'

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{ex:3:x650} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenap} is interchangeable with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naare}(\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{we})-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} `who', but in \REF{ex:3:x651} it is not interchangeable with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mauwa}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-ke} `what'.
Content 1: \gll O unuma \textbf{kamenap}? | \gls 3s.UNM name what.like? | \glt `What is his/her name?'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa fain unuma \textbf{kamenap}? | \gls tree this name what.like | \glt `What is the name of this tree?'

Knowledge Point: The interrogative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenion} forms a clause by itself and only occurs after the question clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} and/or the connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `or' \REF{ex:3:x529}.
Content 1: \gll Maa en-owa=ko p-ekap-e-mik=i \textbf{kamenion}? | \gls thing eat-NMZ=NF BPX-come-PA-1/3p=QM or.what | \glt `Did they bring food, or what (happened)?'

Knowledge Point: The question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap-i} `like that?' is different from the other question words. It is formed by adding the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} to the demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus, like that', and it occurs by itself or sentence-finally after a statement, which often follows another question. It is mainly used in argumentation \REF{ex:3:x1194}, \REF{ex:3:x1195}.
Content 1: \gll Siiwa arow ikiw-eya maa en-owa perek-i-mik. \textbf{Naap}\textbf{=i}? | \gls moon three go-2/3s.DS thing eat-NMZ harvest-Np-1/3p thus=QM | \glt `After three months we'll harvest the food, right?'
Content 2: \gll Feenap eliw ma-i-yen=i? Sira nain eliw marew, \textbf{naap}\textbf{=i}? | \gls like.this well say-Np-FU.1p=QM custom that1 good none thus=QM | \glt `Should we say that that custom is not good -- is that what you are saying?'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake, the indefinites behave syntactically very much like quantifiers \REF{ex:3:x641}, \REF{ex:3:x642}. The position of the indefinites in the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is after the adjective phrase and immediately preceding the demonstrative. They rarely co-occur with a quantifier phrase, but if they do, they follow the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{qp}.
Content 1: \gll Iiriw muuka \textbf{oko} wiawi onak urera maa uup-e-mik. | \gls long.ago boy other 3s/p.father 3s/p.mother evening food cook-PA-1/3p | \glt `Long ago, a certain boy's father and mother cooked food.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The indefinite \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oko} `a certain, (an)other' also has the meaning `otherwise' when it introduces an apprehensive clause \REF{ex:3:x741} (\sectref{sec:8.1.6}).
Content 1: \gll Gurun-owa epasia=pa miim-am-ika-i-kuan, \textbf{oko} mua papako maa ik-em-ik-owa nain kawus wiar uruf-i-kuan. | \gls rumble-NMZ far=LOC hear-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.3p other man some thing/food roast-SS.SIM-be-NMZ that1 smoke 3.DAT see-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They (villagers) keep listening to the rumble from far away, otherwise/lest they (pilots) see the smoke from some men's/people's food-roasting fire.'

Knowledge Point: Those question words (\sectref{sec:3.7.1}) that may function as indefinites behave similarly to question words as \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} constituents, but on the sentence level there are differences between them. The interrogatives occur either in a simple interrogative sentence or occasionally in a medial clause \REF{ex:3:x643}. The indefinites can occur in a medial clause \REF{ex:3:x644}, but they are more common in subordinate clauses, especially relative clauses \REF{ex:3:x645}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Naarew} wia far-ep ekap-o-n? | \gls who 3p.ACC call-SS.SEQ come-PA-2s | \glt `Who did you call, and then came?'\footnote{A more natural translation into English would be `Who did you call before you came?', but it would hide the fact that medial clauses are coordinate.}
Content 2: \gll Masin \textbf{kaanin=ke} samor-ar-eya oko fain=ke asip-i-non. | \gls engine which.of.2=CF bad-INCH-2/3s.DS other this=CF help-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Whichever engine breaks down, this other one will help/substitute.'\footnote{With question intonation it would mean: `Which engine\textsubscript{i} will this other one\textsubscript{j} help, if it\textsubscript{i} breaks down?'}
Content 3: \gll Prais aaw-ep \textbf{uf-owa} \textbf{kain=ke} nomak-e-k nain\textsubscript{RC} wi-e-mik. | \gls prize take-SS.SEQ dance-NMZ which=CF win-PA-3s that1 give.them-PA-1/3p | \glt `They took the prize and, whichever dance won, they gave it (the prize) to them (the dancers).'

Knowledge Point: The indefinite \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mauwa} `what' is also used as a generic substitute for any [\nobreakdash-human] \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} that is left unmentioned because the name of the particular thing is not known or is temporarily forgotten, like \textstyleForeignWords{whatchamacallit} in English \REF{ex:3:x646}.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain \textbf{mauwa} nain akim-a-k=na weetak, \textbf{mauwa} nain me or-o-k. | \gls man that1 what that1 try-PA-3s=TP no, what that1 not descend-PA-3s | \glt `The man tried the thing (press button), but the thing (lift) didn't go down.'

Knowledge Point: The locative question word kaaneke is also used as an indefinite locative adverb \REF{ex:3:x1869}.
Content 1: \gll No \textbf{kaaneke} ikiw-i-nan=na, yos pun nook-i-nen. | \gls 2s.UNM where.CF go-Np-FU.2s=TP 1s.FC too follow.you-Np-FU.1s | \glt `Wherever you go, I will follow you.'

Knowledge Point: The verbal predicate is the only obligatory element in an intransitive clause. A transitive clause does require an object, but even it can often consist of a verb only, as the third person singular accusative pronoun, used for object, is zero \REF{ex:3:x177}. The directional verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) often co-occur with a goal, but when it is left implied the verb can be the only element \REF{ex:3:x178}. In a verbless clause the predicate is a noun, adjective, possessive pronoun or adverb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aaw-e-m.} | \gls get-PA-1s | \glt `I got it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Urup-e-mik}. | \gls go/come.up-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went/came up.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Semantically}}, according to \citet[64]{Givon1984}, a prototypical verb encodes ``{less time-stable experiences, primarily transitory states, events and actions}''. In Mauwake this lack of time-stability feature shows in the strong tendency to use inchoative verbs \REF{ex:3:x179} (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.2.2}) instead of adjectives to describe non-permanent states.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: A verb consists of a root optionally preceded by a derivational prefix \REF{ex:3:x180} and followed by various derivational and inflectional suffixes \REF{ex:3:x181}, \REF{ex:3:x182}, as shown in the diagram below (\figref{fig:3:verbstructure}). Only tense and person/number suffixes are obligatory in a finite verb in the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{indicative}} mood. The obligatory elements are bolded in the diagrams.
Content 1: \gll Soomia wia \textbf{amap-ep-om-i-ya.} | \gls spoon 3p.ACC BPX-go-BEN-Np-PR.3s | \glt `He takes spoons to them.'
Content 2: \gll Iwera pun wiar \textbf{aw-omak-e-k}. | \gls coconut too 3.DAT burn-DISTR/PL-PA-3s | \glt `Many of his coconut palms burned too.'
Content 3: \gll Lawiliw akena \textbf{um-ek-a-m.} | \gls nearly very die-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt `I very nearly died.'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{imperative}} verb structure \figref{fig:3:imperativeinflection} is understandably different in that it cannot take counterfactual, tense or indicative person/number suffixes. Instead, an imperative person/number suffix needs to be attached as the final suffix of the verb \REF{ex:3:x183}, \REF{ex:3:x184}.
Content 1: \gll Ni \textbf{ekap-omak-eka.} | \gls 2p.UNM come-DISTR/PL-IMP.2p | \glt `Come!' (said to several people together)
Content 2: \gll Muuka \textbf{arim-ow-e.} | \gls son grow-CAUS-IMP.2s | \glt `Bring up the boy.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Medial}} verbs likewise can have only the medial suffix after the derivational suffixes, if there are any. The medial suffix distinguishes between sequentiality \REF{ex:3:x409} and simultaneity \REF{ex:3:x186} of the actions when the subject stays the same; with a different subject \REF{ex:3:x187} the actions are understood to be sequential, and simultaneity needs to be marked through continuous aspect form (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1.2}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Ewar=ke \textbf{wuun-ow-ami} epia faker-a-k, mukuna. | \gls wind=CF blow-CAUS-SS.SIM firewood raise-PA-3s fire | \glt `The wind blew and raised the fire(wood), the fire.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Kees-om-a-ya} en-e-k. | \gls spit-BEN-BNFY2-2/3s.DS eat-PA-3s | \glt `He spat/regurgitated it for her and she ate.'

Knowledge Point: The resulting verb is usually transitive \REF{ex:3:x188}, with a few exceptions. The final vowel of a noun or an adjective, usually /a/, is deleted before the verbal inflection \REF{ex:3:x189}.
Content 1: \gll Yo aakisa inasina Rubaruba \textbf{nanar-i-yem}. | \gls 1s.UNM now spirit Rubaruba story-Np-PR.1s | \glt `Now I tell about spirit Rubaruba.'
Content 2: \gll Aruf-ami me \textbf{samor-eka}! | \gls hit-SS.SIM not bad-IMP.2p | \glt `Don't hit/beat and destroy it.'

Knowledge Point: Semantically the resulting verb is usually very close to the word that serves as the root, but in a few instances like \REF{ex:3:x190} the semantic link is not very strong.
Content 1: \gll Nefa \textbf{ikum-am-ika-iwkin} nan kerer-e-n. | \gls 2s.ACC illicitly-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS there appear-PA-2s | \glt `They were just speculating about you when you arrived.'

Knowledge Point: The full resultative verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{-} `become' is more common with nouns, and the meaning of the verb is transparent \REF{ex:3:x191}. It is also used with numerals \REF{ex:3:x192}. Both words retain their word stress.
Content 1: \gll Arim-emi mu'a \textbf{ar-'e-k}. | \gls grow-SS.SIM man become-PA-3s | \glt `He grew up and became man/adult.'
Content 2: \gll Aruf-owa e\textbf{'}repam \textbf{ar-'e-m}. | \gls hit-NMZ four become-PA-1s | \glt `I hit it four times.' (Lit: `Hitting it I became four.')

Knowledge Point: The inchoative suffix \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\nobreakdash-}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar} can occur with nouns \REF{ex:3:x193}, but is more common with adjectives \REF{ex:3:x194} and adverbs \REF{ex:3:x195}, and can attach to a few verb roots too \REF{ex:3:x196}. Since the result is one word it only has one word stress.
Content 1: \gll Yiena opaimika me baliwep \textbf{a'mis-ar-e-mik}. | \gls 1p.GEN talk not well knowledge-INCH-PA-1/3p | \glt `They don't know our language well.'
Content 2: \gll Miiw-aasa \textbf{sa'mor-ar-ek}.{\upshape\footnotemark} | \gls land-canoe bad-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `The car broke.'
Content 3: \gll Kau pun weeser-owa \textbf{e'wur-ar-ek.} | \gls cow too finish-NMZ quickly-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `The beef finished quickly too.'
Content 4: \gll Mua \textbf{i'men-ar-ep} opora pun \textbf{i'men-ar-ek}. | \gls man find-INCH-SS.SEQ talk too find-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `When man appeared, talk/language appeared too.'

Knowledge Point: Verbs derived from adjectives are often used rather than adjectives in the predicative position \REF{ex:3:x82}, \REF{ex:3:x1764}. And instead of a modifying adjective, a whole relative clause with a verb derived from an adjective may be used \REF{ex:3:x83}. This happens especially when the property denoted by the adjective is not static.
Content 1: \gll Sia nain senam \textbf{pin(a)-ar-e-k}. | \gls netbag that1 too.much heavy-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `The netbag is/was (lit: became) very heavy.'
Content 2: \gll Muuka nain op-iya \textbf{dubil}\textbf{(a)-}\textbf{al}\textbf{-}\textbf{e}\textbf{-}\textbf{k}. | \gls boy that1 hold-2/3s.DS slippery-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `When he\textsubscript{1} held the boy\textsubscript{2}, he\textsubscript{2} was slippery.'
Content 3: \gll Konima \textbf{supuk(a)-ar-e-k} \textbf{nain} yasuw-e. | \gls cloth wet-INCH-PA-3s that1 wash-IMP.2s | \glt `Wash the wet cloth.' (Lit: `Wash the cloth that has become wet.')

Knowledge Point: The consonant /r/ in the suffix is lateralized into /l/ when the root has /l/ in the immediately preceding syllable. Lateralization takes place arbitrarily in a few other cases as well \REF{ex:3:x199}.
Content 1: \gll Opaimika efa masi(a)-\textbf{al}-i-ya. | \gls mouth 1s.ACC bitter-INCH-Np-PR.3s | \glt `It tastes bitter to me / in my mouth.'

Knowledge Point: If two preceding syllables contain /l/, the consonant in the verbaliser is not lateralized \REF{ex:3:x200}.\footnote{This rule is very tentative, as \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ilelar}- is the only example found so far.}
Content 1: \gll Aasa puuk-ap ilel(a)-\textbf{ar}-i-ya. | \gls canoe cut-SS.SEQ gouge-INCH-Np-PR.3s | \glt `He has cut the canoe (length from a tree) and is gouging/carving it'

Knowledge Point: The suffix \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar}- often retains its original verbal meaning `become' when adjectives are made into verbs \REF{ex:3:x201}, but when the other word classes are used as the root the original meaning tends to become more opaque or get lost \REF{ex:3:x202}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dubil}\textbf{(a)-al-e-k.} | \gls slippery/smooth-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `It became slippery/smooth.'
Content 2: \gll No \textbf{wadol}\textbf{(a)-al-i-n.} | \gls 2s.UNM lie-INCH-Np-PR.2s | \glt `You are lying.'

Knowledge Point: Most of the verbs formed with the inchoative suffix are intransitive, but some are active, transitive verbs \REF{ex:3:x203}, \REF{ex:3:x204}:
Content 1: \gll Muuka kuisow \textbf{muuk}\textbf{(a)-ar-e-k}. | \gls son one son-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `She gave birth to one son.'
Content 2: \gll Epa \textbf{mores-ar-ep} ikiw-o-k. | \gls place like(ADV)-INCH-SS.SEQ go-PA-3s | \glt `He made the place ready and went.'

Knowledge Point: The inchoative verb formation is also used with verb loans from other languages \REF{ex:3:x488}, especially Tok Pisin \REF{ex:3:x487}.\footnote{The Tok Pisin loans often originally come from English.} Both of the loan words below also have a vernacular synonym.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Sometimes the causative suffix occurs reduplicated as a ``double causative'', but these still add only one argument. Many of the short directional verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) take a double causative instead of a single one \REF{ex:3:x205}.
Content 1: \gll Eewua ir\textbf{-ow-aw-}ap osaiwa ar-e-k. | \gls wing climb-CAUS-CAUS-SS.SEQ bird.of.paradise become-PA-3s | \glt `She put the wing up (on herself) and became a bird of paradise.'

Knowledge Point: \tabref{tab:3:pseudocausatives} lists some verbs that have are derived from other verbs with the causative suffix but which do \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} have any causative meaning \REF{ex:3:x991}, \REF{ex:3:x489}. The causative as a valence-increasing device is discussed in \sectref{sec:3.8.4.3.1}.
Content 1: \gll Mukuna kuuf-ap kirir-e-k. | \gls fire see-SS.SEQ shout-PA-3s | \glt `She saw the fire and shouted.'
Content 2: \gll Yiok-ami naap \textbf{yia} \textbf{kirir-ow-am-ik-ua.} | \gls follow.us-SS.SIM thus 1p.ACC shout-CAUS-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `She was following us and shouting about us like that.'

Knowledge Point: The hierarchy of which argument the distributive applies to is as follows: if there is a recipient \REF{ex:3:x209} or beneficiary \REF{ex:3:x429}, the distributive applies to that; if there is no recipient or beneficiary but an object, the distributive applies to the object \REF{ex:3:x492}; and in case the clause has neither a recipient or beneficiary nor an object, the distributive applies to the subject \REF{ex:3:x491}. Since transitive verbs need an object, the subject can be pluralized with the distributive only when the verb is intransitive.
Content 1: \gll Mua teeria opaimika wia sesek-\textbf{omak}-e-mik. | \gls man family talk 3p.ACC send-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `They sent word to (many members of) the man's family.'
Content 2: \gll Wiena wiawi=ke amia wia keraw-om-\textbf{omak}-e-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN 3s/p.father=CF spear 3p.ACC carve-BEN-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `Their fathers carved spears for them (many beneficiaries).'
Content 3: \gll Emeria unowa fain nia aaw-\textbf{urum}-i-kuan. | \gls woman many this 2s.ACC take-DISTR/A-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They will take all you women.'
Content 4: \gll Emeria teeria koka ikiw-\textbf{urum}-e-mik. | \gls woman group jungle go-DISTR/A-PA-1/3p | \glt `The whole group of women / all the women went to the jungle.'

Knowledge Point: In verbal groups (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1}) the distributive suffix usually attaches to the last verb root \REF{ex:3:x207}, \REF{ex:3:x490}, but it can occasionally also attach to the first root, i.e. the main verb in a verb+\textstyleAcronymallcaps{aux} combination \REF{ex:3:x208}.
Content 1: \gll Iinan aasa ikiw-emi paran-em-\textbf{mi-omak-e-k}. | \gls sky canoe go-SS.SIM rumble-SS.SIM-go.around-DISTR/PL-PA-3s | \glt  `Many planes went rumbling around.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Wi ifa saarik \textbf{in-urum-ep}-ik-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM snake like sleep-DISTR/A-SS.SEQ-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They all slept/lay like snakes.'

Knowledge Point: Both suffixes can be attached to the same verb but it is rare. In that case \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\nobreakdash-}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{urum} precedes \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\nobreakdash-}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{omak} \REF{ex:3:x206}.
Content 1: \gll Wia ifakim\textbf{-urum}-\textbf{omak}-e-mik. | \gls 3p.ACC kill-DISTR/A-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `They killed each and every one of them.' (There were many of those killed.)

Knowledge Point: The benefactive suffix, indicating the fact that the action of the verb is done \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{for someone}}, for their benefit or detriment, is a borderline case among the derivations. It is the last one of the derivational suffixes, and the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{beneficiary suffix}} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.1}) following it and marking the person that the action is done for, is inflectional even if the two suffixes go together semantically. The position of the benefactive is not as stable as that of the other suffixes: it comes after the distributive when the beneficiary is first person singular \REF{ex:3:x210}, \REF{ex:3:x1925} but occurs preceding it with the other persons \REF{ex:3:x211}, \REF{ex:3:x1926}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Buk aaw-omak-\textbf{om}-e! | \gls book get-DISTR/PL-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s | \glt `Get the books for me!'
Content 3: \gll Buk aaw-\textbf{om}-omak-e! | \gls book get-BEN-DISTR/PL-IMP.2s | \glt `Get the books for him!'
Content 4: \gll Wiena wiawi=ke amia wia keraw-\textbf{om}-omak-e-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN 3s/p.father=CF bow 3p.ACC carve-BEN-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `Their fathers carved bows for them.'

Knowledge Point: In verbal groups the benefactive suffix is usually attached to the finite verb or auxiliary \REF{ex:3:x212} but can occasionally occur on the non-finite root \REF{ex:3:x213} or even on both of the two \REF{ex:3:x214}.
Content 1: \gll Iwera wia uruk-am-ik-\textbf{om}-a-mik. | \gls coconut 3p.ACC drop-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `We kept dropping coconuts for them.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Moro mua wia wu-\textbf{om}-am-ik-\textbf{om}-a-mik. | \gls Moro man 3p.ACC put-BEN-BNFY2.SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `They put them (=carts) for the Moro men.'

Knowledge Point: The benefactive form does not always mean that something happens for someone's\textstyleEmphasizedWords{} \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{benefit}}. The benefactive may be strengthened with the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{orawin} `for the benefit' \REF{ex:3:x215}, which makes it unambiguous.
Content 1: \gll Iwera \textbf{orawin} kais-\textbf{om}-e-mik. | \gls Coconut for.the.benefit husk-BEN-BNFY1.PA-1/3p | \glt `They husked coconuts for me (for free).'

Knowledge Point: In verbs of motion reduplication means continuity \REF{ex:3:x218}, and the passing of time may be shown by the number of reduplications \REF{ex:3:x216}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Biri-birin-emi} wia akim-omak-e-mik. | \gls RDP-fly-SS.SIM 3p.ACC try-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `They were flying and teasing them.'
Content 2: \gll Ne \textbf{oro-oro-oro}-oro-mi \textbf{oro-oro}-or-o-k, onoma. | \gls and RDP-RDP-RDP-descend-SS.SIM RDP-RDP-descend-PA-3s horizon. | \glt `And it went down and down and down all the way to the horizon.'

Knowledge Point: In other intransitive verbs reduplication indicates either iterative action \REF{ex:3:x217} or occasionally continuity \REF{ex:3:x692}.
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa \textbf{ku-ku-ep} or-om-ik-ua. | \gls tree RDP-break-SS.SEQ descend-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `The timber (in a bridge) kept breaking and falling down.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Both of these meanings fit in well with \citegen[319]{Moravcsik1978} description of the various meanings that reduplication in verbs can have. In transitive verbs reduplication indicates iterative action as well as the plurality of an inanimate object \REF{ex:3:x219}. The form is used especially when the action \textstyleEmphasizedWords{results} in a plural object \REF{ex:3:x220}.
Content 1: \gll Iinan aasa=ke maifa \textbf{fu-fuurk-ikiw-o-k}. | \gls sky canoe=CF paper RDP-throw-go-PA-3s | \glt `The plane went throwing paper slips down'
Content 2: \gll Oposia nain \textbf{pu-puuk-ap} uup-e-mik. | \gls meat that1 RDP-cut-SS.SEQ cook-PA-1/3p | \glt `We cut up the meat (into many pieces) and cooked it.'

Content 1: \gll Amina aaw-ep Liisa ame wia \textbf{p-er}-om-a. | \gls pot take/get-SS.SEQ Liisa others 3p.ACC BPX-go-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2s | \glt `Get the pot and take it to Liisa and the others.'
Content 2: \gll Pita pensil wiar or-op ik-ua nain aaw-ep \textbf{amap-ikiw}-om-aka. | \gls Pita pencil 3.DAT fall-SS.SEQ be-PA.3s that1 take-SS.SEQ BPX-go-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p | \glt `Take to Pita his pencil that has dropped.'
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll Amina aaw-ep Liisa ame wia \textbf{p-er}-om-a. | \gls pot take/get-SS.SEQ Liisa others 3p.ACC BPX-go-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2s | \glt `Get the pot and take it to Liisa and the others.'
Content 5: \gll Ni auwa maa \textbf{p-urup}-om-aka. | \gls 2p.UNM father food BPX-ascend-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p | \glt `Take food (up) to father.'
Content 6: \gll Iwera ir-ap erup op-ap \textbf{aap-or}-e. | \gls coconut go.up-SS.SEQ two grab-SS.SEQ BPX-descend-IMP.2s | \glt `Climb the coconut palm, grab two coconuts and bring them down.'

Knowledge Point: The only two forms for the beneficiary are \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\nobreakdash-}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} for first or second person singular \REF{ex:3:x225} and \textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\nobreakdash-}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a} for all the other persons \REF{ex:3:x226}. The context often provides more person distinctions, as the plural requires accusative pronouns to precede the verb to indicate the beneficiary, like third person plural in \REF{ex:3:x227}.
Content 1: \gll Wafur-om-\textbf{e}! | \gls throw-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s | \glt `Throw it to me!'
Content 2: \gll Marasin wu-om-\textbf{a}-mik=na weetak. | \gls medicine put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p=TP no | \glt `They put medicine on him but no (it didn't help).'
Content 3: \gll Na-iwkin \textbf{wia} uf-om-\textbf{a}-mik. | \gls say-2/3p.DS 3p.ACC dance-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `They said so and we danced for them.'

Knowledge Point: When the beneficiary suffix is followed by a vowel, a mid vowel is deleted adjacent to a low vowel \REF{ex:3:x228} and both a mid and a low vowel are deleted preceding a high vowel \REF{ex:3:x444}. In the latter case the person distinction gets neutralized in the singular \REF{ex:3:x1750}, but not in the plural where the obligatory accusative pronouns maintain the distinction \REF{ex:3:x445}. The examples \REF{ex:3:x494}-\REF{ex:3:x496} below show how the beneficiary suffix affects the past tense suffix. In \REF{ex:3:x496} a sequence of two identical vowels is reduced to one vowel.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll Panewowa maa \textbf{wia} p-ikiw-om-\textbf{uk}. | \gls old food 3p.ACC BPX-go-BEN-BNFY.IMP.3p | \glt `Let them take food for the old people.'

Knowledge Point: The counterfactual modality is the only modal distinction made in the verb morphology. It is an expression of the truth value of the statement: something could or would have happened, but did not, or something might be the case but for some reason is not. The counterfactual is marked by the suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ek} \REF{ex:3:x234} and is only used with the past tense suffix even if the verb refers to the present \REF{ex:3:x433} or future \REF{ex:3:x434} time\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\textmd{.}} The counterfactual is used in both hypothetical and counterfactual conditional clauses (\sectref{sec:8.3.5}).
Content 1: \gll Lawiliw akena waki-\textbf{ek}-a-m. | \gls nearly very fall-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt `I very nearly fell.'
Content 2: \gll Yena aamun aakisa uruf-\textbf{ek-a}-m=na kemel-\textbf{ek-a}-m. | \gls 1s.GEN yonger.brother now see-CNTF-PA-1s=TP rejoice-CNTF-PA-1s | \glt `If I saw my younger brother now, I would be happy.'
Content 3: \gll Morauta fan ik-\textbf{ek-a}-k=na uurika ikiw-ep maak-\textbf{ek-a}-mik. | \gls Morauta here be-CNTF-PA-3s=TP tomorrow go-SS.SEQ tell-CNTF-PA-1/3p | \glt `If Morauta were here, tomorrow we would go and tell him.'

Knowledge Point: If there is a beneficiary suffix \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-a} preceding the counterfactual, the vowel /e/ of the counterfactual suffix is deleted \REF{ex:3:x235}:
Content 1: \gll Maifa yia aaw-om-\textbf{ak}-a-k=na{\dots} | \gls paper 1p.ACC get-BEN-BNFY2.CNTF-PA-3s=TP | \glt `If he had gotten tickets for us{\dots}'

Knowledge Point: The indicative is the neutral, morphologically unmarked mood. It is characterized by the tense distinctions between present, past \REF{ex:3:x693} and future \REF{ex:3:x694}, and the person/number distinctions of first, second, and third person in singular and plural.
Content 1: \gll I me yia damol-a-mik. | \gls 1s.UNM not 1s.ACC harm-PA-1/3p | \glt `They didn't harm us.'
Content 2: \gll Aria, iperowa opora wiar ook-i-yen. | \gls alright, middle-aged talk 3.DAT follow-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Alright, we'll follow the advice of the middle-aged men.'

Knowledge Point: The term imperative is used for ``mands'' \citep[745]{Lyons1977}\footnote{Lyons borrows the term from B.F. Skinner as a useful cover term, without subscribing to Skinner's behaviouristic position.} showing in the verbal morphology, regardless of person. In Mauwake the imperatives form a full paradigm (with the first person singular being replaced with the first person dual), and their syntactic behaviour is similar. So there is no valid reason to divide them into different categories such as imperatives, jussives and hortatives, just because semantically giving orders to oneself differs from giving orders to an addressee or to a third person \REF{ex:3:x229}--\REF{ex:3:x230}.\footnote{For a discussion on this question, see \citet[109--111]{Palmer1986}.}
Content 1: \gll Or-op mua nain uruf-\textbf{e}. | \gls descend-SS.SEQ man that1 see-IMP.2s | \glt `Go down and see that man.'
Content 2: \gll Wi urup-ep mukuna nain umuk-\textbf{uk}. | \gls 3p.UNM ascend-SS.SEQ fire that1 extinguish-IMP.3p | \glt `Let them go up and extinguish the fire.'

Knowledge Point: The imperative differs from the other moods in that in the first person it has a dual form, rather than a singular form \REF{ex:3:x446}, \REF{ex:3:x1196}.
Content 1: \gll Aria, i owowa=ko or-\textbf{u}. | \gls alright, 1p.UNM village=NF descend-IMP.1d | \glt `Alright, let's (d.) go down to the village.'
Content 2: \gll Yiena ikos akena iw-\textbf{u}. | \gls 1p.GEN two.together truly go-IMP.1d | \glt `Let's just the two of us go together.'

Knowledge Point: The initial (or only) vowel in the second person imperative forms is deleted after the beneficiary suffix \REF{ex:3:x432}--\REF{ex:3:x233}.
Content 1: \gll Iwera ir-\textbf{e.} | \gls coconut ascend-IMP.2s | \glt `Climb up the coconut palm (to get coconuts).'
Content 2: \gll Iwera \textbf{yia} ir-om-\textbf{a}ka. | \gls coconut 1p.ACC ascend-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p | \glt `Climb up (plural) the coconut palm for us.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: The speech event is taken as the reference point. The tense suffixes in themselves only distinguish between two tenses, past and non-past, and the further distinction between present and future is made by the person/number suffixes \REF{ex:3:x1029}. The person/number suffixes, on the other hand, are the same in past and present tense except for the first and third person singular forms.
Content 1: \gll Unan \textbf{aakun-e-mik}, aakisa \textbf{aakun-i-mik} ne uurika nainiw \textbf{aakun-i-yen}. | \gls yesterday talk-PA-1/3p now/today talk-Np-PR.1/3p ADD tomorrow again talk-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Yesterday we talked, now/today we talk and tomorrow we'll talk again.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: The person/number marking in the verb distinguishes three persons in both singular and plural. There is no dual number, nor is there inclusive-exclusive distinction in the first person plural form. The plural is marked only for humans, spirits and important animals. The singular form is used for less important and small animals as well as all inanimates \REF{ex:3:x236}.
Content 1: \gll Waa muuka arow ekap-o-\textbf{k}. | \gls pig boy three come-PA-3s | \glt `Three piglets came.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: Besides their primary meaning, the present and future tenses also have secondary meanings. The present tense form of the first or third person plural is used for generic or time-neutral statements \REF{ex:3:x1034}. For the habitual aspect in the present, the simple present tense \REF{ex:3:x1035} is an alternative to the full habitual aspect form.\footnote{Continuous aspect form is required for the past habitual (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1.2}).}
Content 1: \gll Ifa yia keraw-i-ya nain miira \textbf{saawirin-i-mik}. | \gls snake 1p.ACC bite-Np-PR.3s that1 face become.round-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt  `When a snake bites us, we become dizzy.'
Content 2: \gll Nos=ke anane urema efar \textbf{ikum-ar-i-n}. | \gls 2s.FC=CF always bandicoot 1s.DAT illicitly-INCH-Np-PR.2s | \glt `You always steal bandicoots from me.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: The future tense in any person form is used for habitual or generic conditionals \REF{ex:3:x1640} (\sectref{sec:8.3.5}). The example \REF{ex:3:x1641} refers to a traditional custom and is generic, even if the first person form of the verb is used, and the first person pronoun as well.
Content 1: \gll Waaya \textbf{ika-i-non}, waaya \textbf{uup-i-nan}, naap. | \gls pig be-Np-FU.3s pig cook-Np-FU.2s thus | \glt `If there is a pig, you will cook it - it is like that.'
Content 2: \gll Ikoka yo \textbf{um-i-nen}, muuka nain nainiw wiena \textbf{aaw-i-kuan}. | \gls later 1s.UNM die-Np-FU.1s son that1 again 3p.GEN take-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Later, if I die (without paying the bride price) they will take the son back.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: The second person singular form of the future tense has two other usages as well. It can be used when referring to generic or habitual situations, especially in process descriptions which can also be understood as instructions. For these, the first person plural form of the present tense is much more common, but often the two alternate. The following example \REF{ex:3:x1038} describes work involved in harvesting taro roots (and the addressee that the story was told to, had no garden, so the speaker did not refer to her personally).
Content 1: \gll Perek-ami en-ow(a) gelemuta \textbf{on-i-nan}. | \gls harvest-SS.SIM eat-NMZ little make-Np-FU.2s | \glt `When you harvest it, you make a feast.'

Subsubsection: Tense and person/number in final verbs\label{sec:3.8.3.4
Knowledge Point: It is also used for a command, or a statement of obligation \REF{ex:3:x1039}:
Content 1: \gll Ikoka kuisow kuuma kuisow \textbf{yi-i-nan}. | \gls later one stick one give.me-Np-FU.2s | \glt `Very soon you have to give me 10 kina.' Or: `Give me 10 kina very soon.'

Knowledge Point: Typically, medial verbs have much fewer inflectional possibilities than finite verbs \citep[11]{Foley1986}. This is the case in Mauwake too: mood or tense and full person/number marking cannot be suffixed to the medial verbs. Derivational suffixes, on the other hand, can freely occur on the medial verbs. In Tail-Head linkage a new sentence begins with a medial verb copy of the finite verb that ended the previous sentence (\sectref{sec:8.2.3.5}). Often the derivational morphology of the two verbs is the same, and sometimes the medial verb has less derivation than the final verb; very rarely it has even \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{more}} \REF{ex:3:x237}:
Content 1: \gll Ikiwosa wiar pepekim-ep kaik-a-m. Kaik-\textbf{om}-\textbf{a}p{\dots} | \gls head 3.DAT measure-SS.SEQ tie-PA-1s tie-BEN-BNFY2.SS.SEQ | \glt `I measured her head and tied it (=headdress). I tied it for her and {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: When the subject of the medial clause is the same as that of the following clause, the verb itself does not give any indication of the person and number of the subject, only that the same subject continues in the next clause.\footnote{For exceptions to this, see \sectref{sec:8.2.3} where the functional aspects of switch reference are discussed.} If the actions are sequential, i.e. the action indicated by the verb in the medial clause precedes that of the following clause, the suffix is \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ap} or \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ep} \REF{ex:3:x238} depending on the conjugation class (\sectref{sec:2.3.3.3}).\footnote{For the second conjugation class verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{or}- `descend' the suffix is -\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{op}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{.}}
Content 1: \gll Owowa or-\textbf{op}, wuailal-\textbf{ep} akia ik-e-k. | \gls village go.down-SS.SEQ be.hungry-SS.SEQ banana roast-PA-3s | \glt `He went (down) to the village, was hungry and roasted bananas.'

Knowledge Point: If the verb has the beneficiary suffix \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-a} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-e} (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.1}), the vowel of the medial verb suffix gets assimilated to it \REF{ex:3:x1930}, \REF{ex:3:x1929}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point:
When the medial clause subject is the same as the subject in the following clause but the two actions are simultaneous, or at least overlapping, the suffix is 
obreakdash-	extstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ami} or 
obreakdash-	extstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{emi} (or 
obreakdash-	extstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{omi}) according to the conjugation class of the verb. Even if the action of the medial verb may often be 	extstyleEmphasizedWords{{interpreted}} as continuous \REF{ex:3:x239}, the suffix in itself only indicates simultaneity \REF{ex:3:x240}. Continuous aspect marking may be needed for clarity when continuity is in focus \REF{ex:3:x241}.
Content 1: \gll Wi sawur ir-\textbf{ami} fan yiar pok-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM spirit go-SS.SIM here 1p.DAT sit.down-PA-1/3p | \glt `As the spirits were going they sat down here with us.'
Content 2: \gll {\dots}ekap-\textbf{emi} koora=pa yia wua-i-mik. | \gls come-SS.SIM house=LOC 1p.ACC put-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `{\dots}coming (=upon arrival) they put us in the house.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Soomar-em-ik}\textbf{-ok} ifara oko uruf-a-k. | \gls walk-SS.SIM-be-SS vine other see-PA-3s | \glt `He was walking and saw another vine. '

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' is different from other verbs in that there is no differentiation between the simultaneous and sequential forms in the same-subject medial verb: in example \REF{ex:3:x242} the actions are simultaneous, in \REF{ex:3:x243} sequential. Also, the verb does not take either one of the normal same-subject suffixes.
Content 1: \gll Owowa=pa neeke \textbf{ik-ok} mua maak-ek{\dots} | \gls village=LOC there.CF be-SS man tell-PA-3s | \glt `While they were there in the village she told her husband, {\dots}'
Content 2: \gll No kaaneke \textbf{ik-ok} kerer-e-n? | \gls 2s.UNM where.CF be-SS appear-PA-2s | \glt `Where have you been and now come?'

Knowledge Point: If the subject of the medial clause is different from that of the following clause, the suffix of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{ds} verb reflects this. There are some person/number distinctions in these suffixes, even though not as many as in the finite verbs. The first person singular and plural are distinguished from all the other forms; in the other persons the distinction is based on the number: second and third person singular share the same suffix, and second and third person plural likewise \REF{ex:3:x244}, \REF{ex:3:x245}.\footnote{There is great variation in this area in Papuan languages. Some only have one form to indicate that the subject changes, others have partial or full differentiation according to the person, some even show the subject of the following clause in the medial verb.} \tabref{tab:3:differentsubject} shows the different subject suffixes.
Content 1: \gll Imen-ap maak-\textbf{iwkin} o miim-o-k. | \gls find-SS.SEQ tell-2/3p.DS 3s.UNM precede-PA-3s | \glt `They found him and told him, and he went ahead of them.'
Content 2: \gll Mik-\textbf{amkun} me um-o-k, wiowa onaiya ikiw-em-ik-\textbf{eya} Olas=ke war-ek. | \gls spear-1s/p.DS not die-PA-3s spear with go-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS Olas=CF shoot-PA-3s | \glt `When I speared it, it didn't die, (but) as it was going with the spear Olas shot it.'
