Knowledge Point: The suffix is -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aya} instead of \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eya} in a few short conjugation class 1 verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.1}) \REF{ex:3:x493}\footnote{The vowel \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{-a} is somewhat more common in the Muaka dialect group where the 2/3s.\textsc{ds} marker is -era instead of \nobreakdash-eya.} and in those benefactive verbs where the first vowel of the suffix is assimilated to the preceding vowel of the beneficiary suffix \REF{ex:3:x695}.
Content 1: \gll Iw-\textbf{aya} nan miira saawirin-e-k. | \gls enter-2/3s.DS there face become.round-PA-3s | \glt `As [the poison] entered [his liver], he became dizzy.'
Content 2: \gll Aaya=ko yia aaw-om-\textbf{aya} enim-i-yan. | \gls sugarcane=NF 1p.ACC get-BEN-BNFY2.2/3s.DS eat-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Get us sugarcane and we'll eat it.'

Knowledge Point: The different-subject marking \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eya} is also used with some non-verbs. This seems to be uncommon in \textsc{png} languages: in \citeauthor{Roberts1997}' (1997:137) survey the very few examples where the switch-reference marking was on non-verbs these were pro-clausal substitutes like a demonstrative or vocative. In Mauwake the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{ds} suffix can be added to nouns \REF{ex:3:x250} or adjectives \REF{ex:3:x251}, or the negative adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} \REF{ex:3:x252} functioning as predicates in verbless clauses. When it is added to words ending in -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a}, the first vowel in the suffix gets assimilated to this vowel \REF{ex:3:x250}.
Content 1: \gll Enakiwa-\textbf{ya} me aaw-e-m. | \gls half-2/3s.DS not take-PA-1s | \glt `There was (only) half (left), so I didn't take any/it.'
Content 2: \gll Mauwow maneka-\textbf{ya}=na yia maak-i-non. | \gls work big-2/3s.DS=TP 1p.ACC tell-Np-FU.3s | \glt `If the work is big, she will tell us.'
Content 3: \gll Soomia marew-\textbf{eya} amap-ep-om-a-m. | \gls spoon none-2/3s.DS BPX-come-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1s | \glt `She has/had no spoons (lit: there are/were no spoons) so I brought them to her.'
Content 4: \gll Enakiwa-\textbf{ya} me aaw-e-m. | \gls half-2/3s.DS not take-PA-1s | \glt `There was (only) half (left), so I didn't take any/it.'

Knowledge Point: The medial verbs have no tense marking, so the tense in a medial clause is interpreted in relation to that of the next finite clause. When the finite clause is in the past tense, both a simultaneous \REF{ex:3:x1025} and a sequential medial clause \REF{ex:3:x1023} are also understood to be in the past tense.
Content 1: \gll Iwera uruk-am-ika-iwkin wi \textbf{ikiw-emi} \textbf{aaw-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls coconut drop-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS 3p.UNM go-SS.SIM take-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They\textsubscript{i} kept dropping coconuts, and they\textsubscript{j} went and got them.'
Content 2: \gll Owowa \textbf{or-op,} \textbf{wailal-ep}, akia \textbf{ik-e-k}. | \gls village descend-SS.SEQ be.hungry-SS.SEQ banana roast-PA-3s | \glt `He came down to the village, was hungry and roasted bananas.'

Knowledge Point: Since a sequential verb indicates that the action takes place before another action, a sequential medial clause preceding a present tense final clause has to be interpreted to be in the past tense, whereas a simultaneous clause is interpreted to be in the present tense like the final verb \REF{ex:3:x1024}.
Content 1: \gll Iperuma nain=ke mua \textbf{puuk-ap} owora \textbf{en-emi} afura \textbf{buan-em-ika-i-ya}. | \gls eel that1=CF man change.into-SS.SEQ betelnut eat-SS.SIM lime.container knock-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `The eel has become man, and is eating betelnut and knocking the lime container.'

Knowledge Point: Both a sequential and a simultaneous medial clause preceding a future final clause are also understood as future clauses. The action in a sequential medial clause takes place before that in the final clause, but it is still in the future \REF{ex:3:x1026}. The action in a simultaneous clause is partly or fully overlapping with that in the final clause \REF{ex:3:x1027}.
Content 1: \gll Is=ke maa uup-emkun wi \textbf{ekap-ep} \textbf{enim-i-kuan}. | \gls 1p.FC=CF food cook-1s/p.DS 3p.UNM come-SS.SEQ eat-Np-FU.3p | \glt `We'll cook the food and they'll come and eat it.' Or: `When we have cooked the food they will come and eat it.'
Content 2: \gll Wi \textbf{ir-ami} nia \textbf{aaw-emi} efa \textbf{ifakim-i-kuan}. | \gls 3p.UNM come-SS.SIM 2p.ACC take-SS.SIM 1s.ACC kill-Np-FU.3p | \glt `They will come and take you and kill me.'

Knowledge Point: The medial verb form cannot be used in the following example, because the first verb refers to time preceding the speech event and the second verb to time following it. Final verbs with different tenses have to be used, and in this case it is most natural to place the past tense verb in a relative clause \REF{ex:3:x1030}.
Content 1: \gll Mukuna kerer-e-k nain kamenap umuk-i-yan? | \gls fire appear-PA-3s that1 how extinguish-Np-FU.1p | \glt `How shall we extinguish the fire that started?'

Knowledge Point: The medial verbs acquire more absolute-relative tense character of ``past in the past'' \citep[65]{Comrie1985} in those cases where sequential medial clauses are either right-dislo\-cated and placed after the final clause \REF{ex:3:x1031} or placed inside another medial clause \REF{ex:3:x1032}, or when there is a separate time expression referring to earlier time than that indicated by the final verb \REF{ex:3:x1033}.
Content 1: \gll Rubaruba nain=ke ona emeria nain aaw-ep p-ikiw-o-k, \textbf{iw-iwkin}. | \gls Rubaruba that1=CF 3s.GEN woman that1 take-SS.SEQ BPX-go-PA-3s give.him-2/3p.DS | \glt `That Rubaruba took his wife and took her (away), when they had given her to him.'
Content 2: \gll Um-eya merena ere-erup \textbf{ifara} \textbf{aaw-ep} kaik-ap nabena suuw-ap akua aaw-ep or-o-m. | \gls die-2/3s.DS leg RDP-two vine get-SS.SEQ tie-SS.SEQ carrying.pole push-SS.SEQ shoulder take-SS.SEQ descend-PA-1s | \glt  `It died, and I tied its legs in pairs with a vine that I had gotten, and pushed it to the carrying pole and carried it down on my shoulder.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Iiriw} inasin mua nain=ke naap wia \textbf{maak-eya} wi naap on-a-mik. | \gls earlier spirit man that=CF thus 3p.ACC tell-2/3p.DS 3p.UNM thus do-PA-1/3p | \glt  `The spirit man had earlier told them like that and they did so.'

Knowledge Point: In the Mauwake lexicon the verbs are divided into classes 1 and 2 depending on whether they have \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a} or \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{E} as the past tense suffix. There are morphophonological rules for deriving the past tense marking for most verbs (\sectref{sec:2.3.3.3}), but since some of the rules are rather complicated, and because they do not cover a number of cases like \REF{ex:3:x253} and \REF{ex:3:x254} below, the division into two separate classes is maintained.
Content 1: \gll miim-\textbf{a}-k | \gls hear-PA-3s | \glt `he heard'
Content 2: \gll miim-\textbf{o}-k | \gls precede-PA-3s | \glt `he went ahead'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake the class of basic, or ``ordinary'', intransitive verbs consists of a semantically very diverse group including involuntary processes \REF{ex:3:x266}, many motion verbs \REF{ex:3:x267}, and some bodily function verbs \REF{ex:3:x269}.
Content 1: \gll Fikera \textbf{aw-o-k}. | \gls kunai.grass burn-PA-3s | \glt `The kunai grass burned.'
Content 2: \gll Kuuten ikos \textbf{karu-e-mik}. | \gls Kuuten with run-PA-1/3p | \glt `I ran with Kuuten.'
Content 3: \gll Niir-emi \textbf{pisi-e}\textbf{-k}. | \gls laugh-SS.SIM fart-PA-3s | \glt `He laughed and farted.'

Knowledge Point: Some experience verbs expressing physiological states are also regular intransitive verbs \REF{ex:3:x1485}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verbs derived with the inchoative suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar} (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.2.2}) are mostly intransitive \REF{ex:3:x271}, \REF{ex:3:x1486}, but a few of them are transitive \REF{ex:3:x1836}.
Content 1: \gll Uuw-ap uuw-ap \textbf{lebum-ar-e-m}. | \gls work-SS.SEQ work-SS.SEQ lazy-INCH-PA-1s | \glt `I worked and worked and got tired.'
Content 2: \gll Nan teeria \textbf{manek-ar-e-k}, owowa pun manek-ar-e-k. | \gls there family big-INCH-PA-3s village also big-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `The family grew big there, and the village grew big too.'
Content 3: \gll Maa unowa oram me \textbf{amis}\textbf{-}\textbf{ar}\textbf{-}\textbf{i}\textbf{-}\textbf{mik}, weetak. | \gls thing many just not knowledge-INCH-Np-PR.1/3p no | \glt `We don't just gain knowledge of many things (without learning them), no.'

Knowledge Point: Climate expressions often use intransitive verbs. There is no separate class of verbs for climate expressions \REF{ex:3:x270}.\footnote{Climate expressions also use directional verbs (\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ipia oraiya }`the rain descends'), inchoative verbs (\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{kokomarek }`it got dark') and transitive verbs (\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ama fookak }`the sun split (tr.)').}
Content 1: \gll Aapereka \textbf{paran-em-ika-i-ya}. | \gls cloud rumble-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `It is thundering.'

Knowledge Point: Transitive verbs require a subject and an object. A [+human] object needs to be marked with an accusative pronoun (\sectref{sec:3.5.3}) regardless of the presence or absence of a separate object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} \REF{ex:3:x294}.
Content 1: \gll Yaapan wia ifakim-e-mik. | \gls Japan 3p.ACC kill-PA-1/3p | \glt `They killed the Japanese.'

Knowledge Point: Besides the prototypical transitive verbs with an agent subject and a patient-of-change object \citep[96]{Givon1984} like \REF{ex:3:x295} and \REF{ex:3:x296}, also many verbs of perception \REF{ex:3:x297}, cognition \REF{ex:3:x298} and emotion \REF{ex:3:x299} are transitive.
Content 1: \gll Wiipa erup wia \textbf{sesek-a-mik}. | \gls girl two 3p.ACC send-PA-1/3p | \glt `They sent the two girls.'
Content 2: \gll Yo me efa \textbf{enim-uk}. | \gls 1s.UNM not 1.ACC eat-IMP.3p | \glt `Let them not eat me.'\footnote{This was said in a traditional story by a spirit that was able to change into a man or into an eel, which the people in the story were preparing to eat.}
Content 3: \gll Nomokowa unowa aakisa wia \textbf{uruf-i-n.} | \gls 2s/p.brother many now 3p.ACC see-Np-PR.2s | \glt `Now you see many brothers of yours.
Content 4: \gll Nefa \textbf{amis-ar-ep} ma-i-yem. | \gls 2s.ACC knowledge-INCH-SS.SEQ say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am saying (this) because I know you.'
Content 5: \gll Yena mua=ke efa \textbf{kookal-ep} manin(a) uuw-owa efa asip-i-ya. | \gls 1s.GEN man 1s.ACC like-SS.SEQ garden work-NMZ 1s.ACC help-Np-PR.3s | \glt `My husband likes me and helps me in the garden.'

Knowledge Point: If there is no other overt object available for a transitive verb, the maximally generic noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maa} `thing'\footnote{The semantic area of \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{maa} is at least as wide that of its English equivalent `thing'. Because it is used so often with verbs denoting eating and preparing food, it has acquired a secondary meaning `food'.} is used as a dummy object \REF{ex:3:x300}, \REF{ex:3:x1825}. Compare the next two examples: in \REF{ex:3:x300} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maa} is added because of syntactic requirements, whereas in \REF{ex:3:x301} the lack of an overt object indicates a third person singular object.
Content 1: \gll (Yo) \textbf{maa} uruf-i-yem. | \gls I thing see-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I see.' (=I see something, or: I can see.)
Content 2: \gll Iir oko \textbf{maa} enim-i-yem, iir oko \textbf{maa} me enim-i-yem. | \gls time other thing eat-Np-PR.1s time other thing not eat-Np-PR.1s | \glt `Sometimes I eat, sometimes I don't eat.'
Content 3: \gll (Yo) \textbf{maa} uruf-i-yem. | \gls I thing see-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I see.' (=I see something, or: I can see.)
Content 4: \gll (Yo) uruf-i-yem. | \gls I see-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I see him/her/it.'

Knowledge Point: The language-specific characteristic of syntactic transitivity \citep[49--51]{Kittila2002} is illustrated by a number of verbs that are transitive in Mauwake but intransitive in English: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aner-} `aim (at), refer (to)' \REF{ex:3:x302}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikum-} `wonder (about)' \REF{ex:3:x303}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kerew-} `be angry (at)'.
Content 1: \gll Wi wia amukar-emi me nefa \textbf{aner-a-m}. | \gls 3p.UNM 3p.ACC scold-SS.SIM not 2s.ACC refer.to-PA-1s | \glt `When I scolded them I didn't refer to you.'
Content 2: \gll Nefa \textbf{ikum-am-ika-iwkin} nan kerer-e-n. | \gls 2s.ACC wonder.about-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS there arrive-PA-2s | \glt `As they were wondering about you, you arrived there.'

Knowledge Point: There are a few verbs that require an undergoer object, but usually have recipient object as well. The verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ofakow}- `show, teach' \REF{ex:3:x1838} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- `tell' \REF{ex:3:x943} are the most common of these.\footnote{The verb `send' is cross-linguistically typically ditransitive, but in Mauwake it requires the benefactive suffix in order to be able to take a second object.}
Content 1: \gll Tunde urera Liisa ame=ke \textbf{epa}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{yia}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{ofakowa-y}\textbf{i}\textbf{aw}\textbf{-}\textbf{e}\textbf{-}\textbf{mik}. | \gls Tuesday afternoon Liisa ASSOC=CF place 1p.ACC show-move.around-PA-1/3p | \glt `On Tuesday afternoon Liisa and the othes showed us around the place.'
Content 2: \gll Nena panewowa pun \textbf{wadol} \textbf{opora}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{yia}\textsubscript{O} \textbf{maak-i-n.} | \gls 2s.GEN old also lie talk 1p.ACC tell-Np-PR.2s | \glt `You yourself -- an old person too! -- tell us lies.'

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wu}- `put' requires both an undergoer object and a locative adverbial \REF{ex:3:x1837}:
Content 1: \gll Sosora nain\textsubscript{O} pona=pa\textsubscript{AdvP} wu-a-mik. | \gls grass.skirt that1 riverbank=LOC put-PA-1/3p | \glt `They put those grass skirts on the riverbank.'

Knowledge Point: The directional verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) could be treated as weakly transitive, in which case the goal \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, which is never marked with the locative clitic -pa, could be a locative object. There are two main reasons against this analysis. When the goal of a directional verb is a personal pronoun, the dative case is used rather than the accusative \REF{ex:3:x1870}.
Content 1: \gll {\dots}ona wiawi \textbf{wiar} ikiw-o-k. | \gls 3s.GEN 3s/p.father 3.DAT go-PA-3s | \glt `{\dots}she went to her father.'

Knowledge Point: Also, if the directional verbs were considered weakly transitive and the the goal a locative object, the locative adverb nan `there' in the following clauses would be treated as a locative adverb in \REF{ex:3:x1871} but as a locative object in \REF{ex:3:x1872}:
Content 1: \gll Kerer-ep \textbf{nan} soomare-miaw-e-mik. | \gls arrive-SS.SEQ there walk-move.around-PA-1/3p | \glt `They arrived and walked around there.'
Content 2: \gll Or-op \textbf{nan} ikiw-ep wia uruf-a-k. | \gls descend-SS.SEQ there go-SS.SEQ 3p.ACC see-PA-3s | \glt `He went down and went there and saw them.'

Knowledge Point: Although most verb roots in Mauwake are clearly transitive or intransitive, there are a few that are ambitransitive \REF{ex:3:x1827}--\REF{ex:3:x1060}. Many of their English equivalents would be intransitive. Only the following roots have been found to be neutral with regard to transitivity (\tabref{tab:3:ambitransitives}). Of them \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ofof}- and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{taan}- are of the S=O type, where the intransitive subject is an undergoer; the others are of the S=A type, where the intransitive subject is an actor \citep[124]{Dixon2010b}.
Content 1: \gll Ifar(a) makena wulewul \textbf{ofof-i-ya}. | \gls vine fruit wulewul shake-Np-PR.3s | \glt `The vine fruit (called) \textstyleForeignWords{wulewul} shakes.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Efa} \textbf{om-em-ik-eya} epa wiim-o-k. | \gls 1s.ACC cry-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS place dawn-PA-3s | \glt `While she was mourning for me it dawned.'

Knowledge Point: The subject of the adjunct plus verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek er}- `be enough, suffice' is typically inanimate \REF{ex:3:x1058}, whereas the object, when there is one, is usually human \REF{ex:3:x306}.
Content 1: \gll Kemuka nain \textbf{pepek} \textbf{er-eya} onak ona wiar puuk-a-k. | \gls string that1 enough go-2/3s.DS 3s/p.mother 3s.GEN 3.DAT cut-PA-3s | \glt `When the string was (long) enough, their mother herself cut it.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wia} \textbf{pepek} \textbf{er-a-k}. | \gls 3p.ACC enough come/go-PA-3s | \glt `It was enough for them.'

Knowledge Point: I call these verbs object cross-referencing because, besides marking the subject with a suffix like all other verbs do, they also \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{obligatorily}} mark the object in the verb root. What has clearly been a prefix\footnote{Phonetically this prefix is closer to the unmarked pronouns than the accusative pronouns.} earlier has been grammaticalized as part of the verb itself: there is no neutral root that would not be linked to any particular person \REF{ex:3:x334}--\REF{ex:3:x336}.\footnote{When a ``neutral'' form is required, the third person singular is used.} In this respect these verbs differ from all the other verbs in Mauwake. In the case of `give' the verb root \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i}- has assimilated into the prefix, so currently the person marking of the recipient object is the only root that there is. Four of the object cross-referencing verbs are listed in \tabref{tab:3:crossreferencingverbs}.
Content 1: \gll Maa fain me \textbf{iw}-o-k. | \gls thing this not give.him/her-PA-3s | \glt `He did not give this thing to him/her.'
Content 2: \gll Amia=iya \textbf{nenar}-e-mik=i? | \gls bow=COM shoot.you-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt `Did they shoot you with a gun?'

Knowledge Point: The cross-referenced objects are semantically quite different. In the verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw}- `give (him)' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{onak}- `feed (him)' it is the recipient,\footnote{\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{onak-} `feed (him)' requires a food term as the undergoer object, so a better translation, but longer, would be `give him (something) to eat'.} in \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{war}- `shoot (him)' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ook}- `follow (him)' the undergoer. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wionar}-\footnote{A possible origin for this is \textit{\textsc{pron}+onaiya+ar}- `become together-with \textsc{pron}' (Kwan, p.c.)} `hide among (them)' is a special case in two ways: the cross-referenced argument `among a group' is quite untypical as a verbal argument; and only plural forms of this verb can be used because of semantic restrictions: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yionar-} `hide among us', \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nionar-} `hide among you (pl)', \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wionar-} `hide among them' \REF{ex:3:x337}.
Content 1: \gll Wi \textbf{wionar}-ep pok-ap ik-ua. | \gls 3p.UNM hide.among.them-SS.SEQ sit.down-SS.SEQ be-PA.3s | \glt `He sat hiding among them.'

Knowledge Point: Unlike Usan, in Mauwake the clauses with object cross-referencing verbs can easily have a locative or instrument phrase, and the verb itself can take a benefactive suffix. A sentence like \REF{ex:3:x338} would be possible for instance when sending money to people travelling in the same vehicle as the addressee.
Content 1: \gll Miiw-aasa=pa \textbf{wi-om}-\textbf{e}. | \gls land-canoe=LOC give.them-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s | \glt `Give it to them for me in the car.'

Knowledge Point: The causative always increases the number of arguments a verb can take: the subject of an intransitive verb \REF{ex:3:x997} becomes the object of a transitive verb \REF{ex:3:x998}, and a new subject is added. The causative suffix -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ow} was described above in \sectref{sec:3.8.2.3.1}. In most cases the meaning of a causative is `to cause someone or something to do something'. The caused `doing' is usually \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not} }agentive \REF{ex:3:x992}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Eka napia\textsubscript{O} koor miira=pa iimar-\textbf{ow}-a-mik. | \gls water bamboo house face=LOC stand-CAUS-PA-1/3p | \glt `We made the bamboo water containers stand in front of the house.'
Content 3: \gll Wiowa erup\textsubscript{O} ar-\textbf{ow}-amkun um-o-k. | \gls spear two become-CAUS-1s/p.DS die-PA-3s | \glt `I speared it a second time and it (=the pig) died.' (Lit: `I caused a spear to become two and it died.')

Knowledge Point: The mental state of being angry is expressed via a verb in Mauwake \REF{ex:3:x993}, and it can take the causative suffix \REF{ex:3:x994}.
Content 1: \gll Kema bagiwir-a-m. | \gls liver be.angry-PA-1s | \glt `I was angry.'
Content 2: \gll Yo kema efa\textsubscript{O} bagiwir-\textbf{ow}-a-n, yaa! | \gls 1s.UNM liver 1s.ACC be.angry-CAUS-PA-2s INTJ | \glt `Boy, have you made me angry!'

Knowledge Point: In some cases the causative suffix acts simply as a transitivizer. The subject in \REF{ex:3:x995} does not actually cause the children to grow. Also in this case the suffix increases the valency of the verb: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{arim}- `grow' in \REF{ex:3:x996} is intransitive, but \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{arimow}- in \REF{ex:3:x995} is transitive and takes an object.
Content 1: \gll Aakisa arim-o-n, aakisa muew-o-n. | \gls now grow-PA-2s now marry-PA-2s | \glt `Now you have grown, now you have married.'
Content 2: \gll No nena maa fariar-ep muuka nain\textsubscript{O} arim-\textbf{ow}-e. | \gls 2s.UNM 2s.GEN food abstain-SS.SEQ son that1 grow-CAUS-IMP.2s | \glt `You yourself have to abstain from (certain) food(s) and bring the son up.'
Content 3: \gll Aakisa arim-o-n, aakisa muew-o-n. | \gls now grow-PA-2s now marry-PA-2s | \glt `Now you have grown, now you have married.'

Knowledge Point: When the causative suffix is added to the intransitive verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sail}- `(tell a) lie', its meaning changes into `lie to someone', `cheat' \REF{ex:3:x448}.
Content 1: \gll Opor(a) makena ma-i-yem, me nia\textsubscript{O} sail-\textbf{ow}-iyem. | \gls talk true say-Np-PR.1s not 2p.ACC lie-CAUS-PR.1s | \glt `I am telling the truth, I am not cheating you.'

Knowledge Point: Bring-prefixes (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.4.2}) are another causative strategy, used only with the directional verbs \REF{ex:3:x999}, \REF{ex:3:x1001} (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}) and a couple of other motion verbs \REF{ex:3:x1000}. The subject of the verb causes the object to move by undertaking the transfer himself/herself.
Content 1: \gll Maa unowa ifer aasa=ke \textbf{p}-urup-o-k. | \gls thing many sea canoe=CF BPX-ascend-PA-3s | \glt `A lot of things were brought/taken up by ships.'
Content 2: \gll O mua imen-ap=na feeke wia \textbf{p}-ekap-eka. | \gls 3s.UNM man find-SS.SEQ=TP here.CF 3p.ACC BPX-come-IMP.2p | \glt `If/when you find a/any man, bring them/him here.'
Content 3: \gll Gomi kawus \textbf{p}-irapar-i-ya. | \gls east.wind smoke BPX-move.to.and.fro-Np-PR.3s | \glt `The east wind moves the smoke around.'

Knowledge Point: Forming a causative from an agentive verb (\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{inducive causative}}, \citealt[112]{Talmy2007}) is not done morphologically with an affix but \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{syntactically}} with a verbal construction involving the nominalized form of the main verb and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{suuw}- `push' as the causative auxiliary \REF{ex:3:x1003}, \REF{ex:3:x1002} (\sectref{sec:5.7.1}).
Content 1: \gll O uruf-ap op-ap Yeesus nomokowa moke \textbf{akua-aaw-om-owa} \textbf{suuw-a-mik}. | \gls 3s.UNM see-SS.SEQ hold-SS.SEQ Jesus tree slanting shoulder-take-BEN-NMZ push-PA-1/3p | \glt `They saw him and took hold of him, and made him carry Jesus' cross on his shoulder.'
Content 2: \gll Sira enuma \textbf{ook-owa} \textbf{nia} \textbf{suuw-i-mik}. | \gls custom new follow-NMZ 2p.ACC push-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They make you follow new customs/ways.'

Knowledge Point: In the following examples the three different causative strategies have been applied to the same verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `go', and in all of them the patient is [+human]. In \REF{ex:3:x1016} and \REF{ex:3:x1829} the object of the causative verb has no influence on what happens to him/her, but in \REF{ex:3:x1873} the object of the inducive causative is active and becomes the actor of the verb resulting from the causation.
Content 1: \gll Ipamsika mua=ke \textbf{ikiw-ow}\textbf{-a-k}. | \gls nail man=CF go-CAUS-PA-3s | \glt `A sorcerer (lit: nail man) killed him (lit: caused him to go).'
Content 2: \gll Kes tepak=pa wu-ap \textbf{p-ikiw-e-mik}. | \gls coffin inside=LOC put-SS.SEQ BPX-go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They put him inside the coffin and took him (away).'
Content 3: \gll Yo mua oko \textbf{ikiw-owa} \textbf{suuw-amkun} ikiw-i-non. | \gls 1s.UNM man other go-NMZ push-1s/p.DS go-Np-FU.3s | \glt `I make a man go and he goes.'

Knowledge Point: The benefactive form of a verb (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.3.3}) is used when an action is done \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{for} }someone, for their benefit \REF{ex:3:x1004}, or in some cases for their detriment \REF{ex:3:x1005}. With the addition of the benefactive suffix to the verb, the beneficiary becomes an obligatory argument. The beneficiary is always animate, and usually human.
Content 1: \gll Wi owow mua=ke wilkar wia muf-em-ik-\textbf{om}-a-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM village man=CF cart 3p.ACC pull-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `The village men kept pulling carts for them.'
Content 2: \gll Epia wilin-owa uruf-ap bom yia fuurk-\textbf{om}-i-kuan. | \gls fire(wood) shine-NMZ see-SS.SEQ bomb 1p.ACC throw-BEN-Np-FU.3p | \glt `When they see the light from the fire(s), they will throw bombs at us.'

Knowledge Point: More than one valency-increasing strategy can be applied to a verb simultaneously. In both \REF{ex:3:x1007} and \REF{ex:3:x1008} the valency of the verb increases from one to three: besides the subject of the original verb, the derived verbs also have both an object and a beneficiary.
Content 1: \gll Koor poka iimar-\textbf{ow}-\textbf{om}-e. | \gls house post stand.up-CAUS-BEN-BNFY1.IMP.2s | \glt `Stand up the house posts for me.'
Content 2: \gll Ona soomia marew-eya \textbf{amap}-ep-\textbf{om}-a-m. | \gls 3s.GEN spoon no(ne)-2/3s.DS BPX-come-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1s | \glt `She has/had no spoons of her own, so I brought them for her.'

Knowledge Point: There are no morphological means in Mauwake for decreasing syntactic valence. A verb that is inherently reflexive, like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yaki}- `wash oneself', is intransitive. But the semantic valence of transitive verbs is decreased when they are made either reflexive \REF{ex:3:x1834} or reciprocal \REF{ex:3:x1835} . Syntactically the reflexive/reciprocal pronoun is an object, but the pronoun refers to the same referent(s) as the subject.
Content 1: \gll Birin-ep nomokowa iinan akena ikiw-ep wame pipilim-ep aakun-em-ika-i-non. | \gls fly-SS.SEQ tree top very go-SS.SEQ 3s.REFL hide-SS.SEQ speak-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.3s | \glt `It will fly and hide (itself) in the very top of a tree and keep making noise.'
Content 2: \gll Osaiwa aalbok ikos uf-owa na-ep ofa wiam if-e-mik. | \gls bird.of.paradise black.cuckoo-shrike together dance-NMZ say-SS.SEQ colour 3p.REFL paint-PA-1/3p | \glt `A bird of paradise and a black cuckoo-shrike wanted to dance together and painted each other with colour.'

Knowledge Point: A common valence-decreasing device in many languages is the passive voice, which demotes or deletes the subject. In Mauwake verbs there is no passive voice. The standard way of demoting the subject is to have the verb in third person plural form and leave the subject \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} unexpressed \REF{ex:3:x1009}, \REF{ex:3:x1010} .\footnote{Cf. the English impersonal ``they'': They say it is going to be cold tomorrow.} None of the arguments change their syntactic function. The example \REF{ex:3:x1009} comes from a story where the main point was that the people responsible for the fire were never found, and it was not known if only one person was involved or many.
Content 1: \gll Fikera ikum \textbf{kuum-e-mik} nain ma-i-yem. | \gls kunai.grass illicitly burn-PA-1/3p that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I tell about when the kunai grass was burned (by arson).'
Content 2: \gll Nefa \textbf{war-iwkin} naap ma-e. | \gls 2s.ACC shoot-2/3p.DS thus say-IMP.2s | \glt `If/when you are shot, then say like that.' (Or: `If they shoot you, then say like that.')
Content 3: \gll Fikera ikum \textbf{kuum-e-mik} nain ma-i-yem. | \gls kunai.grass illicitly burn-PA-1/3p that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I tell about when the kunai grass was burned (by arson).'

Knowledge Point: Another strategy to demote the subject is to use the same-subject sequential form of the main verb and the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' agreeing with the object of the verb \REF{ex:3:x1011} . This can only be used when the end result is a state.
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa puuk-ap ik-ua. | \gls tree cut-SS.SEQ be-PA.3s | \glt `The tree is cut.'

Knowledge Point: The basic meaning of the stative verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}(\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a})- is `be'. The vowel /a/ gets deleted elsewhere except in the present tense and the medial different-subject non-first plural form; in the corresponding singular form the vowel may be optionally deleted \REF{ex:3:x257}.
Content 1: \gll Nan mukuna=pa \textbf{ik(a)-eya} o nan samor aaw-o-k. | \gls there fire=LOC be-2/3s.DS 3s.UNM there badly get-PA-3s | \glt `They (=bananas) were there on the fire and he really got bad there.'

Knowledge Point: Like intransitive verbs, it may form a complete clause by itself. Example \REF{ex:3:x1455} is from a situation where the speaker was in a plane for the first time, refused to eat and declined any help offered to him.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ika-i-nen}. | \gls be-Np-FU.1s | \glt `I will just be (like this).'

Knowledge Point: Often it is used for `be/live (somewhere)', and in this use it naturally co-occurs with a locative adverbial \REF{ex:3:x497}:
Content 1: \gll I naap koora=pa \textbf{ik-e-mik}. | \gls 1p.UNM thus house=LOC be-PA-1/3p | \glt `We were in the house like that.'

Knowledge Point: Together with the dative pronouns \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- is used to form possessive constructions \REF{ex:3:x258} (\sectref{sec:3.5.5}, \ref{sec:5.5.2}).
Content 1: \gll Yo waaya arow \textbf{efar} \textbf{ik-ua.} | \gls 1s.UNM pig three 1s.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `I have three pigs.'

Knowledge Point: The function of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- as a copular verb is very restricted. In equative or descriptive clauses it is normally not used in the present tense finite form, but in the past \REF{ex:3:x259} and future \REF{ex:3:x1070} tenses it is employed. It could be said, following \citet[92]{Givon1984}, that in these clauses its primary function is to be the carrier of the tense.
Content 1: \gll Yo um-ep ik-owa saarik \textbf{ik-e-m}. | \gls 1s.UNM die-SS.SEQ be-NMZ like be-PA-1s | \glt `I was like dead.'
Content 2: \gll Ikoka maa marew, eliw manek=iw \textbf{ika-i-nan}. | \gls later thing none well big=LIM be-Np-FU.2s | \glt `Later there will be no problem, you will just be very well.'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake it can also be used when the non-verbal predicate is understood to be transitory \REF{ex:3:x499} rather than stable over time:
Content 1: \gll No kamenap \textbf{ika-i-n}? | \gls 2s.UNM how be-Np-PR.2s | \glt `How are you?'

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' is in a class of its own for several reasons. Its morphology is irregular, and so are the semantics of some of its morphology. In \REF{ex:3:x258} the past tense and the person/number marker in the third person singular form are merged into one portmanteau morpheme. An alternative form for the different-subject first person form \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikemkun} is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikomkun} \REF{ex:3:x1931}. The same-subject medial form is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikok} \REF{ex:3:x260}, not *\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikep} and *\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikemi}\textstyleEmphasizedVernacularWords{\textmd{.}}\footnote{\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ikep} and \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ikemi} are the same subject medial forms of the homophonous verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ik-} `roast'.} There is no formal differentiation between a simultaneous \REF{ex:3:x260} and a sequential \REF{ex:3:x262} form in the same-subject medial verb.
Content 1: \gll Yo waaya arow \textbf{efar} \textbf{ik-ua.} | \gls 1s.UNM pig three 1s.DAT be-PA.3s | \glt `I have three pigs.'
Content 2: \gll Siowa nain kakalt-am-\textbf{ik}\textbf{-}\textbf{emkun} arim-o-k. | \gls dog that1 look.after-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS grow-PA-3s | \glt `I was looking after the dog and it grew.'
Content 3: \gll Naap \textbf{ik-ok} uruf-am-ika-iwkin wia. | \gls thus be-SS see-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS no | \glt `As he was/stayed like that they were watching him (but) no (=he didn't get better).'
Content 4: \gll Naap \textbf{ik-ok} uruf-am-ika-iwkin wia. | \gls thus be-SS see-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS no | \glt `As he was/stayed like that they were watching him (but) no (=he didn't get better).'
Content 5: \gll Owowa ekap-o-k, amia mua=pa \textbf{ik-ok}. | \gls village come-PA-3s bow man=LOC be-SS | \glt `He came to the village, having been in the police (force).'

Knowledge Point: It also differs from ordinary intransitive verbs in that in a verb+auxiliary construction it cannot be the main verb, but can be used as the aspectual auxiliary \REF{ex:3:x1931} (see also \sectref{sec:3.8.4.5}). But it is like other intransitive verbs in that it can take an causative suffix \REF{ex:3:x261}.\footnote{\citet[142]{Reesink1987} notes that in Usan the corresponding verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{igo} `be' cannot occur with the causative suffix. In Mauwake there is no similar restriction.}
Content 1: \gll Siowa nain kakalt-am-\textbf{ik}\textbf{-}\textbf{emkun} arim-o-k. | \gls dog that1 look.after-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS grow-PA-3s | \glt `I was looking after the dog and it grew.'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa war-ep miiwa=pa \textbf{ik-ow-a-mik.} | \gls tree cut-SS.SEQ ground=LOC be-CAUS-PA-1/3p | \glt `We cut trees and laid them on the ground'

Knowledge Point: The tense distinction is partly neutralized: the past tense form is used for past \REF{ex:3:x263} and present \REF{ex:3:x264}. The present tense form is not very common and is mainly used for less time-stable situations \REF{ex:3:x499}, \REF{ex:3:x1028}, or to replace the missing continuous aspect form \REF{ex:3:x265}. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- is used as the regular continuous aspect auxiliary (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1.2}), and as a main verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' cannot take this auxiliary.
Content 1: \gll Yo unan koka=pa \textbf{ik-e-m}. | \gls 1s.UNM yesterday jungle=LOC be-PA-1s | \glt `Yesterday I was in the jungle.'
Content 2: \gll Ni kaaneke \textbf{ik-e-man} oo, ni ekap-omak-eka oo! | \gls 2p.UNM where be-PA-2p oh 2p.UNM come-DISTR-IMP.2p oh | \glt `Wherever you are, come!'
Content 3: \gll No kamenap \textbf{ika-i-n}? | \gls 2s.UNM how be-Np-PR.2s | \glt `How are you?'
Content 4: \gll Mesa asia fiker gone=pa \textbf{ika-i-ya} nain aaw-em-ik-e-m. | \gls winged.bean wild kunai.grass middle=LOC be-Np-PR.3s that1 take-SS.SIM-be-PA-1s | \glt `I was picking wild winged bean that was (lit: is) in the middle of the kunai grass.'

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- mainly functions in intransitive clauses, but it is also needed as a copula for those cases where a non-verbal predicate is in a non-present tense \REF{ex:3:x969} .
Content 1: \gll O ikoka somek mua maneka \textbf{ika-i-non}. | \gls 3p.UNM later song man big be-Np-FU.3s | \glt `He will later be the headmaster.'

Knowledge Point: An equative or descriptive medial clause requires \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- as a copula regardless of the tense of the final verb \REF{ex:3:x498}.
Content 1: \gll Koora naap \textbf{ik-eya} uruf-i-mik. | \gls house thus be-2/3s.DS see-Np-PR.1p | \glt `We see the house as it is like that.'

Knowledge Point: The three position-taking verbs are among the most frequently used verbs in Mauwake: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pok}- `sit down', \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iimar}- `stand up' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{in}- `lie down/ fall asleep'. They are essentially punctiliar verbs with an inceptive meaning \REF{ex:3:x273}, but they are most typically used in the same-subject sequential form together with the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.5}) to convey stative meaning: `sit' \REF{ex:3:x274}, `stand', and `lie/sleep'.
Content 1: \gll Kokom-ar-eya \textbf{in-e-mik}. | \gls darkness-INCH-2/3s.DS lie.down-PA-1/3p | \glt `When it got dark we went to bed.'
Content 2: \gll Ona koora=pa arew-ap \textbf{pok-ap} \textbf{ik-e-mik}. | \gls 3s.GEN house=LOC wait-SS.SEQ sit.down-SS.SEQ be-PA-1/3p | \glt `We sat and waited (lit: waited and sat) in his house.'

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pok}- is occasionally used even without the auxiliary to mean `sit' \REF{ex:3:x1824}.
Content 1: \gll Neek(e) \textbf{pok-aka}. | \gls there sit-IMP.2p | \glt `Sit there/Keep sitting there.' (Commonly used as a conversational ``filler'' for people that are already sitting, when there is a lull in the conversation.)

Knowledge Point: The continuous aspect form of the position-taking verbs is not used with progressive meaning, only with the meaning `habitual' \REF{ex:3:x275} (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1}).
Content 1: \gll Irak-ow epa=pa koka=pa \textbf{in-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls fight-NMZ time=LOC jungle=LOC lie.down-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `During the war we used to sleep in the jungle.'

Knowledge Point: The two verbs that have been verbalized from the demonstrative adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{fan} `here' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nan} `there' (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.2.1}), are very restricted in their use. The original meaning of the verbs must refer to arrival at some place, but since they are only used in the past tense, they currently tend to indicate presence at a place rather than movement \REF{ex:3:x1270}--\REF{ex:3:x1272}.\footnote{This may indicate that the past tense used to encode perfectivity (Malcolm Ross, p.c.)} They can even be used with immobile objects \REF{ex:3:x1276}.
Content 1: \gll No ikiw-e, irak-owa maneka \textbf{fan}\textbf{-}\textbf{e}\textbf{-}\textbf{k} a. | \gls 2s.UNM go-IMP.2s fight-NMZ big here-PA-3s INTJ | \glt `Go (home), the big war is here.'
Content 2: \gll No niawi akena \textbf{nan-e-k}. | \gls 2s.UNM 2s/p.father true there-PA-3s | \glt `Your real father is there.'
Content 3: \gll Aa, o koora \textbf{fan-e-k} a. | \gls INTJ 3s.UNM house here-PA-3s INTJ | \glt `Ah, his house is here.'

Knowledge Point: The resultative verbs with the meaning `become' are another small group of intransitive verbs. Besides the semantic similarity they also share the syntactic characteristic that, in addition to the subject, they require another argument expressing the result of change. This other obligatory argument is a noun with the verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar}- `become' \REF{ex:3:x276}, \REF{ex:3:x277} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{puuk}- `change into' \REF{ex:3:x278},\footnote{This verb is homonymous with the transitive verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{puuk-} `cut'. They may be historically related, but synchronically the meanings are quite different.} and a colour adjective with the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kir}- `turn' \REF{ex:3:x279}.
Content 1: \gll Takira arim-ep mua \textbf{ar-e-k}. | \gls boy grow-SS.SEQ man become-PA-3s | \glt `The boy grew and became a man.'
Content 2: \gll Emeria nain afa \textbf{ar-e-mik}. | \gls woman that1 flyng.fox become-PA-1/3p | \glt `Those women became flying foxes.'
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar}- is mostly used when the subject stays essentially the same but undergoes some change \REF{ex:3:x276}. However, it can also be used when the subject changes into something else \REF{ex:3:x277}. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{puuk}- is only used in the latter context \REF{ex:3:x278}, and it is always an intentional action. It is most common in traditional stories where spirits change into various inanimate things or animate beings. The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kir}- is used with most colour terms \REF{ex:3:x279}, but for `black' there is a separate verb formed with the inchoative suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ar} : \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{sepenar}-\footnote{This is related to the adjective \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{sepa} `black'.} `become black'. The inchoative suffix (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.2.2}) is the standard device used for verbalizing adjectives.
Content 1: \gll Takira arim-ep mua \textbf{ar-e-k}. | \gls boy grow-SS.SEQ man become-PA-3s | \glt `The boy grew and became a man.'
Content 2: \gll Emeria nain afa \textbf{ar-e-mik}. | \gls woman that1 flyng.fox become-PA-1/3p | \glt `Those women became flying foxes.'
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verbs indicating coming and going are among the most frequent verbs in Mauwake. These verbs have the direction inherent in the verb root. Verbs of this kind are quite common among Papuan languages: in some languages the directional is an affix, in others it is part of the meaning of the root itself \citep[149]{Foley1986}; Mauwake is of the latter type. The directional verb group contains verbs that in many languages would be prototypically intransitive \REF{ex:3:x280}, \REF{ex:3:x281}. The directional verbs are listed in \tabref{tab:3:directionals}.
Content 1: \gll Manina \textbf{urup-ep} nan uuw-ap owowa \textbf{or-o-k}. | \gls garden ascend-SS.SEQ there work-SS.SEQ village descend-PA-3s | \glt `She went up to the garden, worked there and came down to the village.'
Content 2: \gll Fofa \textbf{er-ap} \textbf{ir-i-mik}. | \gls market go-SS.SEQ come-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We are coming back from the market.' (Lit: `We went west to the market and are coming east.')

Knowledge Point: The deictic orientation of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `away from speaker/deictic centre' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ekap}- `towards the speaker/deictic centre' is stricter in Mauwake than in many European languages where the deictic centre especially for `come' can vary considerably. The sentence \REF{ex:3:x282} is all right in Finnish regardless of the location of the speaker, but the corresponding sentence in Mauwake would be acceptable only if the speaker were in Tampere at the time of speaking.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The equivalent of the English `come' in \REF{ex:3:x283} has to be `go' in Mauwake \REF{ex:3:x284}. This is discussed further in (\sectref{sec:6.3}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Uurika nefa uruf-owa \textbf{ikiw-i-nen}. | \gls tomorrow 2s.ACC see-NMZ go-Np-FU.1s | \glt `Tomorrow I'll go to see you.'

Knowledge Point: When these verbs occur with a locative phrase containing the locative marker (\sectref{sec:3.12.4}), the phrase almost always refers to either source \REF{ex:3:x285}, or location/path \REF{ex:3:x447}. The goal is very seldom marked with the locative marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa}; this happens when the goal is important mainly as the location of the next event \REF{ex:3:x1878}. Also, in \REF{ex:3:x1878} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mukuna} `fire' is an untypical goal for a directional verb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Manina}\textbf{=pa} \textbf{ekap-ep} maa uup-e-mik. | \gls garden=LOC come-SS.SEQ food cook-PA-1/3p | \glt `We came from the garden and cooked food.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: The directional verbs differ from other verbs in Mauwake in that they can be transitivized with the bring-prefixes \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{p}- \REF{ex:3:x286}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{amap}- and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aap}- (\sectref{sec:3.8.2.4.2}) to indicate either bringing or taking something somewhere.
Content 1: \gll Ona owowa \textbf{p-ikiw-ep} soop-i-yan. | \gls 3s.GEN village BPX-go-SS.SEQ bury-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We'll take him (=his body) in his village and bury him (there).'

Knowledge Point: The causative suffix \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ow}\textstyleEmphasizedWords{} (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.3.1})\textstyleEmphasizedWords{} can be added to the roots; when following a one-syllable root the suffix is often reduplicated \REF{ex:3:x435}, but the meaning is still the same as with a single causative suffix.
Content 1: \gll Purowa ir-\textbf{ow}-(\textbf{ow})-eya siin-ar-e-k. | \gls armband go.up-CAUS-CAUS-2/3s.DS tight-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `She pushed the armband up and it got tight.'

Knowledge Point: The directional verbs are very frequent as the second root in serial verbs \REF{ex:3:x287}\linebreak (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.2}) and as the main verb in verb plus auxiliary constructions \REF{ex:3:x288} (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.1.1}). Some of them also enter into adjunct plus verb constructions \REF{ex:3:x289} (\sectref{sec:3.8.5.2}).
Content 1: \gll Wi Amerika ``epa eliwa'' nae-\textbf{ekap}-e-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM America time good say-come-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Americans came saying, ``peace''.'
Content 2: \gll Wi Yaapan saa=iw \textbf{ir}-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls 3p.UNM Japan sand=INST go-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `The Japanese are going along the beach.'
Content 3: \gll Kemuka \textbf{pepek} \textbf{er-}eya puuk-a-k. | \gls string enough go-2/3s.DS cut-PA-3s | \glt `When the string was (long) enough she cut it.'

Knowledge Point: The meaning of the verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ekap}- `come' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikiw}- `go' can be metaphorically extended to time, to signal time spans. The former is used when the time span is extended from the past to the present \REF{ex:3:x290}, the latter is more common when the time extends from the present to the future \REF{ex:3:x437}, but it can also refer to the past \REF{ex:3:x291}.
Content 1: \gll Naap on-am-ik-e-mik, \textbf{ekap-ep} aakisa. | \gls thus do-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p come-SS.SEQ now | \glt `We have been doing like that (all the time) up until now.'
Content 2: \gll No naap ik-ok \textbf{iki(w-e)p} mokoma enuma iiwawun aakun-i-nan. | \gls 2s.UNM thus be-SS go-SS.SEQ year new altogether talk-Np-FU.2s | \glt `You will be like that (long time) but next year you will talk.'
Content 3: \gll Buren \textbf{ife-iki}\textbf{(}\textbf{w-e}\textbf{)}\textbf{p} aakisa arim-o-n. | \gls ceremonial.liquid rub-go-SS.SEQ now grow-PA-2s | \glt `You have kept rubbing the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{buren} liquid on (for years), and now you have grown up.'

Knowledge Point: On the fringe of directional verbs are \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kerer}- `arrive', \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yiaw}-/\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{miaw}- `walk/move around, wander' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{irapar}- `move back and forth (aimlessly)', which share some of their grammatical characteristics but not all of them. Of these three verbs, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kerer}- cannot be prefixed with the bring-prefixes, but it mainly occurs with an unmarked goal instead of a locative phrase \REF{ex:3:x292}.
Content 1: \gll Emeria mua manina \textbf{kerer-e-mik}. | \gls woman man garden arrive-PA-1/3p | \glt `The people arrived in the garden.'

Knowledge Point: With the other two, a bring-prefix is acceptable \REF{ex:3:x293}, but they do not take a goal/path argument. If a locative phrase occurs with them it requires a locative clitic \REF{ex:3:x436}.
Content 1: \gll Gomi kawus \textbf{p-irapar-i-ya}. | \gls east.wind smoke BPX-move.back.and.forth-Np-PR.3s | \glt `The east wind moves/blows the smoke around.'
Content 2: \gll Soora=pa nan \textbf{yiaw-e-mik}. | \gls jungle=LOC there walk.around-PA-1/3p | \glt `They walked around in the jungle.'

Knowledge Point: Utterance verbs may be either intransitive \REF{ex:3:x309}, ambitransitive \REF{ex:3:x310}, \REF{ex:3:x1927}, or transitive \REF{ex:3:x311}. They may be used to introduce a quote complement, but not to close it. They often occur with one of the `saying' verbs described below \REF{ex:3:x310}.
Content 1: \gll Takira niir-emi \textbf{kirir-i-mik}. | \gls boy play-SS.SIM shout-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `The boys are playing and shouting.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Maapora kamenap \textbf{aakun-i-yan}? | \gls feast how discuss-Np-FU.1p | \glt `How shall we discuss the feast?'
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- `tell' is used in the same two main senses as its English equivalent: telling someone \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{about}} something \REF{ex:3:x312} and telling someone \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{to do}} something \REF{ex:3:x313}. In direct quote formulas it is used mainly preceding a quote \REF{ex:3:x314}, not directly following it as a short closing formula. It is not used in indirect quotes at all.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Moma yia \textbf{maak-i-mik}. | \gls taro 1p.ACC tell-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are telling us (to get them) taro roots.'
Content 3: \gll Efa \textbf{maak-ek}, ``Opora tep=pa wu-e.'' | \gls 1s.ACC tell-PA-3s talk tape.recorder=LOC put-IMP.2s | \glt `She told me, ``Put the talk on a tape recorder.'' '

Knowledge Point: When \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- closes a direct quote, it requires the manner adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus' to precede it \REF{ex:3:x315}:
Content 1: \gll ``Aaw-ep p-ekap-eka,'' \textbf{naap} yia \textbf{maak-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls get-SS.SEQ BPX-come-IMP.2p thus 1p.ACC tell-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt ` ``Bring it'', they were telling us like that.'

Knowledge Point: The default object for \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- is the addressee \REF{ex:3:x314} and a possible second object is the speech itself \REF{ex:3:x316}.
Content 1: \gll Efa \textbf{maak-ek}, ``Opora tep=pa wu-e.'' | \gls 1s.ACC tell-PA-3s talk tape.recorder=LOC put-IMP.2s | \glt `She told me, ``Put the talk on a tape recorder.'' '
Content 2: \gll Wadol opora\textsubscript{O} yia\textsubscript{O} \textbf{maak-i-n}. | \gls lie talk 1p.ACC tell-Np-PR.2s | \glt `You are telling us lies.'

Knowledge Point: The status of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naak}- is unclear. It is infrequent, and in natural texts only occurs in closing formulas \REF{ex:3:x317}. It may have developed as an analogy to the verb pair \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ma}-/\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}-.
Content 1: \gll ``No bom fain=iw mera kuum-e,'' \textbf{naak-e-mik}. | \gls 2s.UNM bomb this=INST fish burn-IMP.2s tell-PA-1/3p | \glt ` ``Blast fish with this bomb,'' they told him.'

Knowledge Point: With the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ma}- `say/speak/tell' the addressee is not in focus, and is hardly ever even mentioned. Instead, the verb requires either an object referring to the speech content \REF{ex:3:x318} or an adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus' \REF{ex:3:x319} preceding the verb, or a quote complement following it \REF{ex:3:x320}.
Content 1: \gll Yo yena yaaya ifa ku-o-k nain opora \textbf{ma-i-yem.} | \gls 1s.UNM 1s.GEN 1s/p.uncle snake bite-PA-3s that1 talk say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am telling a story about my uncle that was bitten by a snake.'
Content 2: \gll Momora, no naap me \textbf{ma-e.} | \gls Fool 2s.UNM thus not say-IMP.2s | \glt `Fool, don't say like that.'
Content 3: \gll En-e-mik na{\upshape\footnotemark} \textbf{ma-e-mik}, ``Eliwa, aara oposia saarik.'' | \gls eat-PA-1/3p ADD say-PA-1/3p good hen meat like | \glt `They ate it and said, ``It is good, like chicken meat.'' '

Knowledge Point: Occasionally the verb can occur without any of the above objects \REF{ex:3:x321}:
Content 1: \gll Yena oram \textbf{ma-i-yem}. | \gls 1s.GEN just say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I'm just speaking (without any reason ).'

Knowledge Point: The difference between the verbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ma}- in regard to the semantic role of a person object is shown clearly in \REF{ex:3:x322}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say/speak/call/think' is the most interesting of the speech verbs. In quote formulas it is only used for closing the quote, with \REF{ex:3:x323} or without another utterance verb \REF{ex:3:x942} in an opening formula.
Content 1: \gll {\dots}\textbf{ma-em-ik-e-mik}, ``Oo, {\dots}'' \textbf{na-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls ...say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p oh ... say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `...they kept saying, ``Oh...'', they kept saying (like that).'
Content 2: \gll Amerika fan ``Epa eliwa'' \textbf{nae-ekap-e-mik}. | \gls America here time good say-come-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Americans came saying ``peace''.'

Knowledge Point: In a tail-head type construction (\sectref{sec:8.2.3.5}) it is often used as a generic verb to replace another utterance verb, when normally the first verb would be repeated \REF{ex:3:x324}.\footnote{Other types of verbs, when not repeated in a tail-head construction, are replaced with the generic verb \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{on-} `do'.}
Content 1: \gll Wia \textbf{maak-e-mik}, ``Yia uf-om-aka.'' \textbf{Na-iwkin}{\dots} | \gls 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p 1p.ACC dance-BEN-BNFY2.IMP.2p say-2/3p.DS | \glt `They told them, ``Dance for us.'' When they said (that){\dots}'

Knowledge Point: When \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- replaces another utterance verb in that way, the replaced verb may influence what semantic argument becomes the object. In \REF{ex:3:x325} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maak}- requires the addressee of the verb as the default object, and in the following sentence with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- the same accusative pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} still refers to the addressees, even if with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- it would normally refer to the people spoken about.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- is also used in a somewhat different sense `call (by some name)'. In \REF{ex:3:x326} the speaker tells that the word used by the Japanese soldiers for `coconut' was \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yasi}, a foreign word for her.\footnote{The verb unuf- is used when the calling by name or giving a name is emphasized.}
Content 1: \gll Iwera ``yasi'' yia \textbf{na-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls coconut yasi 1p.ACC say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept calling coconut (by the name) ``yasi'' to us.'

Knowledge Point: The ``speaking'' expressed by \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- can also be internal speech, i.e., thinking \REF{ex:3:x327}. This characteristic is quite common to speech verbs in Papuan languages. When the thinking \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{process}} itself is more in focus, an adjunct plus verb construction \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kema} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{suuw}- `think' (literally: `push the liver') is used.
Content 1: \gll Maa eliwa=ke \textbf{na-ep} aaw-e-m. | \gls thing good=CF say-SS.SEQ get-PA-1s | \glt `I thought it was a good thing and got it.'

Knowledge Point: Related to the inner speech is another usage typical of verbs for `saying' in Papuan languages: to convey desire , intention or plan \REF{ex:3:x328}--\REF{ex:3:x1608}. For this function only the same subject sequential form \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsxiiptItalic{naep} is used, and the verb that indicates the desired or intended action is in a preceding speech complement clause. This is discussed more fully in the section on complements of utterance verbs (\sectref{sec:8.3.2.1}).
Content 1: \gll Yo manina urup-i-nen \textbf{na-ep}. | \gls 1s.UNM garden ascend-Np-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ | \glt `I want to go to the garden.'
Content 2: \gll Ununa owowa p-or-owa \textbf{na-ep} maa eno-wa maneka on-i-kuan. | \gls slit.gong village BPX-descend-NMZ say-SS.SEQ food eat-NMZ big make-Np-FU.3p | \glt `When they want to take the slit gong down to the village they make a big feast.'

Knowledge Point: In this function naep is becoming less like a regular medial verb. It can occur in sentence-final position, without being right-dislocated \REF{ex:3:x328}. It usually does retain its word stress, but there is a tendency to un-stress and shorten it by dropping the vowel /a/ in speech \REF{ex:3:x1830}. When the verb in the speech complement clause is in the counterfactual form, all that is sometimes left of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na-ep} is only the suffix, which is then added as a suffix to the other verb \REF{ex:3:x1609}.
Content 1: \gll Yo manina urup-i-nen \textbf{na-ep}. | \gls 1s.UNM garden ascend-Np-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ | \glt `I want to go to the garden.'
Content 2: \gll Ifana wu-am-ika-i-kuan, unuma wia miim-u \textbf{n}\textbf{-}\textbf{ep}. | \gls ear put-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.3p name 3p.ACC hear-1d.IMP say-SS.SEQ | \glt `They\textsubscript{i} are listening carefully (lit: putting their ear), wanting to hear their\textsubscript{j} names.'
Content 3: \gll Yo aakisa nanar nain \textbf{ma-ek-a-m-{\O}-ep}. | \gls 1s.UNM now story that1 say-CNTF-PA-1s-{\O}-SS.SEQ | \glt `Now I would like to tell that story.'

Knowledge Point: The verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- quite freely combines with sound words \REF{ex:3:x330}, and a number of these combinations have been lexicalized \REF{ex:3:x331}, \REF{ex:3:x332}. The onomatopoeic word has become part of the verb, and the vowel /a/ has been deleted from the verb in the process.
Content 1: \gll Oro-mi \textbf{bulak} \textbf{na-i-ya}\textbf{\textmd{.}} | \gls drop-SS.SIM plop say-Np-PR.3s | \glt `When it drops it says ``plop''.'
Content 2: \gll Siowa \textbf{baun-i-ya}. ({{\textless}} bau na-i-ya) | \gls dog bark-Np-PR.3s ( bau say-Np-PR.3s) | \glt `The dog barks.'
Content 3: \gll Ema \textbf{buun-eya} mua erup um-e-mik. ({{\textless}} buu na-eya) | \gls mountain erupt-2/3s.DS man two die-PA-1/3p ( buu say-2/3s.DS) | \glt `The mountain (=volcano) erupted and two men died.'

Knowledge Point: In fast speech \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- is often reduced to \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a}- when the verb follows a consonant-final word \REF{ex:3:x333}.
Content 1: \gll ``Uruf-a-mik'' \textbf{a-e-k}. | \gls see-PA-1/3p say-PA-3s | \glt ` ``They saw it,'' he said.'

Knowledge Point: The medial form \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na-eya} is also used as resultative connective `so, therefore' \REF{ex:3:x500} (\sectref{sec:3.11.2}).
Content 1: \gll Iwera yia na-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Naeya} iwera wia uruk-am-ik-om-a-mik. | \gls coconut 1p.ACC say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p So coconut 3p.ACC drop-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept speaking to us about coconuts /asking us for coconuts. So we kept dropping coconuts for them.'

Knowledge Point: This very small group mainly consists of verbs indicating some kind of pain. They look like transitive verbs, but the syntactic subject is inanimate, usually a body part, and the human experiencer is the object \REF{ex:3:x1013}, \REF{ex:3:x1014} (\tabref{tab:3:impersonalexperience}).
Content 1: \gll Maara efa \textbf{tiitin-i-ya}. | \gls forehead 1s.ACC hurt-Np-PR.3s | \glt `My head hurts.'/ `I have a headache.' (Lit: `It hurts my forehead.')
Content 2: \gll Uuw-ap uuw-ap oona=ke efa \textbf{sirir-i-ya}. | \gls work-SS.SEQ work-SS.SEQ bone=CF 1s.ACC ache-Np-PR.3s | \glt `I have worked and worked, and my bones ache.'

Knowledge Point: The auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- is very frequent and has several functions. When it is used with a main verb in the same-subject simultaneous form (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{ss}.\textsc{sim}), it indicates continuous aspect, which can have either progressive \REF{ex:3:x339} or habitual \REF{ex:3:x340} meaning. For position-taking verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.2}) and other semantically punctiliar verbs the habitual interpretation is the only possible one, but for other verbs the context is needed to determine the correct interpretation.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: When the main verb is in the same-subject sequential form (\textstyleAcronymallcaps{\textsc{ss}.\textsc{seq}}), the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- indicates stativity \REF{ex:3:x341}. With non-punctiliar verbs this form can often be translated into English with a past perfect \REF{ex:3:x342}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pu}- `completive', is obviously derived from \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wu}- `put'\footnote{`Put' is one of the verbs commonly used in Papuan languages to indicate completion \citep[145]{Foley1986}.} through assimilation with the final /p/ of the same-subject sequential form in the main verb preceding it \REF{ex:3:x343}, \REF{ex:3:x501} . Synchronically, the Mauwake speakers do not recognise the origin of the auxiliary.
Content 1: \gll Maa en-ep-\textbf{pu}-ap soomar-eka. | \gls food eat-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ walk-IMP.2p | \glt `Having finished eating you may go.' (Lit: `Eat the food and go'.)
Content 2: \gll Nan efa wu-ap-\textbf{pu}-ami o Ulingan ikiw-o-k. | \gls there1 1s.ACC put-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SIM 3s.UNM Ulingan go-PA-3s | \glt `He left (lit: put) me there and went to Ulingan.'

Knowledge Point: The verbal clusters are described here under verb morphology, because they function as a unit very much like single verbs. There are two kinds of verbal clusters: verbal groups and adjunct plus verb constructions. The definition of a verbal group is from \citet[175]{Halliday1994}: ``a sequence of words in the primary class of verb'' \REF{ex:3:x347}.
Content 1: \gll Ifara \textbf{mokak-ikiw-em-ik-ok} ifara oko uruf-a-k. | \gls vine stare-go-SS.SIM-be-SS vine other see-PA-3s | \glt `He kept looking for a vine and saw one vine.'

Knowledge Point: Adjunct plus verb combinations\footnote{\citet[184]{Halliday1994} calls these ``phrasal verbs''.} contain a verb (or a verbal group) plus an element from another word class that is obligatory and contributes to the meaning of the verb \REF{ex:3:x348}.
Content 1: \gll Owora efar \textbf{ikum} \textbf{aaw-iwkin} wia maak-e-m. | \gls betelnut 1s.DAT illicitly get-2/3p.DS 3p.ACC tell-PA-1s | \glt `They stole my betelnut and I talked to them.'

Knowledge Point: When the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{completion}} of an action is in focus, the completive aspect is used. It is formed by a main verb in the same-subject sequential form, followed by the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pu}- `completive' \REF{ex:3:x361} (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.5}).
Content 1: \gll Ifakim-ep nomokow ekeka=pa \textbf{sererim-ep-pu-a-k}. | \gls kill-SS.SEQ tree branch=LOC hang-SS.SEQ-CMPL-PA-3s | \glt `He killed it and hung it on a tree branch.'

Knowledge Point: The completive aspect verb is often used in a medial same-subject sequential form, which in itself only indicates sequentiality but often implies completion of the first action as well \REF{ex:3:x362}--\REF{ex:3:x1042}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sererim-ep-pu-ap} owowa or-o-k. | \gls hang-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ village descend-PA-3s | \glt `He hung it up and went/came down to the village.'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa \textbf{war-ep-pu-ap} arew-i-mik. | \gls tree cut-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ wait-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We cut the trees and wait.'

Knowledge Point: But it is not uncommon either to have the completive aspect with a simultaneous action medial form, when the second action coincides with the completion of the first one \REF{ex:3:x363}--\REF{ex:3:x1043}.
Content 1: \gll Wia \textbf{maak-ep-pu-ami} i ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 3p.ACC tell-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SIM 1p.UNM go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We told them and went.'
Content 2: \gll Maa en-owa \textbf{wakesim-ep-pu-ami} ikiw-o-k. | \gls thing eat-NMZ cover-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SIM go-PA-3s | \glt `Covering the food she left.'

Knowledge Point: The completive aspect form is also used when \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{momentaneity}} of the action is emphasized \REF{ex:3:x364}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{En-ep-pu-ap} ikiw-e! | \gls eat-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ go-IMP.2s | \glt `Get done with your eating and go!'

Knowledge Point: The origin of the auxiliary, the verb `put', shows in the fact that it cannot be used with non-controlled actions \REF{ex:3:x365}.\footnote{In general, control vs. non-control is not a prominent feature in the verb system in Mauwake, unlike many other Papuan languages (\citealt[127]{Foley1986}, \citealt[128]{Reesink1987}).}
Content 1: \gll Waki-ep-pu-a-k | \gls fall-SS.SEQ-CMPL-PA-3s | \glt }

Knowledge Point: In process descriptions a medial verb, followed by the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weeser}- `finish', which stresses the endpoint of the action, is used more than the completive aspect \REF{ex:3:x366}. This, however, is a case of clause chaining (\sectref{sec:8.2}), not a verbal group.
Content 1: \gll Uup-ep \textbf{weeser-eya} wienak-e-m. | \gls cook-SS.SEQ finish-2/3s.DS feed.them-PA-1s | \glt `I finished cooking it and fed it to them.' [Lit: `I cooked it and when it (=the cooking) was finished I fed it to them.']

Knowledge Point: Continuity, or duration, is the semantic component shared by the aspects called progressive and habitual in many languages: continuation of the same action or of repeated actions of the same kind \citep[26]{Comrie1976}. The continuous aspect form in Mauwake can have either progressive \REF{ex:3:x349}, \REF{ex:3:x1044} or habitual \REF{ex:3:x350}, \REF{ex:3:x1045} interpretation. The main verb is in the same-subject simultaneous medial form, but with the final /i/ deleted, and the auxiliary \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' is inflected for tense and person/number \REF{ex:3:x350}.
Content 1: \gll Maa \textbf{en-em-ik-omkun} ama or-o-k. | \gls food eat-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS sun descend-PA-3s | \glt `As I was eating the sun went down.'
Content 2: \gll Fikera \textbf{aw-em-ik-eya} nain umuk-i-nen na-ep urup-o-k. | \gls kunai.grass burn-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS that1 extinguish-Np-FU.1s say-SS.SEQ ascend-PA-3s | \glt `The kunai grass was burning, and she went up in order to extinguish it.'
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll Wi Yaapan naap kuisow=iw \textbf{ekap-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls 3p.UNM Japan thus one=INST come-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `The Japanese kept coming like that, one by one.'

Knowledge Point: For punctiliar verbs the habitual interpretation \REF{ex:3:x351} is the only one possible, whereas for non-punctiliar \REF{ex:3:x1932} verbs both habitual and progressive interpretations are possible.
Content 1: \gll Koka=pa nan \textbf{in-em-ik-e-mik.} | \gls jungle=LOC there lie.down-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `We kept sleeping in the jungle'
Content 2: \gll Owowa oko wiam=iya \textbf{irak-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls village other 3p.ACC=COM fight-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `We were fighting (or: kept fighting repeatedly) with the other village.'

Knowledge Point: When the verbal group is in the medial form, the progressive interpretation \REF{ex:3:x353} is the more common:
Content 1: \gll Waaya \textbf{urup-em-ik-eya} mik-a-m. | \gls pig ascend-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS spear-PA-1s | \glt `As the pig was going/coming up I speared it.'

Knowledge Point: Often the context provides the only clue as to whether the continuous aspect form should be interpreted as progressive or habitual. The example \REF{ex:3:x354} describes a situation where the villagers kept feeding the Japanese soldiers who asked them for food; the sentence \REF{ex:3:x355} is from a text describing a coconut plantation fire and its consequences.
Content 1: \gll Waaya yia na-iwkin waaya \textbf{wienak-em-ik-e-mik}. | \gls pig 1p.ACC say-2/3p.DS pig feed.them-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They asked us for pigs and we kept giving them pigs to eat.'
Content 2: \gll Kawus \textbf{ir-am-ik-eya} kuuf-a-k. | \gls smoke rise-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS see-PA-3s | \glt `The smoke was rising and she saw it.'

Knowledge Point: Cross-linguistically the habitual aspect more commonly receives overt marking in the past tense than in the present \citep[154]{Cristofaro2006}. In Mauwake the continuous aspect can be used for habitual in any of the three tenses. The example \REF{ex:3:x1063} was said about particular work that the speaker was not involved in continuously; he used to do it time to time because of his position as need arose. The example \REF{ex:3:x1064} refers to a couple needing to keep visiting an ailing father.
Content 1: \gll Yo anane maneka naap \textbf{mauw-am-ika-i-yem}. | \gls 1s.UNM always very thus work-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I always/forever keep working like that.'
Content 2: \gll O me sariar-i-non-(na) neeke \textbf{in-em-ika-i-kuan}. | \gls 3s.UNM not get.well-Np-FU.3s-(TP) there.CF sleep-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.3p | \glt `If he doesn't get well, they will keep sleeping/staying there.'

Knowledge Point: For a clause to have habitual interpretation it is not obligatory to use the continuous aspect form in the verb. For instance in process descriptions, which tell how something is habitually done, the unmarked, aspectually neutral present tense form is more common than the continuous aspect. Three of the four verbs in \REF{ex:3:x1049} are aspectually unmarked, although all the clauses have habitual interpretation, describing seclusion customs.
Content 1: \gll Moma ik-owa \textbf{enim-i-mik}. Eka me \textbf{enim-i-mik}, iwer eka me \textbf{enim-i-mik}. Aaya muutiw \textbf{en-em-ika-i-mik}. | \gls taro roast-NMZ eat-Np-PR.1/3p water not eat-Np-PR.1/3p coconut water not eat-Np-PR.1/3p sugarcane only eat-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `We do not eat roasted taro. We do not drink water or coconut water. We only eat / keep eating sugarcane.'

Knowledge Point: The same semantic component of continuity is also shared by the other aspect using the auxiliary ik- `be': this time it is a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{state}} rather than activity that continues the same over time. In the stative aspect, the auxiliary is combined with a main verb that is in the same-subject sequential form. This usage is most common with the position-taking verbs like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pok}- `sit down' \REF{ex:3:x356}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iimar}- `stand up' \REF{ex:3:x1046} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{in}- `lie down/ fall asleep'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Pok-ap-ik-omkun} epa wiim-o-k. | \gls sit.down-SS.SEQ-be-1s/p.DS place dawn-PA-3s | \glt `As we were sitting it dawned.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Other punctiliar verbs \REF{ex:3:x357}, as well as non-punctiliar verbs, can be used in this aspect to indicate the state resulting from an action \REF{ex:3:x358}, or process \REF{ex:3:x1047}, but they are less frequent.
Content 1: \gll Ifakim-eya \textbf{pu-ep-ik-eya} om-em-ik-ua. | \gls kill-2/3s.DS die-SS.SEQ-be-2/3s.DS cry-SS.SIM-be-PA.3s | \glt `When she killed him and he was dead, she was crying.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikiw-ep-ik-eya} ona emeria=ke ekap-o-k. | \gls go-SS.SEQ-be-2/3s.DS 3s.GEN woman=CF come-PA-3s | \glt `While he was gone his wife came.'
Content 3: \gll Ewar pun wuun-e-k ne epa \textbf{reen-ep-ik-ua}. | \gls west.wind too blow-PA-3s and place dry-SS.SEQ-be-PA.3s | \glt `The west wind blew, too, and the ground was dry.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x359} the continuous form indicates more active waiting process than is the case in \REF{ex:3:x360} with the stative aspect. In \REF{ex:3:x359} the people were getting impatient with the vehicle that should already have come to get them. The example \REF{ex:3:x360} is from a description of garden work, and part of the work process is the state of patiently waiting for the felled trees and undergrowth to dry.
Content 1: \gll Arew\textbf{-am-}ik-omkun ama ikur miiw-aasa kerer-ek. | \gls wait-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS sun five land-canoe arrive-PA-3s | \glt `As we were waiting the car arrived at five.'
Content 2: \gll Nomokowa war-ep-pu-ap arew\textbf{-ap-}ika-iwkin reen-eya saama kuum-i-mik. | \gls tree cut-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ wait-SS.SEQ-be-2/3p.DS dry-2/3s.DS cleared.bush burn-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They cut the trees and while they are waiting it dries and then they burn the cleared bush.'
Content 3: \gll Arew\textbf{-am-}ik-omkun ama ikur miiw-aasa kerer-ek. | \gls wait-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS sun five land-canoe arrive-PA-3s | \glt `As we were waiting the car arrived at five.'
Content 4: \gll Nomokowa war-ep-pu-ap arew\textbf{-ap-}ika-iwkin reen-eya saama kuum-i-mik. | \gls tree cut-SS.SEQ-CMPL-SS.SEQ wait-SS.SEQ-be-2/3p.DS dry-2/3s.DS cleared.bush burn-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They cut the trees and while they are waiting it dries and then they burn the cleared bush.'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake a non-final verb in a serial construction consists of a bare root without any inflection at all. This restriction is tighter than those given for serial verbs in many other languages (\citealt[19]{Crowley2002}; \citealt[86--87]{Sebba1987}; \citealt[28]{James1983}). Each of the verbs in a serial construction contributes to the overall semantic meaning of the predicate. Even if the meaning is not exactly the same as the combination of the same verbs would have in a tight medial verb chain \REF{ex:3:x377} \citep[cf.][310]{Payne1997}, it does not get bleached either, like that of the auxiliaries.\footnote{Since a serial verb construction has only one main stress it is written as one word in the orthography, but the verb stems are separated by hyphens to make reading easier.}
Content 1: \gll Sama=pa \textbf{oro-boon-ek}. | \gls ladder=LOC descend-get.loose-PA-3s | \glt `He fell from the ladder.'

Knowledge Point: The last verb in a series is either a finite verb with tense and person/number inflection, or a medial verb. The arguments are shared by the whole verbal complex, even if they would originally have been associated with only one of the verbs \REF{ex:3:x378}. Also negation and obliques \REF{ex:3:x379} are shared. All this points to serial verbs being a nuclear-level phenomenon in Mauwake, rather than a core-level one \citep[189--193]{FoleyEtAl1984}.
Content 1: \gll Yo Amerika wia \textbf{akup-ikiw-i-yem}. | \gls 1s.UNM America 3p.ACC search-go-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am going to look for the Americans. / I go searching the Americans.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Semantically the verb combinations are of two types. In the more common one a directional or another motion verb follows another verb stem, giving the meaning of \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{movement}} to the whole \REF{ex:3:x378}-\REF{ex:3:x438}, and often the meaning of \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{directionality}} as well \REF{ex:3:x379}-\REF{ex:3:x381}.\footnote{Cross-linguistically motion and location verbs are very common in serial verbs \citep[9]{Lord1993}.} This is a productive process, as long as the verbs are semantically compatible.
Content 1: \gll Yo Amerika wia \textbf{akup-ikiw-i-yem}. | \gls 1s.UNM America 3p.ACC search-go-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am going to look for the Americans. / I go searching the Americans.'
Content 2: \gll Wia \textbf{mokak-urup-o-k}, wia \textbf{mokak-or-o-k}. | \gls 3p.ACC stare-ascend-PA-3s 3p.ACC stare-descend-PA-3s | \glt `He stared them up and down.'
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll Aasa \textbf{suuw-or-o-mik}. | \gls canoe push-descend-PA-1/3p | \glt `We pushed the canoe down (towards the sea).'\footnote{Compare this with a medial construction: \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{Aasa suuw-ap or-o-mik} `We pushed the canoe and went down (to sea)'}

Knowledge Point: If the first stem is also a motion verb, it indicates the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{manner}} of movement \REF{ex:3:x380}:
Content 1: \gll Merena kir-ep \textbf{segen-ikiw-o-k}. | \gls foot turn-SS.SEQ limp-go-PA-3s | \glt `He twisted his foot and limped.'

Knowledge Point: A motion verb in a serial construction can also indicate \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{temporal continuity}} over a long period of time. In \REF{ex:3:x439} the length of time is emphasized even more by the repetition of the motion verb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ife-iki}(w-e)\textbf{p} \textbf{iki}(w-e)\textbf{p} aakisa arim-o-n. | \gls rub-go-SS.SEQ go-SS.SEQ now grow-PA-3s | \glt `You kept rubbing it (over the years) and now you have grown up.'

Knowledge Point: In the second type, any two verbs can, in principle, combine into a serial verb. But this process is less productive, and both the type and token frequency of this type is low when compared with the frequency of the first type. Usually, like in \REF{ex:3:x382} the meaning of the whole is transparent and can be inferred from the meanings of the component roots, but sometimes the semantics are more opaque \REF{ex:3:x383}.
Content 1: \gll Emera \textbf{kue-puuk-ap} okaiwi siowa onak-e-k. | \gls sago bite-cut-SS.SEQ other.side dog feed.him-PA-3s | \glt `He bit off half of the sago cake and fed it to the dog.'
Content 2: \gll Aakun-emi \textbf{mika-kof-a-m}. | \gls speak-SS.SIM spear-knock-PA-1s | \glt `I stumbled in my speech.'

Knowledge Point: A special case among the roots forming serial verbs is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{afur}- `do well'/`augmentative', which is not used as an independent verb, only as a second element in a serial verb structure \REF{ex:3:x384}.\footnote{See \citet[32]{James1983} for the use of a similar verb, \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{ito,} in Siane.}
Content 1: \gll Koora ku-owa \textbf{amis-ar-afur-a-k}. | \gls house build-NMZ knowledge-INCH-do.well-PA-3s | \glt `He really knew how to build a house.'

Knowledge Point: It is quite possible even if not very common to form a three-root serial verb by combining the two types \REF{ex:3:x385}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mika-fien-ikiw-o-k}. | \gls hit-push.aside-go-PA-3s | \glt `He went on countering (an attack).'

Knowledge Point: It is far more common to have three verbs in a combination where an auxiliary is attached to a serial verb \REF{ex:3:x386}:
Content 1: \gll Naap \textbf{amis-ar-ikiw-em-ik-o-wen}. | \gls thus knowledge-INCH-go-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.2p | \glt `That way you will gain more and more knowledge.'

Knowledge Point: In Mauwake the clause chaining is structurally midway between serialization and main clause coordination, and may consequently be used instead of either in some cases. The instrumental may in Mauwake be expressed by a `take-instrument-do' structure \REF{ex:3:x387} which in many serializing languages is a serial verb construction \citep[162--74]{Sebba1987}; but in Mauwake there is no good reason to call the structure anything other than a combination of a medial and final clause. This shows more clearly in example \REF{ex:3:x388}, which does not pass the rule for verbal groups: ``no non-verbal elements between the parts''.
