Content 1: \gll Fura \textbf{aaw-ep} puuk-a-m. | \gls knife take-SS.SEQ cut-PA-1s | \glt `I took a knife and cut it.' Or: `I cut it with a knife.'
Content 2: \gll Burir aaw-ep nomokowa unowa war-e-mik. | \gls axe take-SS.SEQ tree many fell-PA-1/3p | \glt `We took an axe and felled many trees.' Or: `We felled many trees with an axe.'

Knowledge Point: The borderline between serial verbs and medial verbs on the one hand, and between verb + \textstyleAcronymallcaps{aux} groups and medial verbs on the other is not absolutely clear-cut. In \REF{ex:3:x389} the medial verb structure is used instead of a serial verb, even though the two actions are simultaneous, not sequential as indicated by the form of the medial verb.\footnote{Mauwake does not allow same subject simultaneous forms following each other except in a strictly coordinate structure where the verbs do not so much indicate simultaneity with each other as with the final verb.}
Content 1: \gll Wi Malala=ke \textbf{muf-ep} \textbf{ekap-emi}{\dots} | \gls 3p.UNM Malala=TP pull-SS.SEQ come-SS.SIM | \glt `The Malala people came pulling it and{\dots}'

Knowledge Point: Likewise, the four verbs in \REF{ex:3:x390} describe \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{one}} protracted action in spite of the sequential form in the medial verbs:
Content 1: \gll Ifa nain \textbf{murar-ep} \textbf{wiok-ap} \textbf{ekap-ep} \textbf{ekap-ep} owowa kerer-ek. | \gls snake that1 follow-SS.SEQ follow.them-SS.SEQ come-SS.SEQ come-SS.SEQ village arrive-PA-3s | \glt `The snake kept following them and arrived in the village.'

Knowledge Point: The main verb in verb plus \textstyleAcronymallcaps{aux} combinations has to be in medial form. The only exception found is the continuous aspect form of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wiaw}- `move around'. The mere root of this verb is used when it is the second verb in a serial structure which then takes an aspectual auxiliary \REF{ex:3:x391}:
Content 1: \gll Ifara mufe-\textbf{wiaw}-ik-ok{\dots} | \gls vine pull-move.around-be-SS | \glt `As he was pulling the vine around{\dots}'

Knowledge Point: The nominal adjuncts look like object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s, and the origin of at least some of them probably is in object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s, but currently there are syntactic and semantic differences between the two. An object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} may be separated from the verb by the negator adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} or by an accusative or a dative pronoun, but a nominal adjunct must immediately precede the verb \REF{ex:3:x450}. The meaning of the nominal adjunct plus verb construction often cannot be derived from the meanings of its constituent parts.
Content 1: \gll Meta yia miim-ap yia \textbf{miira} \textbf{puuk-ekap-e-mik}. | \gls fame 1p.ACC hear-SS.SEQ 1p.ACC face cut-come-PA-1/3p | \glt `They heard about us and came to greet us.'

Knowledge Point: An object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} only occurs with a transitive verb, but a nominal adjunct can also occur with an intransitive verb \REF{ex:3:x451}:
Content 1: \gll Uura or-op \textbf{arua} \textbf{karu-e-mik}. | \gls night descend-SS.SEQ torch run-PA-1/3p | \glt `At night we went down to sea and fished with a torch.'

Knowledge Point: Those nominal adjunct plus verb structures where the verb is transitive look like two-object clauses, and in a few cases behave like them syntactically. In \REF{ex:3:x452} the nominal adjunct \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kema} `liver' is in its normal adjunct position, but in \REF{ex:3:x453} it is in object \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} position. The basic meanings of the two sentences are the same, but with a different prominence: \REF{ex:3:x452} encodes marked negative focus and \REF{ex:3:x453} verb focus. The clause \REF{ex:3:x1874} with an initial theme pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yo} `I' is pragmatically more neutral than the others except in cases where the initial pronoun receives extra stress. Note the intervening negator also in \REF{ex:3:x1489} below.
Content 1: \gll Me efa \textbf{kema} \textbf{suuw-a-k}. | \gls not 1s.ACC liver push-PA-3s | \glt `He did \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} think of me.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kema} me efa \textbf{suuw-a-k}. | \gls liver not 1s.ACC push-PA-3s | \glt `He didn't \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{think}} of me.'
Content 3: \gll Me efa \textbf{kema} \textbf{suuw-a-k}. | \gls not 1s.ACC liver push-PA-3s | \glt `He did \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{not}} think of me.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Kema} me efa \textbf{suuw-a-k}. | \gls liver not 1s.ACC push-PA-3s | \glt `He didn't \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{think}} of me.'
Content 5: \gll Yo me efa \textbf{kema} \textbf{suuw-a-k}. | \gls 1s.UNM not 1s.ACC liver push-PA-3s | \glt `He didn't think of me.'
Content 6: \gll Muuka gelemuta akena \textbf{kema} me \textbf{puk}\textbf{-}\textbf{e}\textbf{-}\textbf{mik}. | \gls son small very liver not burst-PA-1/3p | \glt `Little boys/children do not think well (yet).'

Knowledge Point: In cases where the adjunct only occurs with a certain verb it is difficult to give it a specified meaning apart from the verb \REF{ex:3:x454}. The same is true for verbs that do not occur independently, only with an adjunct \REF{ex:3:x455}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Naruw} \textbf{ir-a-mik}. | \gls ? ascend-PA-1/3p | \glt `They acted silly.'
Content 2: \gll Naap \textbf{kema} \textbf{tuup-am-ika-i-ya}. | \gls thus liver ?-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `He is hoping so.'

Knowledge Point: Most of the verbs in Mauwake indicating physiological or psychological states and cognition are nominal adjunct plus verb constructions. The verb takes the person marking from the experiencer. \tabref{tab:3:nominaladjunctplusverbconstruction} gives only a small sample of these constructions, where the most common nominal is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kema} `liver'.\footnote{A good list of these is in \citet[47--63]{Kwan1989}, where she has described a large number of body image concepts formed with kema from semantic point of view. For that study the syntactic characteristics of the structures were not relevant.} The second column provides a literal translation. A few more examples of these constructions are in the sentences \REF{ex:3:x1490}-\REF{ex:3:x1489}.
Content 1: \gll Uura \textbf{uroma} \textbf{ikiw-e-m}. | \gls night stomach go-PA-1s | \glt `Last night I had diarrhea.'
Content 2: \gll Muuka gelemuta akena \textbf{kema} me \textbf{puk}\textbf{-}\textbf{e}\textbf{-}\textbf{mik}. | \gls son small very liver not burst-PA-1/3p | \glt `Little boys/children do not think well (yet).'

Knowledge Point: Adverbial adjuncts also have to precede the verb without any intervening words \REF{ex:3:x456}, \REF{ex:3:x457}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma efar \textbf{ikum} \textbf{aaw-e-mik}. | \gls money 1s.DAT illicitly get-PA-1/3p | \glt `They stole money from me.'
Content 2: \gll Maa me efa \textbf{pepek} \textbf{er-a-k}. | \gls food not 1s.ACC enough go-PA-3s | \glt `The food wasn't enough for me.'

Content 1: \gll Koka=pa nan \textbf{in-em-ik-e-mik.} | \gls jungle=LOC there lie.down-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `We kept sleeping in the jungle'

Knowledge Point: Some of the adverbial adjuncts, like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikum} `illicitly' \REF{ex:3:x456} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pepek} `enough' \REF{ex:3:x457}, also function as independent adverbs, shown by an intervening pronoun \REF{ex:3:x458} and/or negator \REF{ex:3:x459}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma efar \textbf{ikum} \textbf{aaw-e-mik}. | \gls money 1s.DAT illicitly get-PA-1/3p | \glt `They stole money from me.'
Content 2: \gll Maa me efa \textbf{pepek} \textbf{er-a-k}. | \gls food not 1s.ACC enough go-PA-3s | \glt `The food wasn't enough for me.'
Content 3: \gll Yo oram \textbf{ikum} efa wu-a-n. | \gls 1s.UNM for.nothing illicitly 1s.ACC put-PA-2s | \glt `You accused me for theft without grounds.'
Content 4: \gll No \textbf{pepek} me ma-e-n. | \gls 2s.UNM enough not say-PA-2s | \glt `You didn't say right.'

Knowledge Point: Other adjuncts like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ane} `together' \REF{ex:3:x460} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{anu} `apart' \REF{ex:3:x461}, only combine with verbs to form verbal groups, and it is hard to give them an exact meaning; the glosses below are just approximations.
Content 1: \gll Apura \textbf{ane} \textbf{suuw-am-ika-iwkin} pok-ap ik-ok om-o-k. | \gls widow together push-SS.SIM-be-2/3p.DS sit.down-SS.SEQ be-SS cry-PA-3s | \glt `They were supporting the widow (sitting against her back) and she sat and wailed.'
Content 2: \gll Opora \textbf{anu} \textbf{fien-owa} me pepek. | \gls talk apart/aside brush.off-NMZ not enough | \glt `He wasn't able to disregard the talk.'

Knowledge Point: All the non-controversial locative adverbs are deictic \REF{ex:3:x1933}, \REF{ex:3:x1934}, and they were discussed above in section on spatial deictics (\sectref{sec:3.6.3}).
Content 1: \gll {\dots}mokoma kuisow naap \textbf{fan} yiam=iya ik-e-mik. | \gls year one thus here 1p.REFL=COM be-PA-1/3p | \glt `{\dots}for about a year they were here with us.'
Content 2: \gll {\dots}mua owawiya \textbf{neeke} ik-ok uruf-ap{\dots} kiiriw ep-i-kuan. | \gls man with there.CF be-SS see-SS.SEQ again come-Np-FU.3p | \glt `{\dots}having been with her husband there and seeing [her father] they will come (back) again.'

Knowledge Point: The words \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{epasia} \footnote{Epasia has probably developed from epa asia `wild place'.} `far (away)' \REF{ex:3:x467} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{mamaiya} `near, close' \REF{ex:3:x469}, \REF{ex:3:x1856} are actually locative nouns, but may be in the process of becoming adverbs. They optionally take the locative clitic \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa}, but its presence or absence causes no semantic difference. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Tiil} `edgewise, close' \REF{ex:3:x470} cannot take the locative clitic. Its use is quite restricted, and it might be more accurately classified as a manner adverb.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Epasia} ikiw-em-ik-omkun yia far-e-k. | \gls far go-SS.SIM-be-1s/p.DS 1p.ACC call-PA-3s | \glt `As we were (still) walking at a distance, he called us.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Mua oko=ke \textbf{mamaiya} pok-a-k. | \gls man other=CF near sit-PA-3s | \glt `Another man slept with her (lit: sat near).'
Content 4: \gll Saapipia baliwep me wu-a-m, \textbf{tiil} wu-a-m. | \gls trap well not put-PA-1s on.edge put-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't put the trap well, I put it right on the edge (of the reef).'

Knowledge Point: Locative expressions that in some other languages would be expressed through pre- or postpositions or adverbs are formed with locative phrases containing locative relational nouns in Mauwake \REF{ex:3:x468}.
Content 1: \gll koor \textbf{kuenuma}\textbf{=pa} | \gls house underside=LOC | \glt `underneath (lit: in/on the underside of) the house'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Deictic specific}} temporal adverbs refer to a certain day in relation to the time of the utterance \REF{ex:3:x471}, \REF{ex:3:x472}.\footnote{The only exception to this in the data is \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{uurika}, which in the forms \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{uurik ona} (lit: `tomorrow place') and \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{uurika naap nain} (lit: `tomorrow thus that') means `the following day' and takes the time of the event as the deictic centre.} They are given in \tabref{tab:3:deicticsepecifictemporaladverbs}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Unan} nainiw yiam fiirim-e-mik. | \gls Yesterday again 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt `Yesterday we met again.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Uurika} emeria manina ikiw-ep en-owa nop-ap or-eka. | \gls tomorrow woman garden go-SS.SEQ eat-NMZ fetch-SS.SEQ descend-IMP.2p | \glt `You women, go to the garden tomorrow and fetch food (and come) down.'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{deictic non-specific temporals}} (\tabref{tab:3:deicticnonspecifictemporals}) refer to a time that is related to the time of the utterance (or in some cases to the time of the event), but is not restricted to a certain day \REF{ex:3:x473}--\REF{ex:3:x474}.
Content 1: \gll Aria, no \textbf{aakisa} maa enim-e. | \gls alright 2s.UNM now thing/food eat-IMP.2s | \glt `Alright, eat now.'
Content 2: \gll No emeria \textbf{iiriw} sesek-a-mik. | \gls 2s.UNM woman already send-PA-1/3p | \glt `We already sent your wife (away).'

Knowledge Point: Both \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikoka} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wiimar } mean `later', and they can occasionally be used interchangeably. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Ikoka} is the more common of the two, and has to be used when referring to a later time the same day \REF{ex:3:x476}. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Wiimar} always refers to a less specific time somewhere in the future, but the use of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikoka} is spreading to cover that too. The sentence \REF{ex:3:x477} is from a wedding speech, and it was unlikely that the young couple would be fighting later the very same day.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wiimar} ikiw-i-yan, \textbf{ikoka} weetak. | \gls later go-Np-FU.1p later no | \glt `We'll go some other time, not later today.'
Content 2: \gll No \textbf{ikoka} mua ikos irak-ep me efar kerer-e. | \gls 2s.UNM later man with fight-SS.SEQ not 1s.DAT arrive-IMP.2s | \glt `Later when you fight with your husband, don't come to me.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Aakisa} `now' can be modified to further specify the meaning, as the exact present moment is so short that a word referring to it only is practically useless. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Aakisa kuisow} (lit: `now one') refers to something that \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{will take place}} `just now', in a moment \REF{ex:3:x478}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa fan} (lit: `now here') refers to something that \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{has happened}} just now \REF{ex:3:x479} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aakisa fain} (lit: `now this') compares the present situation with earlier times \REF{ex:3:x480}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aakisa} \textbf{kuisow} on-e, ikoka weetak. | \gls now one do-IMP.2s later no | \glt `Do it right now, not later.'
Content 2: \gll Muuna kirip-owa ma-e-mik nain \textbf{aakisa} \textbf{fan} kirip-a-mik. | \gls debt return-NMZ say-PA-1/3p that1 now here return-PA-1/3p | \glt `They (only) just now returned the debt they have talked about returning.'
Content 3: \gll Iiriw miiw-aasa marew, \textbf{aakisa} \textbf{fain} miiw-aasa nepik akena. | \gls earlier land-canoe none now this land-canoe crowd real | \glt `Earlier there were no cars, now(adays) there are lots of cars.'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{non-deictic specific}} temporals \REF{ex:3:x698}, \REF{ex:3:x699} refer to a specific time, but their interpretation is not tied to the time of the utterance (\tabref{tab:3:nondeicticspecifictemporal}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Amirika} ama kekan-eya uurar-i-mik. | \gls day sun strong-2/3.DS rest-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `During the day (or: at noon) when the sun is strong, we take a rest.'
Content 2: \gll Yaapan=ke \textbf{uura} ifera=pa nan pok-om-ow-a-mik. | \gls Japan=CF evening/night sea=LOC there sit-BEN-CAUS-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the evening the Japanese made him sit in the sea.'

Knowledge Point: The temporal adverbs in \tabref{tab:3:nondeicticnonspecifictemp} are both \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{non-deictic}} and \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{non-specific}} \REF{ex:3:x502}, \REF{ex:3:x504}.
Content 1: \gll Yo \textbf{anane} naap mauw-am-ika-i-yem. | \gls I always thus work-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1p | \glt `I always work like that.'
Content 2: \gll Irak-owa maneka \textbf{ewur} me imen-ar-e-k. | \gls fight-NMZ big quickly not find-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `The big fight/war didn't start quickly.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Nainiw} \REF{ex:3:x697} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kiiriw} \REF{ex:3:x1762} both mean `again', and they can be used interchangeably when referring to repeated action.
Content 1: \gll Ne \textbf{nainiw} sande uura yiam fiirim-e-mik. | \gls ADD again Sunday evening 1p.REFL gather-PA-1/3p | \glt `And again on Sunday evening we gathered together.'
Content 2: \gll Ne \textbf{kiiriw} enuma on-am-ik-e-mik. | \gls ADD again new make-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `And again they kept making a new one.'

Knowledge Point: When some action or event results in a state that is the same or similar as before, even if the action itself is not repeated, only\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kiiriw} can be used. Thus, only \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kiiriw} is possible in \REF{ex:3:x503}. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Kiiriw} indicates that Jesus is alive again, as he had been before, whereas \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nainiw} would indicate that he had risen from the dead earlier too.
Content 1: \gll Yeesus \textbf{kiiriw} iikir-a-k. | \gls Jesus again rise-PA-3s | \glt `Jesus rose again (= rose from the dead).'

Knowledge Point: Also, if the action is the same but the situation changes, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kiiriw} is used. The example \REF{ex:3:x1761} describes a situation where a grandmother first sent her younger grandchild, a girl, to listen to a sound. Later she sent the grandson for the same errand; the act of sending was repeated but the person who was sent changed:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Kiiriw} morena iperowa nain sesek-a-k. | \gls again male older that1 send-PA-3s | \glt `Again she sent the elder male (grandchild).'

Knowledge Point: Occasionally, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kiiriw} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nainiw} can be used together \REF{ex:3:x700}:
Content 1: \gll Ar-ep ik-eya aria \textbf{kiiriw} mua nain \textbf{nainiw} urup-o-k. | \gls become-SS.SEQ be-2/3s.DS alright again man that1 again ascend-PA-3s | \glt `When she had become like that, alright the man came up again.'

Knowledge Point: The manner adverbial phrase is often manifested by just an adverb word rather than a longer phrase. The same distinction between deictic and non-deictic adverbs that was made with the other material adverbs can be made with the manner adverbs as well. The description of the deictic manner adverbs \REF{ex:3:x1935}, \REF{ex:3:x1936} is in \sectref{sec:3.6.4}.
Content 1: \gll ...maa oposia pun \textbf{naap} sesek-a-mik. | \gls thing meat also thus sell-PA-1/3p | \glt `{\dots}like that they also sold meat.'
Content 2: \gll Soo nain \textbf{feenap}: era erup ik-ua. | \gls fishtrap that1 like.this way two be-PA.3s | \glt `The fishtrap (custom) is like this: there are two ways.'

Knowledge Point: Most of the non-deictic manner adverbs are non-derived \REF{ex:3:x704}--\REF{ex:3:x507}, but a few have been derived from adjectives by the deletion of word-final <\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{a}> \REF{ex:3:x506}. This process is not productive. \tabref{tab:3:nondeicticmanneradverbs} gives a list of some of the more common non-deictic manner adverbs.
Content 1: \gll Naap yia ma-i-kuan na-ep yo \textbf{ariman} nefa maak-i-yem. | \gls thus 1p.ACC say-Np-FU.3p say/think-SS.SEQ 1s.UNM openly 2s.ACC tell-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am telling you this openly, thinking that they will say like that about us.'
Content 2: \gll Fikera \textbf{ikum} kuum-e-mik nain ma-i-yem. | \gls kunai.grass illicitly burn-PA-1/3p that1 say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I tell about that when the kunai grass was burned by arson.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Samor} akena aruf-a-mik. | \gls badly very hit-PA-1/3p | \glt `They beat him very badly.'

Knowledge Point: Intensity adverbs are a small and heterogeneous group of adverbs that modify a verb, an adjective, a quantifier or another adverb \REF{ex:3:x508}, \REF{ex:3:x510}. Some of them (\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena, maneka}) are also adjectives, some others (\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{lawisiw, iiwawun, wenup}) are non-numeral quantifiers (\sectref{sec:3.4.2}) with a second function as intensity adverbs. The distribution is different for each of the intensity adverbs (\tabref{tab:3:intensityadverbs}).
Content 1: \gll Moma fain eliw(a) \textbf{oram}. | \gls taro this good just/very | \glt `This taro is very good.'
Content 2: \gll Koora nain maala \textbf{pepek}. | \gls house that long enough | \glt `That house is long enough.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Akena} `really, truly' is more flexible than the other intensity adverbs in that it can modify a word belonging to almost any word class \REF{ex:3:x706}-- \REF{ex:3:x1875}.
Content 1: \gll Eka mamaiya \textbf{akena} i yoowa me aaw-i-yen | \gls river near very 1p.UNM hot not get-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Very near the river we'll not get hot.'
Content 2: \gll Weetak \textbf{akena}, i=ko me kuum-e-mik. | \gls no really, 1p.UNM=NF not burn-PA-1/3p | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Really no}}, we did not burn it.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Lawisiw} `somewhat' is different from the rest in that it precedes the expression it modifies, rather than following it \REF{ex:3:x703}.
Content 1: \gll Uuw-owa nain \textbf{lawisiw} yoowa. | \gls work-NMZ that1 somewhat hot/hard | \glt `That work is somewhat hard.'

Knowledge Point: As an adjective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{maneka} `big' is very common, but as an intensity adverb `very' it is very restricted in its distribution. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Maneka} cannot modify a verb, but it can intensify some non-numeral quantifiers like \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{unowa} `many' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iiwawun} `altogether', as well as the temporal adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{anane} `always' \REF{ex:3:x509}.
Content 1: \gll Yo anane \textbf{maneka} naap mauw-am-ika-i-yem. | \gls I always very thus work-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{always}} keep working like that.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Eliw} `all right, well'\footnote{The manner adverb `well' is \textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{baliwep }\textstyleFootnoteBaseChar{(\sectref{sec:3.9.1.3})}.} is a \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{deontic}} adverb and expresses permission or desirability: `it is all right/good that{\dots}'. It can often be translated with the auxiliary `may' in English. It follows the subject, if there is any, but precedes the other clause constituents \REF{ex:3:x514}. It may also be in the tail position after the clause, either following a clause that already has \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eliw} in it \REF{ex:3:x515}, or by itself \REF{ex:3:x516}.
Content 1: \gll Wie wi \textbf{eliw} wiar op-i-kuan. | \gls 3s/p.uncle 3p.UNM well 3.DAT hold-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Her uncles may get (lit: hold) them (=clay pots) from her.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Eliw} Kululu ma-e-man, \textbf{eliw}. | \gls well Kululu say-PA-2p well | \glt `It is all right that you mentioned Kululu, that is OK.'
Content 3: \gll Nomokowa, nie owowa=pa fan pok-a-n, \textbf{eliw}. | \gls 2s/p.brother 2s/p.uncle village=LOC here sit-PA-2s well | \glt `It is good/OK that you settled here in your brother's and uncle's village.'

Knowledge Point: An \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{epistemic}} modal adverb is the clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} (with an alternative form -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nion}), expressing hesitation or non-committal assumption: `perhaps', `maybe', `I suppose'. It is attached to the predicate, which usually is a verb \REF{ex:3:x517}, \REF{ex:3:x518}, but can also be non-verbal \REF{ex:3:x519}. The question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{kamenion} `or what' is related to the modal adverb -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} (\sectref{sec:3.9.3}).
Content 1: \gll Maa me wu-om-a-mik=\textbf{yon}. | \gls thing/food not put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p-perhaps | \glt `Perhaps they didn't put food (aside) for him.'
Content 2: \gll Yo me efa ma-e-n=\textbf{yon} aa? | \gls 1s.UNM not 1s.ACC say-PA-2s-perhaps aa | \glt `I suppose you weren't saying it about me?'
Content 3: \gll Ni kema puk-owa marewa=ke=\textbf{yon}! | \gls 2p.UNM liver burst-NMZ none=CF-perhaps | \glt `You must be crazy!' (Lit: `I suppose your liver hasn't burst (yet).')

Knowledge Point: The adverbs \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muut(a}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{)}/\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muutiw} `just/only' and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pun} `also, too' are called free adverbs, as they can move around quite freely and attach themselves to various elements in a clause. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Muutiw} is a combination of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muut(a)} and the limiter clitic \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw}, and it restricts the scope of a preceding noun phrase or adverbial phrase \REF{ex:3:x747}--\REF{ex:3:x807}. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Muut(a)} is used almost exclusively with noun phrases \REF{ex:3:x1820}, \REF{ex:3:x1821}.
Content 1: \gll Aaya \textbf{muutiw} en-em-ika-i-mik. | \gls sugarcane only eat-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are only eating sugarcane.'
Content 2: \gll Eliw \textbf{muutiw}. | \gls well only | \glt `It's just all right.'
Content 3: \gll Yo opora \textbf{muut} naap. | \gls 1s.UNM talk only thus | \glt `That's my talk.'
Content 4: \gll Uf-owa erup \textbf{muuta} naap uf-e-mik. | \gls dance-NMZ two only thus dance-PA-1/3p | \glt `We only danced two dances like that.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Pun} `also' has even wider distribution than \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muutiw}: it can occur following almost any element in a clause \REF{ex:3:x749}--\REF{ex:3:x808}.\footnote{Pun may be in the process of developing into a clitic. As a one-syllable word it it often has a weak stress, and some speakers also write it attached to the preceding word with a hyphen, the way clitics are written in the Mauwake orthography.}
Content 1: \gll Ne waaya nain \textbf{pun} afila marew, waaya asia \textbf{pun.} | \gls and pig that1 also grease no(ne) pig wild also | \glt `And that pig also didn't have fat, (as) it was a wild pig too.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Mauwake has four negators: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{weetak}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew}. They are morphologically free and syntactically heterogeneous, each one having its specific position. Of the four negators \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} is positioned before the negated element \REF{ex:3:x654}, \REF{ex:3:x1112}, while \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} follows the negated element \REF{ex:3:x655}. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Weetak} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} either form a complete utterance by themselves, or they are sentence-initial when used as negative interjections \REF{ex:3:x707} but clause-final when functioning as non-verbal predicates \REF{ex:3:x1212}, and when replacing full clauses they take the position of the clause they replace \REF{ex:3:x705}, \REF{ex:3:x1111}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma \textbf{me} tuun-owa ik-e-mik. | \gls money not count-NMZ be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They haven't counted the money (yet).'
Content 2: \gll Mukuna \textbf{me} op-a, nefa kuum-i-non! | \gls fire not touch-IMP.2s 2s.ACC burn-Np-FU.3s | \glt `Don't touch the fire, it will burn you!'
Content 3: \gll I muuka \textbf{marew}. | \gls 1p.UNM son no(ne). | \glt `We have no son.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Wia}, me kookal-i-yem. | \gls No not like-Np-PR.1s | \glt `No, I don't like it.'
Content 5: \gll Yo uuw-owa oko \textbf{weetak}. | \gls 1s.UNM work-NMZ other no | \glt `I have no other work.'
Content 6: \gll Wafur-a-k na \textbf{weetak}, ufer-a-k. | \gls throw-PA-3s but no, miss-PA-3s | \glt `He threw it (a spear), but no (=he didn't succeed), he missed (the pig).'
Content 7: \gll Akup-a-mik, akup-a-mik, \textbf{wia}. | \gls search-PA-1/3p search-PA-1/3p no | \glt `We searched and searched, but no (=we did not find it).'

Knowledge Point: According to a rough generalization, the most frequent negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{me} is basically a clause and constituent negator. It is also used to negate imperatives. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Weetak} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} are negative interjections or predicates in verbless clauses, and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} can negate non-verbal predicates and occasionally noun phrase constituents. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Marew} often has the meaning `none at all' \REF{ex:3:x652}.
Content 1: \gll Ni niam erup kema \textbf{{marew akena}}! | \gls 2p.UNM 2p.REFL two liver no(ne) really | \glt `The two of you have \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{really no}} sense at all!'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Weetak}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} \REF{ex:3:x1875}, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} and occasionally \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{marew} \REF{ex:3:x652}, may be intensified by a postposed intensity adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} `truly, very'. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Me} can only be intensified as a verbal negator, in which case \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{akena} comes after the verb rather than after the negator \REF{ex:3:x653}.
Content 1: \gll Weetak \textbf{akena}, i=ko me kuum-e-mik. | \gls no really, 1p.UNM=NF not burn-PA-1/3p | \glt `\textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Really no}}, we did not burn it.'
Content 2: \gll Ni niam erup kema \textbf{{marew akena}}! | \gls 2p.UNM 2p.REFL two liver no(ne) really | \glt `The two of you have \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{really no}} sense at all!'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Me} on-a-m \textbf{akena}. | \gls not do-PA-1s really | \glt `I \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{really didn't}} do it.'

Knowledge Point: The connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} `additive' only indicates that something is added to what has just been said. It can connect word and phrase level units (\sectref{sec:4.1.2}), but is mostly used between clauses (\sectref{sec:8.1}) and even sentences. It is semantically neutral. When it conjoins words \REF{ex:3:x711} or phrases \REF{ex:3:x1359}, and often when it coordinates clauses \REF{ex:3:x713} or sentences \REF{ex:3:x714}, it can be translated into English with `and'.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Sesa nain waaya erup arow \textbf{ne} maamuma kuuma erepam ikur \textbf{ne} manar kuisow, waa eneka, naap muuka sesenar-i-nen. | \gls price that1 pig two three ADD money stick four five ADD forehead.ornament one pig tooth thus son buy-Np-FU.1s | \glt `(As for) the price, I will buy my son with two-three pigs and forty-fifty kina and a forehead ornament (and) pig's tusk(s), like that.'
Content 3: \gll Inawera sira unowa, \textbf{ne} kemena unowa. | \gls dream custom many ADD inside many | \glt `There are many kinds of dreams, and (they have) many meanings.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Ne} yo aakisa tep=pa ma-i-yem. | \gls ADD 1s.UNM now tape.recorder=LOC say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `And now I say it to a tape recorder.'

Knowledge Point: Words or phrases in lists are most commonly joined by juxtaposition only. If a connective is used, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} usually joins the last two \REF{ex:3:x1359} coordinands. It is also possible to place the connective(s) closer to the beginning of the list.
Content 1: \gll Sesa nain waaya erup arow \textbf{ne} maamuma kuuma erepam ikur \textbf{ne} manar kuisow, waa eneka, naap muuka sesenar-i-nen. | \gls price that1 pig two three ADD money stick four five ADD forehead.ornament one pig tooth thus son buy-Np-FU.1s | \glt `(As for) the price, I will buy my son with two-three pigs and forty-fifty kina and a forehead ornament (and) pig's tusk(s), like that.'

Knowledge Point: If the propositions connected by \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} contrast with each other in some way, it may be interpreted as adversative and translated into English with `but' \REF{ex:3:x715}, \REF{ex:3:x716}.\footnote{Many Papuan languages have a connective that is glossed `and/but'. I suggest it is an additive connective like ne, interpreted as either `and' or `but' according to the content of the clauses conjoined.} In these cases it is always a ``weak'' adversative in contrast to the demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} used in ``strong'' adversative clauses (\sectref{sec:8.1.3}).
Content 1: \gll Maa en-owa iw-e-mik, \textbf{ne} rais weetak. | \gls thing eat-NMZ give.him-PA-1/3p ADD rice no | \glt `They gave him food, but not rice.'
Content 2: \gll Wi me kuum-e-mik, \textbf{ne} wi murar-owa=pa mukuna nain kerer-e-k. | \gls 3p.UNM not burn-PA-1/3p ADD 3p.UNM follow-NMZ=LOC fire that appear-PA-3s | \glt `They didn't burn it, but the fire started after them.'

Knowledge Point: In a number of cases either neutral additive or contrastive interpretation is possible \REF{ex:3:x1361}:
Content 1: \gll Wiam erup irak-ep puk-e-mik, aalbok=ke ifera or-o-k ne osaiwa=ke soor(a) asia ikiw-o-k. | \gls 3p.REFL two fight-SS.SEQ disperse-PA-1/3p black.cuckoo-shrike=CF sea descend-PA-3s ADD bird.of.paradise=CF forest wild go-PA-3s | \glt `The two of them fought and went their separate ways, the black cuckoo-shrike went down to the coast and/but the bird of paradise went to the wild (rain)forest.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Aria} `alright'\footnote{The translation reflects the Tok Pisin word orait, which sometimes has a similar discourse function. Aria occurs in many Madang languages, and the speakers of those languages tend to use aria in Tok Pisin too.} usually comes sentence-initially, but can also or occur sentence-med\-ially. Its main function is to indicate a break in the topic chain. In \REF{ex:3:x717} the topic changes from the snake to the man, and in \REF{ex:3:x718} from a health extension officer to a group of men:
Content 1: \gll Keraw-eya \textbf{aria} nomokowa gelemuta puuk-ap ifa nain ifakim-o-k. | \gls bite-2/3s.DS alright tree small cut-SS.SEQ snake that kill-PA-3s | \glt `It (=the snake) bit him, and he cut a small tree and killed the snake.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: It often signals the beginning of a turn in a conversation \REF{ex:3:x721}, or beginning of a speech \REF{ex:3:x720}, again indicating a break with the preceding text.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aria} wiipa, i yia uruf-e. | \gls alright daughter, 1p.UNM 1p.ACC see-IMP.2s | \glt `Daughter, look at us.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Aria}, i owowa=ko urup-u. | \gls alright, 1p.UNM village=NF ascend-IMP.1d | \glt `Alright, let's go back to the village.'

Knowledge Point: Even if the topic stays the same, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria} can be used, especially when there is a contrast between alternatives \REF{ex:3:x719}, or sometimes when an expected sequence of events is broken \REF{ex:3:x722}.
Content 1: \gll Mua maneka maamuma erup, \textbf{aria} wi suule takira maamuma kuisow, naap omopora sesenar-e-mik. | \gls man big money two alright 3p.UNM school child money one thus door buy-PA-1/3p | \glt `The grown men paid two coins (=20 toea) for entrance, the schoolchildren one coin.'
Content 2: \gll Wiawi onak urera maa uup-e-mik, \textbf{aria} maa me wu-om-a-mik=yon. | \gls 3s/p.father 3s/p.mother evening food cook-PA-1/3p alright food not put-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p-perhaps | \glt `In the evening his parents cooked food, (but) perhaps they didn't put any food for him.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Ne aria} `and alright' occurs less often than \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria}, and only sentence-initially \REF{ex:3:x723}. It marks major points of development in the plot of a story. Sometimes it also signals return to foreground text (i.e. main story line) after some backgrounded material.
Content 1: \gll Naap wia maak-e-mik. \textbf{Ne} \textbf{aria}, ifa nain murar-ep{\dots} | \gls thus 3p.ACC tell-PA-1/3p ADD alright snake that follow-SS.SEQ | \glt `They told them like that. Now, the snake followed them and {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: The semantic connectives specify the relationship between two propositions. The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{disjunctive}} connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `or' can connect not only propositions but words or phrases as well. It is used both for standard \REF{ex:3:x724} and interrogative \REF{ex:3:x725} disjunction\footnote{This terminology is from \citet{Haspelmath2007}.} (\ref{sec:8.1.2}, \ref{sec:7.2.2}). When there are two alternatives, the connective occurs between them. It is also common to have the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} cliticized to the end of the first alternative, especially in questions, but also elsewhere.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Emeria=ko efar uruf-a-man=\textbf{i} \textbf{e} weetak? | \gls woman=NF 1s.DAT see-PA-2p=QM or no | \glt `Did you see my wife or not?'

Knowledge Point: When there are more alternatives than one and the question clitic is present, the connective may be left out altogether \REF{ex:3:x726}, or it may occur between the first two alternatives \REF{ex:3:x727}.
Content 1: \gll maa oposia=i moma, emera, naap | \gls thing meat=QM taro, sago, thus | \glt `meat, or taro, or sago, (things) like that'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naapeya/naeya} is the most generic and frequently used of the four. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naapeya} has developed from the manner adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus' followed by the different-subject marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{eya}\textstyleParagraphChari{ (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.5.2})};\footnote{Actually this connective in the coastal villages is naapera, but because of the language committee's decision to use -eya for the 2/3s.\textsc{ds} marker, this form is used here too.} the resulting meaning is `it being thus'. The origin of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} is in the medial different-subject form of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na}- `say, think'. The difference between the two is mainly dialectal, or areal: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naapeya} \REF{ex:3:x731}, \REF{ex:3:x732} is used more on the coast, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} \REF{ex:3:x735}, \REF{ex:3:x1413} in the inland. They are used for marking the effect or result clause in a consecutive sentence.
Content 1: \gll I maamuma marew, \textbf{naapeya} ifera=ko me sesenar-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM money no(ne), so salt=NF not buy-PA-1/3p | \glt `We didn't have money, so we didn't buy salt.'
Content 2: \gll Ben uuw-owa piipu-a-k. \textbf{Naapeya} emina urur-ep me ekap-o-k. | \gls Ben work-NMZ left-PA-3s therefore occiput fall-SS.SEQ not come-PA-3s | \glt `Ben has left the work. Therefore he was ashamed to come.'
Content 3: \gll Pika oona me kekan-ow-a-k. \textbf{Naeya} uura ewar=ke teek-a-k. | \gls wall bone not strong-CAUS-PA-3s therefore night wind=CF tear-PA-3s | \glt `He didn't strengthen the wall studs. So at night the wind tore it (the house) down.'
Content 4: \gll I miiw-aasa=pa ekap-e-mik, \textbf{naeya} o me yook-a-k. | \gls 1p.UNM land-canoe=LOC come-PA-1/3p therefore 3s.UNM not follow.us-PA-3s | \glt `We came in a car, so he didn't follow/come with us.'

Knowledge Point: The origin of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} is so transparent that there are many cases where two different interpretations for \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} are acceptable \REF{ex:3:x734}.
Content 1: \gll ``Yo koka=pa ik-e-m.'' \textbf{Na-eya} Magerka=ke (ma-e-k){\dots} | \gls 1s.UNM jungle=LOC be-PA-1s say-2/3s.DS MacArthur (say-PA-3s) | \glt ` ``I was in the jungle.'' He said that, and (or: So) MacArthur said, {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: But in \REF{ex:3:x733} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} clearly means `therefore' and cannot be interpreted as a medial verb, as the correct verb form in this case would be plural \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naiwkin} `they said and{\dots}', not singular \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} `you/(s)he said and{\dots}'.
Content 1: \gll Iwera yia na-em-ik-e-mik. \textbf{Naeya} iwera wia uruk-am-ik-om-a-mik. | \gls coconut 1s.ACC say-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p So coconut 3p.ACC drop-SS.SIM-be-BEN-BNFY2.PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept asking us for coconuts. So we kept dropping coconuts for them.'

Knowledge Point: The originally dialectal difference may be developing into a semantic one. In the original text data from three decades ago there is no clear semantic distinction between the use of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naapeya} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya}, but fairly recently when a group with members from different dialects, discussing language matters, produced consecutive clauses, nearly all of the sentences with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naapeya} were cases of cause-effect \REF{ex:3:x1414}, and all of the sentences with \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naeya} were cases of reason and result \REF{ex:3:x1415}.
Content 1: \gll I fiirim-owa=pa ik-emkun ama or-o-k, \textbf{naapeya} epa kokom-ar-e-k. | \gls 1p.UNM gather-NMZ=LOC be-1s/p.DS sun descend-PA-3s therefore place dark-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `When we were in the meeting the sun went down, so it became dark.'
Content 2: \gll I fiirim-owa=pa ik-emkun ama or-o-k, \textbf{naeya} maa me wiar en-owa ikiw-o-k. | \gls 1p.UNM gather-NMZ=LOC be-1s/p.DS sun descend-PA-3s therefore food not 3.DAT eat-NMZ go-PA-3s | \glt `When we were in the meeting the sun went down, so he went without eating the food.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naapeya} can also co-occur with the conjunctive coordinators \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria}. In argumentation, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ne naapeya} or \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{aria naapeya} has to be used, when the reason is not confined to one clause but extends to a longer stretch of the discourse \REF{ex:3:x1406}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aria} \textbf{naapeya} niena soomar-owa ne aakun-owa pun sira yi-e-k nain kaken=iw ook-ap soomar-eka. | \gls alright therefore 2p.GEN walk-NMZ ADD talk-NMZ also custom give.us-PA-3s that1 straight=LIM follow-SS.SEQ walk-IMP.2p | \glt `So therefore, as concerns your walk and talk too, follow straight the behaviour that he gave us and walk that way.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Neemi} is used only in reasoning. It requires some point of similarity between the antecedent and the result clause \REF{ex:3:x736}.
Content 1: \gll Teeria fain K10 wu-a-mik. \textbf{Neemi} wi teeria nain pun K10 wu-a-mik. | \gls group this K10 put-PA-1/3p therefore 3p.UNM group that1 too K10 put-PA-1/3p | \glt `This group put down K10. Therefore that group put down K10, too.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Naap nain} can be translated into English with `therefore', `in that case', `if so, then'. It is made up of the manner adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{naap} `thus' and the distal demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that'. It is a strong connective, stressing the fact that the proposition following the connective is a logical conclusion from the preceding proposition \REF{ex:3:x737}.
Content 1: \gll Ni moma uup-i-man=i? \textbf{Naap} \textbf{nain} yo saa uup-i-nen. | \gls 2p.UNM taro cook-Np-2p=QM thus that 1s.UNM rice cook-Np-FU.1s | \glt `Are you cooking taro? In that case I'll cook rice.'

Knowledge Point: It is much less common in Mauwake to mark the reason clause than the result clause with a connective. When the reason clause is emphasized, it is marked with the connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moram} (\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia}) `because' and always follows the result clause rather than preceding it. The origin of the reason connective is in the question word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moram} `why?' and the negator \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{wia} `no(t)'.\footnote{Moram as a reason connective is probably a calque on Tok Pisin bilong wanem `why, because'. The negator, which does not influence the meaning of the connective, may have been added in Mauwake to help distinguish the connective from the question word.} The difference between \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moram wia} and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{moram} is that the former is mainly used across sentence boundary \REF{ex:3:x738}, and the latter within a sentence \REF{ex:3:x739}.
Content 1: \gll Maamuma senam aaw-e-mik. \textbf{Moram} \textbf{wia}, maa ele-eliwa sesek-a-mik. | \gls money a.lot get-PA-1/3p why not thing RDP-good sell-PA-1/3 | \glt `They got a lot of money. (That's) because they sold good things/foods.'
Content 2: \gll Miiw-aasa muf-owa me ikiw-e-mik, \textbf{moram} os=ke naap ar-eya. | \gls land-canoe pull-NMZ not go-PA-1/3p why 3s.FC=CF thus become-2/3s.DS | \glt `We didn't go to fetch a truck, because she had become like that (=died).'

Knowledge Point: The comitative clitic is -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iya} `with, and, both {\dots} and'. The clitic may be attached to either of the two related noun phrases \REF{ex:3:x775}, \REF{ex:3:x776}, or to both \REF{ex:3:x777}.
Content 1: \gll Nan pok-ap-ik-e-mik, \textbf{mua=iya} \textbf{emeria}. | \gls there sit-SS.SEQ-be-PA-1/3p man=COM woman. | \glt `They were sitting there, (both) husband and wife.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Muuka} \textbf{wiip=iya} kerer-e-mik. | \gls son daughter=COM appear-PA-1/3p | \glt `(Both) a son and a daughter appeared.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Bom=iya} \textbf{kateres=iya,} \textbf{bom=iya} \textbf{kateres=iya} (fuurk-a-mik). | \gls bomb=COM cartridge=COM bomb=COM cartridge=COM drop-PA-1/3p | \glt `They dropped (both) bombs and cartridges, (both) bombs and cartridges.'

Knowledge Point: Occasionally the clitic can also be used to indicate instrument \REF{ex:3:x778}.
Content 1: \gll Mauwa ar-e-n, \textbf{amia=iya} nenar-e-mik=i? | \gls what become-PA-2s bow=COM shoot.you-PA-1/3p=QM | \glt `What happened to you, did they shoot you with a gun?'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Owawiya}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{/owawik} `with, together with' is used only for humans; it can refer to two or more people \REF{ex:3:x821}. It can also occur by itself \REF{ex:3:x822}. The origin of the first part \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owaw}- is unknown. The second part is either the comitative clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iya} or the root of the existential verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}\nobreakdash- `be', a reflection of an earlier construction \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{owawiya ik}\nobreakdash- `be together' \REF{ex:3:x1817}.
Content 1: \gll Yoli onak \textbf{owawiya} efa amukar-e-mik. | \gls Yoli 3s/p.mother with 1s.ACC scold-PA-1/3p | \glt `Yoli and his mother scolded me.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Owawiya} feeke pok-ap ik-ok soomar-ek-eka. | \gls with here.CF sit-SS.SEQ be-SS walk-go-IMP.2p | \glt `(First) sit here with us and (then) go.'
Content 3: \gll Iikir-ami onak \textbf{owawik} soomar-e-mik. | \gls get.up-SS.SIM 3s/p.mother with walk-PA-1/3p | \glt `He got up and walked with his mother.'

Knowledge Point: The postposition \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{onaiya/onaria}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{/onaiyik} may be based on the third person singular genitive pronoun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ona} and the clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iya}; \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{onaiyik} also includes the root of the verb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}\nobreakdash- `be'. This postposition is more generic and can be used with noun phrases referring to people \REF{ex:3:x754} but is also common when referring to things \REF{ex:3:x755}. When the relationship between the two noun phrases is unequal, \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{onaiya} may used, like in \REF{ex:3:x823}, where the other people carried the sick man. The subject marking on the verb is influenced by how active part the referents of the comitative noun phrase take in the action. When all the participants are active, the subject marking on the verb is plural. The speech in \REF{ex:3:x1819} was directed towards the villagers who were instructed to stay away from the Japanese troops.
Content 1: \gll Mua unowa \textbf{onaiya} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls man many with go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went with many people.'
Content 2: \gll Urom(a) \textbf{onaiya} ik-ua. | \gls stomach with be-PA.3s | \glt `She is/was pregnant.'
Content 3: \gll Mua napuma \textbf{onaiya} Medebur ek-a-mik. | \gls man sick with Medebur go-PA-1/3p | \glt `They went to Medebur with the sick man.'
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: Another comitative postposition that mainly refers to things is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{feekiya} `with' \REF{ex:3:x824}--\REF{ex:3:x1818}. It originates from the combination of \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{feeke} `here' and -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iya} `comitative', but the meaning does not reflect the deictic origin of the initial part. In those rare cases when it is attached to a [+human] noun phrase, the referent of this \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is subordinate to the referent of the other \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} and not in control, but still influencing the subject marking of the verb \REF{ex:3:x825}.
Content 1: \gll Mokok urupa kaik-i-man nain \textbf{feekiya} baurar-eka. | \gls eye cup tie-Np-PR.2p that1 with flee-IMP.2p | \glt `Flee with your ``eye cups'' (a singsing decoration) still on.'
Content 2: \gll Maa eliw akena nain aaw-ep \textbf{feekiya} ikiw-o-k. | \gls thing good very that1 take-SS.SEQ with go-PA-3s | \glt `He took the very good thing and went with it.'
Content 3: \gll Wiamun gelemuta pun aaw-ep \textbf{feekiya} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 3s/p.brother small also take-SS.SEQ with go-PA-1/3p | \glt `He took his little brother too, and went with him.'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{dual}} comitative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ikos} `with, together (with)' can only be used when two human participants are referred to \REF{ex:3:x752}. It can also occur alone, without a preceding noun phrase, when the participants are known from the person/number suffix in the verb, or from the context \REF{ex:3:x753}. The parties are considered equally active, so the verb is always in the plural.
Content 1: \gll Wekera \textbf{ikos} irak-e-mik. | \gls 3s/p.sister with fight-PA-1/3p | \glt `He fought with his sister.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ikos} ikiw-i-yen. | \gls with go-Np-FU.1p | \glt `Let's go together (just the two of us).'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Associative}} \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ame} `with others' is different from the comitative postpositions above in that only one of the parties is specified. The identity of `the others' is left unspecified \REF{ex:3:x826}, \REF{ex:3:x827}.
Content 1: \gll Auwa \textbf{ame} wia maak-eya res aaw-ep merena puuk-a-mik. | \gls 1s/p.father ASSOC 3p.ACC tell-2/3s.DS razor take-SS.SEQ leg cut-PA-1/3p | \glt `He told my father and the others, and they took a razor and made a cut on his leg.'
Content 2: \gll Kuuten \textbf{ame}=ke miim-e-mik. | \gls Kuuten ASSOC=CF precede-PA-1/3p | \glt `Kuuten with (some) others went ahead of them.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Muuta}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ (nain)} `because of, for' gives a reason for an action, when the reason is expressed in a noun phrase rather than a full clause. It has developed from the adverb \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muuta} `a little, only', and in some cases the meaning `only' is retained with the new function as well \REF{ex:3:x756}, \REF{ex:3:x1876}. The distal-1 demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} `that' is optional, and is left out especially when there is another demonstrative \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{nain} preceding \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{muuta} \REF{ex:3:x759}.
Content 1: \gll Iiriw miiwa \textbf{muuta} \textbf{nain} irak-owa marew, oram momor mauw-am-ik-e-mik. | \gls earlier land for that1 fight-NMZ no(ne) just indiscriminately work-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `Earlier there was no fighting for land, they just worked indiscriminately (on any land).'
Content 2: \gll Yia amukar-owa \textbf{muuta} \textbf{nain} nan iiriw ifakim-e-mik. | \gls 1p.ACC scold-NMZ for that1 there earlier kill-PA-1/3p | \glt `We killed her earlier (only) because she scolded us (lit: {\dots}for her scolding of us).'
Content 3: \gll Opora ara nain \textbf{muuta} ifakim-u na-ep on-a-mik. | \gls Talk section that1 for kill-IMP.1d say-SS.SEQ do-PA-1/3p | \glt `(Only) because of that talk they tried to kill him.'

Knowledge Point: \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Saarik} `like' occurs with noun phrases \REF{ex:3:x760} and with nominalized clauses \REF{ex:3:x761}. It indicates a point of similarity between two essentially \textstyleEmphasizedWords{different} things.
Content 1: \gll Mua eliwa \textbf{saarik} aakun-e-k. | \gls man good like speak-PA-3s | \glt `He spoke like a good man.'
Content 2: \gll No sia on-owa \textbf{saarik} magimal puuk-a-n. | \gls 2s.UNM netbag make-NMZ like vine.sp. cut-PA-2s | \glt `You cut \textstyleForeignWords{magimal} vine as if you were going to make a netbag.'

Knowledge Point: The locative clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{pa} mainly marks locative in noun phrases \REF{ex:3:x762}. The most common verb that it collocates with is \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ik}- `be' \REF{ex:3:x1880}. When it occurs with the directional verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.4.4.5}), it often indicates source \REF{ex:3:x1877}, but it can also be used for path \REF{ex:3:x770}, or for instrument in cases where it has a strong locative meaning as well \REF{ex:3:x771}. It is rarely used for goal \REF{ex:3:x1879}; this is possible in cases where the goal is the location for an event taking place immediately.
Content 1: \gll Pon piipa unowa=\textbf{pa} soomar-em-ik-eya mik-a-m. | \gls turtle seaweed many=LOC walk-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS spear-PA-1s | \glt `The turtle was walking among the seaweeds and I speared it.'
Content 2: \gll Ona owowa=\textbf{pa} ik-eya epa wiim-o-k. | \gls 3s.GEN village=LOC be-2/3s.DS place dawn-PA-3s | \glt `When he was in his village it dawned.'
Content 3: \gll Ifa maneka=ke iinan=\textbf{pa} or-o-k. | \gls snake big=CF on.top=LOC descend-PA-3s | \glt `A big snake dropped from above.'
Content 4: \gll Saa=\textbf{pa} ir-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls sand=LOC come/go-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are coming on/along the beach.'
Content 5: \gll Miiw aasa=\textbf{pa} ikiw-e-mik. | \gls land canoe=LOC go-PA-1/3p | \glt `We went by car/in a car.'
Content 6: \gll Mua nain ... eka kapa\textbf{=pa} ir-ap eka nain up-o-k. | \gls man that1 ... river top=LOC come/go-SS.SEQ river that1 block-PA-3s | \glt `The man went to the top/source of the river and blocked the river.'

Knowledge Point: \noindent As temporal phrases locate an event in time, they also use the same locative clitic \REF{ex:3:x763}.
Content 1: \gll Fraide=\textbf{pa} maapora puk-o-k, urera. | \gls Friday=LOC celebration burst-PA-3s, afternoon. | \glt `On Friday the celebration started, in the afternoon.'

Knowledge Point: \noindent It can also be used with an essive meaning, when referring to people's jobs \REF{ex:3:x765}:
Content 1: \gll Yena mua owowa ekap-o-k, amia mua=\textbf{pa} ik-ok. | \gls 1s.GEN man village come-PA-3s bow man=LOC be-SS | \glt `My husband came back to the village, having been a policeman.'

Knowledge Point: The locative clitic has its origin in the word \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{epa} `place'; the transition vowel [e] can sometimes be heard between the clitic and its host, when the host word ends in a consonant \REF{ex:3:x764}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The instrumental clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw}\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{} is used both for concrete \REF{ex:3:x766} and abstract \REF{ex:3:x768} instruments.\footnote{A less emphasized way to add an instrument is to use the chaining structure: `take instrument do something' \REF{ex:3:x387}, \REF{ex:3:x388}.}
Content 1: \gll Nomokowa galua-galua nain=\textbf{iw} biiris on-am-ik-e-mik | \gls tree soft-soft that1=INST bridge make-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They kept making bridges with soft timber.'
Content 2: \gll ...wiena opaimik=\textbf{iw} yia maak-em-ik-e-mik. | \gls 3p.GEN mouth=INST 1p.ACC tell-SS.SIM-be-PA-1/3p | \glt `They talked to us in their language.'
Content 3: \gll Fura \textbf{aaw-ep} puuk-a-m. | \gls knife take-SS.SEQ cut-PA-1s | \glt `I took a knife and cut it.' Or: `I cut it with a knife.'
Content 4: \gll Burir aaw-ep nomokowa unowa war-e-mik. | \gls axe take-SS.SEQ tree many fell-PA-1/3p | \glt `We took an axe and felled many trees.' Or: `We felled many trees with an axe.'

Knowledge Point: It is also used for \textstyleEmphasizedWords{path} and has the meaning `along'; the verb indicates action that continues for some time \REF{ex:3:x767}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The difference between \REF{ex:3:x767} and \REF{ex:3:x770} above is that in \REF{ex:3:x770} the people were coming along the beach at least some of the way, and more specifically at the time of the speaking; whereas \REF{ex:3:x767} indicates that they travelled along the beach more or less the whole way.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Saa=\textbf{pa} ir-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls sand=LOC come/go-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are coming on/along the beach.'
Content 3: \gll Saa=\textbf{pa} ir-am-ika-i-mik. | \gls sand=LOC come/go-SS.SIM-be-Np-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are coming on/along the beach.'
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: The instrumental may also be utilized to indicate \textstyleEmphasizedWords{manner} \REF{ex:3:x1881}--\REF{ex:3:x774}:
Content 1: \gll Uurik ona naap=\textbf{iw} iw-ap poka aaw-e-mik. | \gls tomorrow place thus=INST go-SS.SEQ housepost get-PA-1/3p | \glt `The following day they went in the same way and got houseposts.'
Content 2: \gll Waaya=ke anane wiar en-ow=\textbf{iw} ika-i-ya. | \gls pig=CF always 3.DAT eat-NMZ=INST be-Np-PR.3s | \glt `A pig stays eating their (taro) all the time.'

Knowledge Point: Another usage is in those temporal phrases that refer to something taking place repeatedly at the same time \REF{ex:3:x1882}:
Content 1: \gll I amirik=\textbf{iw} ... Gawar wiar ikiw-e-mik. | \gls 1p.UNM daytime=INST ... Gawar 3.DAT go-PA-1/3p | \glt `In the daytime we always went to Gawar {\dots}'

Knowledge Point: The limiter clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} `only, just' is homophonous with the instrumental. The two probably are of common origin, but synchronically their meanings and positions in the word are distinct (\sectref{sec:3.12.9}). The limiter does not mark a case but restricts the applicability of the predication to the element that it is attached to \REF{ex:3:x769}, \REF{ex:3:x772}.
Content 1: \gll Maa eka\textsubscript{NP}=\textbf{iw} en-ep en-ep lebum-ar-i-nan. | \gls food water=LIM eat-SS.SEQ eat-SS.SEQ lazy-INCH-Np-FU.2s | \glt `When you keep eating only food cooked with water you become tired of it.'
Content 2: \gll Mua=\textbf{iw} pok-aka. | \gls man=LIM sit-IMP.2p | \glt `Sit just among the men.'

Knowledge Point: Of the two topic markers \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ena} is fairly low in frequency, and the description given here is only tentative. It seems that \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ena} as an independent word originally had a topic marking function, but later the topic clitic -(e)na developed from it and is now used for highlighted topic (\sectref{sec:9.2.4}) in main clauses. \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{Ena} still marks a topic, but mainly in relative clauses. It often has a specifying function as well: `the/that (particular one)' \REF{ex:3:x1681}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mua} \textbf{ena} ma-e-k nain makena yos. | \gls man SPEC say-PA-3s that1 true 1s.FC | \glt `The man that he talked about is I.'

Knowledge Point: In long relative clauses, where it is attached to the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{relnp}, it helps to distinguish it from all the other \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}s in the clause \REF{ex:3:x1815}, \REF{ex:3:x1683}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{I} mua owowa=pa ik-ok \textbf{ena} irakowa uruf-a-mik nain nanar nain yo fan ma-i-yem. | \gls 1p.UNM man village=LOC be-SS SPEC fight-NMZ see-PA-1/3p that1 story that1 1s.UNM here say-Np-PR.1s | \glt `I am telling the story of us (particular) people who stayed in the village and saw the fighting.'

Knowledge Point: If the head noun of the \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np} is is recoverable from the context, it may be deleted, leaving behind only \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ena}. In \REF{ex:3:x1682} the head noun \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{epira} `bowl(s)' has been omitted.
Content 1: \gll Aakisa fan \textbf{ena} maneka wu-a-mik nain eliw, wie wi eliw wiar op-i-kuan. | \gls now here SPEC big put-PA-1/3p that1 well 3s/p.uncle 3p.UNM well 3.DAT grab-Np-FU.3p | \glt `Those big (bowls) that we put just now, all right, the uncles may take those from them.'

Knowledge Point: The example \REF{ex:3:x1816}, taken from Bible translation, has a highlighted topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} on the sentence-initial topic \textstyleAcronymallcaps{np}, which is part of the main clause, and \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ena} inside the relative clause:
Content 1: \gll Ni Samaria=na \textbf{o} \textbf{ena} me baliwep amis-ar-e-man nain\textsubscript{RC} lotu on-i-man. | \gls 2p.UNM Samaria=TP 3s.UNM SPEC not well knowledge-INCH that1 worship do-Np-PR.2p | \glt `You Samaritans worship [the one that you do not know well].'

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:3:x779} is from a traditional story, where a man has gone hunting and the spirit of his lover comes to his home. When the wife sees her, she knows what the spirit woman has come to look for and comments:
Content 1: \gll Nena mua=\textbf{na} urema osarena ikiw-o-k. | \gls 2s.GEN man=TP bandicoot path go-PA-3s | \glt `(As for) your husband, he went to catch bandicoots.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x1751} the answer to the question reveals the identity of the person asked about; the topic marker may be used even in a short exchange like this but especially if the text continues to tell more about the topic.
Content 1: \gll Mua nain naareke? Mua nain=\textbf{na} owow saria maneka=ke. | \gls Man that1 who.CF man that1=TP village headman big=CF | \glt `Who is that man? -That man is the big village headman.'

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:3:x780} the speaker changes the topic to the addressee after a discussion on something else:
Content 1: \gll Nos=\textbf{na}? | \gls 2s.FC=TP | \glt `(So,) what about you?'

Knowledge Point: An important function for the topic marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{na} is to mark conditional clauses \REF{ex:3:x744}, \REF{ex:3:x745} (\sectref{sec:8.3.5}). This is a common function for topic markers in Papuan languages (\citealt{Haiman1978}; \citealt{Reesink1983b}, \citeyear[242]{Reesink1987}; \citealt[203]{Foley1986}).
Content 1: \gll Opora wiar ika-i-ya=\textbf{na} eliw urup-ep wia maak-uk. | \gls talk 3.DAT be-Np-PR.3s=TP well ascend-SS.SEQ 3p.ACC tell-IMP.3p | \glt `If they have something to say, they can get up and tell them.'
Content 2: \gll O emeria aaw-owa kookal-ek-a-k=\textbf{na} iw-ek-a-mik. | \gls 3s.UNM woman get-NMZ like-CNTF-PA-3s=TP give.him-CNTF-PA-1/3p | \glt `If he had liked to get a wife, they would have given him one.'

Knowledge Point: It is also used in adversative subordinate clauses (\sectref{sec:8.3.4}) when the main clause expresses a frustrated effort or a cancelled expectation \REF{ex:3:x1399}, or surprise.
Content 1: \gll Ikiw-ep mukuna nain umuk-a-mik=\textbf{na} me pepek. | \gls go-SS.SEQ fire that1 extinguish-PA-1/3p=TP not enough/able | \glt `We went and (tried to) extinguish the fire, but couldn't.'

Knowledge Point: There are two focus clitics, the \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{contrastive focus}} marker -(\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e})\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} and the neutral focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ko}, which has developed from the indefinite \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{oko} `a certain, other'.\footnote{Most of this section is based on J\"arvinen (1988b:81--96).} The main candidate for the contrastive focus marker is the subject of a noun phrase \REF{ex:3:x781}. When the object is fronted as a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}), the subject usually gets the contrastive focus marking to distinguish it from the object \REF{ex:3:x782}.
Content 1: \gll Iiriw ifa marasin=\textbf{ke} kekan-e-k. | \gls earlier snake poison=CF be.strong-PA-3s | \glt `The snake poison had already taken effect.'
Content 2: \gll Episowa ifa nain atua=\textbf{ke} en-e-k. | \gls tobacco leaf that1 worm=CF eat-PA-3s | \glt `The tobacco leaves were eaten by worms.'

Knowledge Point: \noindent Another possible host is the non-verbal predicate of a verbless clause \REF{ex:3:x783} (\sectref{sec:5.6}).
Content 1: \gll Iperuma nain me enim-eka, inasin mua=\textbf{ke}. | \gls eel that1 not eat-IMP.2p spirit man=CF | \glt `Do not eat that eel, it is a spirit man.'

Knowledge Point: There are a few isolated cases where it occurs on some other contrasted element of a clause \REF{ex:3:x784}.
Content 1: \gll Amirika=\textbf{ke} eliw ika-i-yem, uura=\textbf{ke} napum-ar-i-yem. | \gls noon=CF well be-Np-PR.1s night=CF sickness-INCH-Np-PR.1s | \glt `At noon I'm well, at night I am sick.'

Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{neutral focus}} clitic -ko mostly occurs in irrealis-type clauses:\footnote{Because of this, it was called Irrealis focus clitic in J\"arvinen (1988b).} questions \REF{ex:3:x785}, commands \REF{ex:3:x786}, negative clauses \REF{ex:3:x787}, or those with future tense \REF{ex:3:x788}. Unlike the contrastive focus marker, the neutral focus marker can be attached to almost any element of a clause except the final verb. Neutral focus as a textual device is discussed further in \sectref{sec:9.3.2}.
Content 1: \gll Mukuna=\textbf{ko} op-a-man=i? | \gls fire=NF hold-PA-2p=QM | \glt `Did you hold any fire?'
Content 2: \gll Mua nain=\textbf{ko} onak-e! | \gls man that1=NF give.to.eat-IMP.2s | \glt `Give it to that man to eat!'
Content 3: \gll Oposia en-e-man nain yo=\textbf{ko} me uruf-a-m. | \gls meat eat-PA-2p that1 1s.UNM=NF not see-PA-1s | \glt `I didn't (even) see the meat that you ate.'
Content 4: \gll Akim-ap=\textbf{ko} uruf-i-yen. | \gls try-SS.SEQ=NF see-Np-FU.1p | \glt `We'll try and see.'

Knowledge Point: The question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} is a sentential clitic, used to form polar questions, and it attaches itself to the clause-final verb \REF{ex:3:x789} or another clause-final element \REF{ex:3:x790}. Its relationship to the alternative connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} `or' (\sectref{sec:3.11.2}) is unclear; it is possible that \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} was originally an alternative connective but was also employed as a question marker and became so established in this function that a new alternative connective \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{e} developed. It is not uncommon in \textstyleAcronymallcaps{TNG} Madang languages that the question marker and the alternative connective are either the same or closely related.\footnote{In Usan and Amele the alternative connector and the question marker are the same (\citealt[293]{Reesink1987}, \citealt[99]{Roberts1987}). Maia has -i `QM' and e `or' like Mauwake \citep[83,159]{Hardin2002}. Bargam has borrowed the Tok Pisin o as an alternative connector but has retained the clitic -e as the question marker \citep[53,122]{Hepner2002}. Kobon may use the alternative interrogative connector aka `or' sentence-finally in leading polar questions, where the speaker expects the addressee to agree with the proposition. }
Content 1: \gll Sira nain piipua-i-nan=\textbf{i}? | \gls habit that1 leave-Np-FU.2s=QM | \glt `Will you give up that habit?'
Content 2: \gll Nobonob ikiw-e-man nain, owowa eliwa=\textbf{i}? | \gls Nobonob go-PA-2p that1 village good=QM | \glt `You went to Nobonob, is it a good village?'

Knowledge Point: The question marker can also be used in statements, when two or more \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{alternatives}} are given \REF{ex:3:x791}:
Content 1: \gll Mua kuisow manina erup=\textbf{i} (e) arow=\textbf{i} (e) naap. | \gls man one garden two=QM (or) three=QM (or) thus | \glt `A man can have two gardens, or three, like that.'

Knowledge Point: It is possible to have two or more clitics attached to the same word; only the topic marker does not allow other clitics with it. A case marking clitic, forming a constituent with the preceding noun phrase, is placed first. Next comes the focus clitic \REF{ex:3:x792}, with the scope over a phrase but not forming a constituent. The limiter \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{iw} may have a phrase with the focus marking in its scope, so it follows the focus marker. When the limiter follows another clitic, there is a transition consonant <r>between the clitics \REF{ex:3:x795}, \REF{ex:3:x796}. The modal clitic \nobreakdash-\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{yon} `perhaps' (\sectref{sec:3.9.3}) may have a scope over a whole predication, so its position is after the limiter \REF{ex:3:x793}. The sentential clitic, with a scope over the whole sentence, comes last. When the contrastive focus marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ke} and the question marker -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{i} are adjacent, they become a portmanteau clitic -\textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{ki} \REF{ex:3:x794}.
Content 1: \gll Fura=\textbf{iw}=\textbf{ko} me puuk-a-mik. | \gls knife=INST=NF not cut-PA-1/3p | \glt `They didn't cut it with a knife.'
Content 2: \gll Fikera=\textbf{pa}-r=\textbf{iw} fiirim-eka. | \gls kunai.grass=LOC-{\O}=LIM gather-IMP.2p | \glt `Gather them right at the \textstyleForeignWords{kunai} grass.'
Content 3: \gll Os=\textbf{ke}-r=\textbf{iw} maa en-emi ewur-ar-e-k. | \gls 3s.FC=CF-{\O}=LIM food eat-SS.SIM haste-INCH-PA-3s | \glt `Only he rushed with his food.'
Content 4: \gll Wi anim onoma pun o makena Krais=ke na-i-mik=\textbf{yon}=\textbf{i}? | \gls 3p.UNM blade basis also 3s.UNM truly Christ=CF say-Np-PR.1/3p=perhaps=QM | \glt `Are also the authorities perhaps saying that he truly is Christ?'
Content 5: \gll Mua fain Saror muuka=\textbf{ki}? | \gls man this Saror son=CF.QM | \glt `Is this man Saror's son?'

Knowledge Point: There are a lot of interjections in Mauwake; the following \tabref{tab:3:interjections} is not even nearly exhaustive. The pronunciation of interjections may differ from that of other words: intonational variations are greater, and lengthening, even extreme lengthening, of the final vowel is common. Interjections are not part of the normal clause structure, and they usually occur either sentence-initially or finally \REF{ex:3:x797}--\REF{ex:3:x800}. Some can also be placed between clauses in a coordinate sentence \REF{ex:3:x801}. The glosses given in \tabref{tab:3:interjections} for the interjections are just rough approximations.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Aa}, kema=ko kir-ek-a-n \textbf{aa}! | \gls oh liver=NF turn-CNTF-PA-2s oh | \glt `Oh, if only you had changed your ways (lit: turned your liver)!'
Content 2: \gll Naap ma-emi om-em-ika-i-nan, \textbf{na}. | \gls thus say-SS.SIM cry-SS.SIM-be-Np-FU.2s INTJ | \glt `You must cry saying like that.'
Content 3: \gll Yo damol-al-e-m \textbf{oo}, fiker fufa iw-a-m \textbf{oo}. | \gls 1s.UNM bad-INCH-PA-1s oh kunai.grass old.grass enter-PA-1s oh | \glt ` Oh, I'm in a bad way, I am hiding among the grass.'
